Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Fucked up shit!


Heh, that happened when I was playing a live pa once at 2nd and Jackson, 
some fucking douchebag had the balls to steal my drum machine during the 2 
minute window between setup -> preflight check -> quick pee -> start of 
set.  Funny thing is, I had just bent one of the knobs on it a day or two 
before, and was planning to replace it under warranty so I'd just backed 
up all the patterns on it.  It was like a $200 loss at a time when I was 
making fairly good money DJing and doing sound for parties, so it was just 
a cost of doing things really, no major loss except faith in humanity.

I've gotten to the point now that I pretty much play off barely running 
ancient gear, a throwaway midi controller + cheap audio interface + cheap 
old mac g3.  Records used to have this built in security mechanism... they 
weigh a LOT... but even then, I had a full box of records ganked at a 
party once too.

It's weird, cause at 80% of the parties I attend, that is unthinkable.... 
so easy to let your guard down for the other 20%.

andyw

Subject: [sfraves] Allow me to re-introduce mahself

Hi Guys.

So I shared with you 'Street Art' (Wooster Collective) as a way to say  
Hi.  Some of you know me pretty well.  (Hi Terry, Sarilion, Apollo,  
Phillip, Forest, D-Fly and Moksha Tribe!)

I used to lurk  and post periodically on the list like 6-7 years back  
(holly shit time goes by quickly!).   I jumped off when there was too  
much unecessary flaming going on.  I signed back up about 2 weeks ago,  
mainly to hear feedback on Phoenix, and now feel comfy enough to re- 
introduce myself so here goes:

-My Name is Jose
-I hooked up with MokshaTribe through SFR, so I am forever grateful!
-I reside in the South Bay
-I dj, predominantly house music, but can cut up some nice downtempo  
and trip hop too
-I would like to start throwing my own events, because I would like  
the experience of doing my own thing.  I will still be collaborating  
with others Of course! I hope to call on the list from time to time  
for advice, for help, to promote, so on and so forth
-I am always willing to lend a hand if needed
-By day I work with New York Life

I think I will be heading to 'Blissed Out' tonight.  Maybe I will get  
a chance to meet more of you guys in person!

Much Respect,

-Jose Padilla

----- Original Message ----
From: Jose Padilla <4beat.dfd@gmail.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Sent: Friday, April 11, 2008 2:07:35 PM
Subject: [sfraves] Allow me to re-introduce mahself

Hi Guys.

So I shared with you 'Street Art' (Wooster Collective) as a way to say  
Hi.  Some of you know me pretty well.  (Hi Terry, Sarilion, Apollo,  
Phillip, Forest, D-Fly and Moksha Tribe!)

I used to lurk  and post periodically on the list like 6-7 years back  
(holly shit time goes by quickly!).  I jumped off when there was too  
much unecessary flaming going on.  I signed back up about 2 weeks ago,  
mainly to hear feedback on Phoenix, and now feel comfy enough to re- 
introduce myself so here goes:

-My Name is Jose
-I hooked up with MokshaTribe through SFR, so I am forever grateful!
-I reside in the South Bay
-I dj, predominantly house music, but can cut up some nice downtempo  
and trip hop too
-I would like to start throwing my own events, because I would like  
the experience of doing my own thing.  I will still be collaborating  
with others Of course! I hope to call on the list from time to time  
for advice, for help, to promote, so on and so forth
-I am always willing to lend a hand if needed
-By day I work with New York Life

I think I will be heading to 'Blissed Out' tonight.  Maybe I will get  
a chance to meet more of you guys in person!

Much Respect,

-Jose Padilla

>> Phillip, Forest, D-Fly and Moksha Tribe!)
>>
>> I used to lurk  and post periodically on the list like 6-7 years back
>> (holly shit time goes by quickly!).   I jumped off when there was too
>> much unecessary flaming going on.  I signed back up about 2 weeks =20
>> ago,
>> mainly to hear feedback on Phoenix, and now feel comfy enough to re-
>> introduce myself so here goes:
>>
>> -My Name is Jose
>> -I hooked up with MokshaTribe through SFR, so I am forever grateful!
>> -I reside in the South Bay
>> -I dj, predominantly house music, but can cut up some nice downtempo
>> and trip hop too
>> -I would like to start throwing my own events, because I would like
>> the experience of doing my own thing.  I will still be collaborating
>> with others Of course! I hope to call on the list from time to time
>> for advice, for help, to promote, so on and so forth
>> -I am always willing to lend a hand if needed
>> -By day I work with New York Life
>>
>> I think I will be heading to 'Blissed Out' tonight.  Maybe I will get
>> a chance to meet more of you guys in person!

>> Much Respect,

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: (but funny) "Porn star unveils campaign weapon - her bottom"


ROME (Reuters) - She had no desire to be just another smiling face in Italian politics. So when porn star Milly D'Abbraccio designed her campaign posters, it was obvious she was going to show off her bottom.

Targeting her male fan base, the veteran of Italy's adult entertainment industry has plastered images of her derriere all around the Eternal City in a bid to win a seat in Rome's city hall.

If elected, D'Abbraccio wants to create a red light area with strip clubs, erotic discos and sex shops called "Love City" just kilometers away from the Vatican.

"It would be something cute, clean -- nothing to do with prostitution," said the actress whose films include "The Kiss of the Cobra" and "Paolina Borghese, Imperial Nymphomaniac."

...

"People don't want to see these politicians' faces anymore," she told Reuters in an interview from her Rome apartment. 

She said she was tapping into her popularity among pornography fans as "an act of generosity" to help Italy's socialists, who are fielding her in the municipal race.

"I am the derriere of the Socialist party," she concluded.

http://www.reuters.com/article/newsOne/idUSL1080561820080411

I want the t-shirt!

Regards,

Peter

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Vagina-Bong???? WTF?!?!?!

>  vagina+bong is not the new peanut butter+chocolate.

Just a side note. According to Robert Anton Wilson, in the 70s,
Playboy photographers would occasionally put hash blocks inside
models' vaginas to increase the puffiness of the vagina lips and
simultaneously induce a contact high.

Vagina + hash is different from vagina + bong, though, and you should
always be careful about believing things that Robert Anton Wilson
said.

Giles

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: 4x4 bassheavy mix from me.

i've said i dig 4=D74 tracks with a strong bass element, but could never
make a whole mix out of it.  well, this makes me a

h y p o c r i t e
32 minutes of wall rattling 4tothefloor tunes, featuring:

a1 bassline - somebody
just 4 jokes feat mc rb - jump up (2 digital take 2) (zj edit)
chemical brothers - bongoloid
3 play - girl in the taxi (4=D74 mix)
hotflush - motion
erbs - heaven
virus syndicate - digital (darqwan remix)
60 hz - sneaky
detboi - just can't hold back
a1 bassline - girl thing f/ safi
detboi - gunshot lean forward
detboi - drop the bass
a1 bassline - my baby f/ safi
zero productions - the big bang (bass remix)
rogue state - jaisha (zj edit)
a1 bassline - its alot
detboi - hold up

available at http://zombie-j.com/wordpress/?p=3D18

--=20
jason
6th Floor Sessions Podcast
http://zombie-j.com

Subject: Re: [sfraves] giles needs techno mix mp3s



Actually, been meaning to ask folks... As much as I love techno, I almost
never have enough time to actually LISTEN to it outside of parties... I
mean sure, before I'll book a DJ I've not seen spin, I'll require a demo
and listen to that just to make sure it's a style that'll play to the
audience I expect would show up, but outside of that I find it's really
hard to find enough time to listen to a complete mix.  How does everyone
else do it?  It seems for me like I'm busy working, or running around and
taking care of stuff, not listening to techno unless I'm at a party.

As far as Forest, she spins enough and varies her track selections enough
how would you pick what to make available?  I would like for her to get
more out of town bookings, as she deserves a bigger audience than we've
got here in SF, you really think sticking some mixes up would help that?
Personally, I'm hoping to get her to produce some more tracks, but I'm
busy enough working on promo to chase after recording tracks just yet. :-\

ray

        b=Eqn/XONGzjNDclzn2FnhE8DB6W4HPSAdakgsZsfxxWGAaDi8C8IaFIWUuVO65SiDn+0ZoCrVa2xWqsVfKVfJ5F3yKY2yUAEtpBmSBVl0fQsC0zUk9zY/UBDDzjPVw3FKsmmTYVRjXFAHAmu1aK+AsTY6iBs2tG8wLCBG5gGsaKg=

Message-ID: <4688f3110804141057u6c012cb4xc3ffb401965ceefb@mail.gmail.com>
Date: Mon, 14 Apr 2008 10:57:16 -0700
From: "Giles Soundwave" <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>
To: "Ray Wong" <rayw@rayw.net>
Cc: "sf raves" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
In-Reply-To: <20080414032106.GQ6323@jmmredux.doomba.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline
References: <4688f3110804131957y15e7cb29lea72d110a56180cf@mail.gmail.com>
	 <20080414032106.GQ6323@jmmredux.doomba.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] giles needs techno mix mp3s

>  As far as Forest, she spins enough and varies her track selections enough
>  how would you pick what to make available?  I would like for her to get
>  more out of town bookings, as she deserves a bigger audience than we've
>  got here in SF, you really think sticking some mixes up would help that?
>  Personally, I'm hoping to get her to produce some more tracks, but I'm
>  busy enough working on promo to chase after recording tracks just yet. :-\

Well OK. Here's the thing. Producing tracks is the main way people
hear about out-of-town DJs. So yes producing tracks to get out-of-town
bookings, plenty much logic. Howeva. Many producers now complain about
people putting their tracks on Soulseek before they're even released.
I've never had any luck at all with my releases or attempts at
releases so I can't say for sure but the impression I get is that the
same damage that MP3 did to the major labels is happening somewhat in
the DJ world as well.

But then again I don't believe it. The reason is I stopped buying
records and then bought a few because of stuff I heard on MP3. I knew
that it'd only be available for a limited time and I knew that if I
ever did start buying records again I'd kick myself for not having
those particular records. So I started buying records again **just in
case** I ever started buying records again. And as crazy as that is,
it's an instance of MP3 availability creating sales rather than
destroying them. And a team of Harvard economists found that MP3 has
the same effect for nearly everybody in the music industry except for
the big stars. So it could be that the damage MP3's caused the music
industry is due to an overemphasis on Lindsey Lohans and an
underemphasis on Forest Greens.

I forgot my point. Which is why I didn't want to respond because it's
so easy to go off on these sorts of tangents. Especially since it ties
into a presentation I'm preparing and some code I'm working on and a
theory I have about the business side of EDM. It's wicked faskinatin.
Howeva. Should Forest Green put up her mixes for download? YES! Any
time your fans are trying to hear your music and they can't, that's a
bad thing. And if I had Forest Green MP3s on my iPod people could be
hearing them in Edinburgh, London, Los Angeles, New Mexico,
Philadelphia, and Utah, because I travel all over the freaking place
and I like to tell people about the music I'm listening to. And it's
not as if I'm this incredible exception to the rule. The number of
people who take their iPods with them when they fly is actually quite
large. And literally everywhere I've ever been people are sharing DJ
mixes with each other, and nobody in their right mind is going to
refuse to listen to a mix because it comes from some other town. YES
FOREST SHOULD MAKE HER MIXES DOWNLOADABLE!!!!! Sheesh.

I can rant all day, so, I'll stop, but yes I have a firm opinion here
and that's what it be.

-- 
Giles Soundwave/Goat Boy/Bowkett
http://www.gilesgoatboy.org/
http://gilesbowkett.blogspot.com (code)

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Interesting.  I have some (I suspect) similar ideas about business implications of EDM "business models" to the wider music business.  I tried to pursue some of these back at Live365, but didn't get to far...

I also see that you have an interest in metaprogramming.  I am currently writing a meta-program to generate clustering algorithms in Mathematica.  Fun!

Subject: Re: [sfraves] giles needs techno mix mp3s

> Interesting.  I have some (I suspect) similar ideas about business implications of EDM
> "business models" to the wider music business.  I tried to pursue some of these back
> at Live365, but didn't get to far...

Just found something where the Plump DJs say there's not a lot of
money to be made in releasing albums any more. So maybe it's true
across genres, rather than just being a Top 40 thing.

http://www.bijoubreaks.com/forums/viewtopic.php?t=20490

>  I also see that you have an interest in metaprogramming.  I am currently writing a
> meta-program to generate clustering algorithms in Mathematica.  Fun!
>
>  Also I think I will steal your Darth Vader slide.

The Darth Vader thing turned into a huge meme at that conference. If
you're into that stuff keep an eye on my blog, I'm doing a
presentation on music-generating code in late April in New York, it'll
be available as video and it'll have some interesting bits. (It's
mostly for an audience not savvy to EDM but with an interesting Webby
perspective on business.)

Anyway, there are actually two Darth Vader slides, plus one with R2D2,
and Boba Fett, but he's wearing a fez rather than a sombrero. I'm
fairly certain I stole the original Darth slide from a Bay Area crew
throwing parties, so if it's stolen back there's no harm in that.

Holt Sorenson <hso@hsomusic.com> wrote: 
Please tune in to KZSU by listening to 90.1 in the Bay Area or pointing
your web browser to http://kzsulive.stanford.edu.

We changed our streams two weeks ago. If you have bookmarked the streams,
please visit the kzsulive using the link above and save a new copy
of the stream you use. The change we made should make our streams
accessible to more listeners because the stream now runs over the
same access method (port) as the traffic (http) that the web uses.
If you've tried to listen in the past and were unable to, give it
another go.

If you're interested in guest appearing on any of our shows
or having a mix featured contact us using our email addresses
or: electronicadjs@kzsu.stanford.edu

Big Love Show with Jack - Mondays 3PM-6PM PST (11PM UTC)
--------------------------------------------------------------------------

Jack is hosting DJ Scott Binder this week. Scott brings
an exciting, electrifying, and energizing mix of Djing
and live music when ever he throws down a set. This power
house draws on his experience from sharing the stage with
two Grammy award winning percussionists and is emerging
onto the electronic music culture as a must hear attraction.
His captivating stage presence and ability to engage the
crowd is part of why Scott Binder is a much requested DJ
and live performer on the West Coast and the European music
scene. More infos on Scott Binder at:
http://www.djscottbinder.com

Eclektronik Groove w/ Holt Sorenson - Thu 6AM-9AM PDT (9AM EDT)
--------------------------------------------------------------------------

Holt's away from the station this week. Catch his show at it's
new time on thusday the 24th.

Epiphany of Sound with J.C. - Thursday 9AM-12PM PDT (12PM EDT)
-------------------------------------------------------------------------

After 14 years, DJ J.C.'s techno/house/electronica showcase has
garnered much attention and devotion. Like most folks at Stanford's
radio station, he's a volunteer, proving that his motivation isn't
a paycheck; it's his passion to share his interest in one of music's
most eclectic genres. With his conversational style, inclusion of
producers and musicians from both the local & international scene,
and his stewardship of the station's 24-hour marathons during
Solstices and Equinoxes, it's no wonder that DJ J.C has made a
connection with listeners in a very crowded market. Catch his live
broadcasts or listen to the previous week's program at underheard.org.

J.C. will email this week if he has an update on any guests.

Thanks for your support!!!

--
Holt Sorenson/Eclektronik Groove
hso@hsomusic.com
hsomusic.com - myspace.com/hsomusic
KZSU (kzsulive.stanford.edu) show on Mon Nite/Tues Morn. 12-3AM

From: dangrsmind@yahoo.com
To: Giles Soundwave <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>
Cc: sf raves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Message-ID: <968996.43207.qm@web32405.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] giles needs techno mix mp3s

Its clearly not just a top 40 thing.  In fact its not just about music or movies, even though these get all the press.  It is about anything that can be digitized and shared as digital data file.  This includes software, books, photographs, and many other products of applied knowledge.

What are the forces at work that have led to the decline of music sales? IMO we have three:

First we have ubiquitous connectivity.  I can get on the network pretty much anywhere I am and almost anytime I need music.  And I can connect to anyone, anywhere, that has some music to share with me.

Second, we have extreme media abundance.  I receive more links to music than I actually have time to listen to.  And there are litteraly thousands of hours of free music in almost every genre available.  If you just spend a short time looking, you'll find more music than you need, and it will be almost all free.

Third, we have easily accessible algorithmic search.  If I want to find music by any artist, a specific track, etc. I use Google or some other form of algorithmic search to find it.  I don't wait to hear something on the radio or for word of mouth or  for anything else.  I can actively search and find exaclty the music I want.

These three forces have brought us to where we are today with the music industry teetering on the brink of collapse.  Thi sis large part because their primary purposes have become obsolete.  Labels existed originally so that muscians could find an audience to sell their works and so that the audience could find music it would enjoy.  However, the labels existing expertise in these areas is quickly becoming irrelevant in the age of ubiquitous connection, media abundance, and algorithmic search.  I simply connect and search for what I want.  To the extent that underground artists and labels have copied the classical record label business models based around outdated ideas like scarcity of copies, difficulty of finding new artists, etc. these  three forces will have a similar impact on their wallets.  That game is simply over, and people really should stop playing it.

But now things get really interesting since we have two more powerful forces about to come into play:

1. Virtually unlimited storage
2. Virtually unlimited computation via scalable grid computing

At its peak Live365 offered over 40,000 different MP3 streams.  We built a server farm with 4 terabytes of network attached storage to serve these streams.  Today many personal computers ship with 1 terabyte, and you can buy external terabyte drives at Costco.  The smallest iPod already has the capability to hold more music than most people will ever listen to (a survey taken around ten years back showed that the average American owned less than 20 CDs), but beyond that soon you'll be able to store every song ever recorded on an affordable removable and portable storage device.  Its just a matter of time before people start selling drives on the black market preloaded with entire categories or genres of music.  Someone recently offered a "complete" set of recorded music on eBay collected exactly for this purpose on might suppose.  See http://www.boingboing.net/2008/02/18/worlds-most-complete.html

The availability of essentailly unlimited on demand computing makes possible a range of media processing tasks that can only be partially imagined today.  For example, a few years back I proposed the idea of creating a playlist "renderer" that could render a defined playlist of music against an arbitrary music library.  If a specific track was not present in the library the renderer might select another similar sounding track, a track by the same artist, a track with similar theme and mood, etc. This all hinges on having a complex database of musical metadata either derived from human inputs such as tags or directly extracted from an examination of the audio signal itself.  Processing audio data to extract these sorts of signals is only now becoming possible on desktop machines, see for example http://www.fxpal.com/publications/FXPAL-PR-03-204.PDF but you can expect future applications to use the grid to do things like extracting signals, rendering
 playlists, computing new music recommendations, etc. or even generating new algorithmic music on the fly. 

And while the industry touts its online sales via iTunes (http://news.moneycentral.msn.com/ticker/article.aspx?Feed=AP&Date=20080103&ID=7992868&Symbol=SNE) the dirty secret is that fewer than 5% of music consumers actually purchase music online.  The industry is in deep trouble, and the Apple alone isn't going to save them.  True Apple's the number one music retailer now, but some might recall that the previous number one retailer, tower Reocrds, is no defunct. 

So back to EDM and raves...I would suggest that EDM artists and labels need to align their business models with these five forces if they want to avoid the fate of the RIAA labels/artists who have resisted the obvious until it is almost too late.  We've already seen a large decline in vinyl sales as many people started buying digital tracks at places like Beatport.  And this has led to a glut of used vinyl, such that even vinyl purists are buying less new stuff.  

The good news is that the existing track & party based model is very adaptable to the online environment, and many artists are poised to take advantage of their existing social networks, distribute new music without the need to produce a physical recording  They simply don't need to have a label in the classical sense.  People in the EDM scene are tech savvy and ready to find music online from services offering what they want.  The rest of the music industry is likely to lag here as the technical savvy of music consumers varies pretty widely.

IMO. YMMV.

Peter

----- Original Message ----
From: Giles Soundwave <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>

> Interesting.  I have some (I suspect) similar ideas about business implications of EDM
> "business models" to the wider music business.  I tried to pursue some of these back
> at Live365, but didn't get to far...

Just found something where the Plump DJs say there's not a lot of
money to be made in releasing albums any more. So maybe it's true
across genres, rather than just being a Top 40 thing.

> until it is almost too late.  We've already seen a large decline in vinyl 
> sales as many people started buying digital tracks at places like 
> Beatport.  And this has led to a glut of used vinyl, such that even vinyl 
> purists are buying less new stuff.
>
> The good news is that the existing track & party based model is very 
> adaptable to the online environment, and many artists are poised to take 
> advantage of their existing social networks, distribute new music without 
> the need to produce a physical recording  They simply don't need to have a 
> label in the classical sense.  People in the EDM scene are tech savvy and 
> ready to find music online from services offering what they want.  The 
> rest of the music industry is likely to lag here as the technical savvy of 
> music consumers varies pretty widely.
>
> IMO. YMMV.
>
> Peter
>
> ----- Original Message ----
> From: Giles Soundwave <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>
> To: dangrsmind@yahoo.com
> Cc: sf raves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
> Sent: Monday, April 14, 2008 2:33:35 PM
> Subject: Re: [sfraves] giles needs techno mix mp3s
>
>> Interesting.  I have some (I suspect) similar ideas about business 
>> implications of EDM
>> "business models" to the wider music business.  I tried to pursue some of 
>> these back
>> at Live365, but didn't get to far...
>
> Just found something where the Plump DJs say there's not a lot of
> money to be made in releasing albums any more. So maybe it's true
> across genres, rather than just being a Top 40 thing.
>

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Hysteria: A Benefit for the Women's Community Clinic

Just wanted to let folks know about a truly worthwhile benefit event that's
coming up later this week: Hysteria.  It's a Benefit for the Women's
Community Clinic, the only totally free clinic dedicated to serving the needs
of the uninsured/underinsured women of San Francisco by providing both
free health care and education.

I can sell tickets to whoever wants to buy them.  I'm sure it will be a
wonderfully fun evening, which includes a comedy performance from
Caroline Rhea (www.carolinerhea.com), a silent auction with over 140
fabulous items up for bid, a fully catered reception with delicious food as
well as an open bar sponsored by Anchor Steam, Seltzer Sisters, Miette
Organic Patisserie, Ritual Coffee Roasters, Craft Distillers, Hangar 1
Vodka and Cabot Vermont.  All guests receive a personal  gift bag to take
home.  In addition, your $100 ticket is valid for a $40 tax deductible
donation and your money supports an amazing, grass roots health clinic
that proves that it's truly possible to provide free, quality health care to
women, by women.

"There are no words to describe what the Women's Community Clinic
means to me. There are no words to describe what the Women's
Community Clinic means to this city. An excellent resource for women
with no health insurance. I am now fully insured and consider the treatment
I received at this clinic equal, and at times better, than what I now receive
at my health care provider"
- A Clinic Client

To hear more about how the Women's Community Clinic helps out the
women of San Francisco, listen to clinic director Carlina Hansen on
KQED's "Forum" here: http://www.kqed.org/epArchive/R803201000 as
well as on Women's Life Radio here:
http://www.womensradio.com/content/templates/?a=2354&z=25

The benefit will be happening on Thursday April 17th from 6p-9p at the
Jewish Community Center of San Francisco at 3200 California St.  People
who regularly attend local benefits have stated that they felt they were
stealing from the clinic by getting such a great event in return for their
donation.

And if I sell enough tickets I'll be able to get a free one for my girlfriend,
who volunteers at the clinic.  So please consider attending!

Thank you in advance!



--

http://www.sfbg.com/promo/pollpositions.php

----- Original Message ----- 
From: <dangrsmind@yahoo.com>
To: "Giles Soundwave" <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>
Cc: "sf raves" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Monday, April 14, 2008 4:36 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] giles needs techno mix mp3s


> Its clearly not just a top 40 thing.  In fact its not just about music or 
> movies, even though these get all the press.  It is about anything that 
> can be digitized and shared as digital data file.  This includes software, 
> books, photographs, and many other products of applied knowledge.
>
> What are the forces at work that have led to the decline of music sales? 
> IMO we have three:
>
> First we have ubiquitous connectivity.  I can get on the network pretty 
> much anywhere I am and almost anytime I need music.  And I can connect to 
> anyone, anywhere, that has some music to share with me.
>
> Second, we have extreme media abundance.  I receive more links to music 
> than I actually have time to listen to.  And there are litteraly thousands 
> of hours of free music in almost every genre available.  If you just spend 
> a short time looking, you'll find more music than you need, and it will be 
> almost all free.
>
> Third, we have easily accessible algorithmic search.  If I want to find 
> music by any artist, a specific track, etc. I use Google or some other 
> form of algorithmic search to find it.  I don't wait to hear something on 
> the radio or for word of mouth or  for anything else.  I can actively 
> search and find exaclty the music I want.
>
> These three forces have brought us to where we are today with the music 
> industry teetering on the brink of collapse.  Thi sis large part because 
> their primary purposes have become obsolete.  Labels existed originally so 
> that muscians could find an audience to sell their works and so that the 
> audience could find music it would enjoy.  However, the labels existing 
> expertise in these areas is quickly becoming irrelevant in the age of 
> ubiquitous connection, media abundance, and algorithmic search.  I simply 
> connect and search for what I want.  To the extent that underground 
> artists and labels have copied the classical record label business models 
> based around outdated ideas like scarcity of copies, difficulty of finding 
> new artists, etc. these  three forces will have a similar impact on their 
> wallets.  That game is simply over, and people really should stop playing 
> it.
>
> But now things get really interesting since we have two more powerful 
> forces about to come into play:
>
> 1. Virtually unlimited storage
> 2. Virtually unlimited computation via scalable grid computing
>
> At its peak Live365 offered over 40,000 different MP3 streams.  We built a 
> server farm with 4 terabytes of network attached storage to serve these 
> streams.  Today many personal computers ship with 1 terabyte, and you can 
> buy external terabyte drives at Costco.  The smallest iPod already has the 
> capability to hold more music than most people will ever listen to (a 
> survey taken around ten years back showed that the average American owned 
> less than 20 CDs), but beyond that soon you'll be able to store every song 
> ever recorded on an affordable removable and portable storage device.  Its 
> just a matter of time before people start selling drives on the black 
> market preloaded with entire categories or genres of music.  Someone 
> recently offered a "complete" set of recorded music on eBay collected 
> exactly for this purpose on might suppose.  See 
> http://www.boingboing.net/2008/02/18/worlds-most-complete.html
>
> The availability of essentailly unlimited on demand computing makes 
> possible a range of media processing tasks that can only be partially 
> imagined today.  For example, a few years back I proposed the idea of 
> creating a playlist "renderer" that could render a defined playlist of 
> music against an arbitrary music library.  If a specific track was not 
> present in the library the renderer might select another similar sounding 
> track, a track by the same artist, a track with similar theme and mood, 
> etc. This all hinges on having a complex database of musical metadata 
> either derived from human inputs such as tags or directly extracted from 
> an examination of the audio signal itself.  Processing audio data to 
> extract these sorts of signals is only now becoming possible on desktop 
> machines, see for example 
> http://www.fxpal.com/publications/FXPAL-PR-03-204.PDF but you can expect 
> future applications to use the grid to do things like extracting signals, 
> rendering
> playlists, computing new music recommendations, etc. or even generating 
> new algorithmic music on the fly.
>
> And while the industry touts its online sales via iTunes 
> (http://news.moneycentral.msn.com/ticker/article.aspx?Feed=AP&Date=20080103&ID=7992868&Symbol=SNE) 
> the dirty secret is that fewer than 5% of music consumers actually 
> purchase music online.  The industry is in deep trouble, and the Apple 
> alone isn't going to save them.  True Apple's the number one music 
> retailer now, but some might recall that the previous number one retailer, 
> tower Reocrds, is no defunct.
>
> So back to EDM and raves...I would suggest that EDM artists and labels 
> need to align their business models with these five forces if they want to 
> avoid the fate of the RIAA labels/artists who have resisted the obvious 
> until it is almost too late.  We've already seen a large decline in vinyl 
> sales as many people started buying digital tracks at places like 
> Beatport.  And this has led to a glut of used vinyl, such that even vinyl 
> purists are buying less new stuff.
>
> The good news is that the existing track & party based model is very 
> adaptable to the online environment, and many artists are poised to take 
> advantage of their existing social networks, distribute new music without 
> the need to produce a physical recording  They simply don't need to have a 
> label in the classical sense.  People in the EDM scene are tech savvy and 
> ready to find music online from services offering what they want.  The 
> rest of the music industry is likely to lag here as the technical savvy of 
> music consumers varies pretty widely.
>
> IMO. YMMV.
>
> Peter
>
> ----- Original Message ----
> From: Giles Soundwave <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>
> To: dangrsmind@yahoo.com
> Cc: sf raves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>

> across genres, rather than just being a Top 40 thing.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] giles needs techno mix mp3s

great post, Peter.

As far as new distribution models for music go, I'd like to see  
something like a subscription service for labels or individual  
artists. For instance, if I find an artist whose music I really like,  
I could buy a subscription to their releases, maybe a few bucks a  
month, and whenever they put out a new track it pops up in my music  
library for me to listen to, play out, etc.

The benefits of this system would be:

- the artist gets ongoing income, and has a direct connection with  
their fan base
- as a subscriber, I become a direct patron of the artist and help  
support their creative work
- I don't have to go looking for new tracks - they come to me

This of course could function in parallel with other distribution/ 
sales models.

I think this would be a good and viable alternative to the top-down  
megaconglomerate music distribution model, which I, like Peter,  
believe is on its way out, and not a moment too soon.

philip

---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

In-Reply-To: <968996.43207.qm@web32405.mail.mud.yahoo.com>

References: <968996.43207.qm@web32405.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] giles needs techno mix mp3s

> simply connect and search for what I want.  To the extent that
> underground artists and labels have copied the classical record
> label business models based around outdated ideas like scarcity
> of copies, difficulty of finding new artists, etc. these  three forces
> will have a similar impact on their wallets.  That game is simply over,
> and people really should stop playing it.

I agree. Check this out:

http://www.kk.org/thetechnium/archives/2008/01/better_than_fre.php

>  The good news is that the existing track & party based model is
> very adaptable to the online environment, and many artists are
> poised to take advantage of their existing social networks, distribute
> new music without the need to produce a physical recording  They
> simply don't need to have a label in the classical sense.  People in
> the EDM scene are tech savvy and ready to find music online from
> services offering what they want.  The rest of the music industry is
> likely to lag here as the technical savvy of music consumers
> varies pretty widely.

Yes indeed. But I don't think the subscription model will work out. I
think that model has its heart in the right place but still assumes
scarcity. Check this out:

http://shirky.com/writings/fame_vs_fortune.html

Probably the only way to make money as a musician in the future will
be to give away music and charge for something else - such as live
performance, or music customized for particular situations (as in the
Kevin Kelly link).

This is why algorithmic composition matters. If you can't charge for
music any more, you need to be able to make as much original music as
possible, and ideally not only charge for live performance, but also
guarantee that the music in your live performance is guaranteed to be
unique.

Algorithmic composition ftw.

-- 
Giles Soundwave/Goat Boy/Bowkett
http://www.gilesgoatboy.org/
http://gilesbowkett.blogspot.com (code)

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Tax Day joke

Found at http://www.joketribe.com/bawdy/96/June/JobTitle.html


A woman walks into her accountant's office and tells him that she needs 
to file her taxes.

The accountant says, "Before we begin, I'll need to ask a few 
questions."

He gets her name, address, social security number, etc. and then asks, 
"What is your occupation?"

The woman replies, "I'm a whore."

The accountant balks and says, "No, no, no. That will never work.

That is much too crass. Let's try to rephrase that."

The woman, "Ok, I'm a prostitute."

"No, that is still too crude. Try again."

They both think for a minute, then the woman states, "I'm a chicken 
farmer."

The accountant asks, "What does chicken farming have to do with being a 
whore or a prostitute?"

"Well, I raised over 5,000 cocks last year."




-- 
San Francisco Bay Guardian's Readers Choice Award Winner: Best Radio DJ:
http://www.sfbg.com/promo/pollpositions.php
AIM: jckzsu (or kzsudj during my show.)

"Opinions are my own only, and do not necessarily represent those of
KZSU Radio or Stanford University." (or words to that effect.)

sfraves post from =9293 re: pulgas water temple full moon


"Date: Fri, 4 Jun 93 13:02:29 PDT
From: geoffw@nexsys.net (Geoff White)
Subject: June Moon Tune

This months FMR was at Pulgas Water Temple, an eerie neo-grecco-roman =20=

outdoor promanade situated in the wilderness of San Mateo county. The =20=

site is actually the terminus for the hetch hetchy water acquaduct =20
that supplies the reservoir system of San Francisco. The park is small =20=

but beautiful with a flat area for dancing, a long shallow reflective =20=

pool and an open dome or circular arch suppoorted by columns in the =20
middle of which is a hole from which you can look down at thousands of =20=

gallons of swirling water. It was nice to play the mythical mind game =20=

of what a couple of kilos of sid could do... but then we have =20
something better, the Vibe.

All of the parking along canada road is illegal (no parking signs =20
everywhere) by when I arrived at 0300 most cars were neatly parked =20
along the road, maybe about 150 - 200 cars, this was a relief to me as =20=

I usualy park cars for these things and it was good to see that the =20
community can take up the slack if I'm not there.

Even though the site was secured and people had been arriving en-mass, =20=

by 0345 the sound system, though set up had not started yet, (The FMR =20=

seems to be plagued with sound system problems, it would be nice if =20
they checked the stuff out before hand or arrived earlier, cuz it =20
always takes them 45 - 1 hour to get the sound working) but by 0400 =20
Garth was spinning the groove right along. The weather was just the =20
right temperature, and even though the moon became obscured by clouds, =20=

we could still feel her presence. Garth started to kick some really =20
funky tunes, and I could see that this could turn out to be another =20
incredible/evolutionary FMR when... the Police showed up.

It was just a lone car at first, I saw him at the top of the hill =20
shining his flashlight and whatever, I decides not to go up right =20
away, let him take it all in for a bit (besides, I really didn't want =20=

to do it) but eventualy no one else was around who was gonna do it so =20=

I decided to make initial contact. I gave my sacrements to a friend =20
for safe keeping and walked up the hill...

"Hi ya doin officer!"
"What's goin on down there" he says.
I say, "Well I think it's one of those rave party things, or something"
"Is this your party?"
Who me! NO, I'm just coming up to see whats happening"
He say "Well I sugguest that you leave right away cuz I just called my =20=

sargent and all of these people are going to jail"
I think to myself yeah buddy, you and what army, but I say "Well my =20
girlfriend is still down there, let me go get her OK?" This works =20
every time :)
"OK but I'd get her and leave right away if I were you."

So back down the hill I go, this is a usual first contact, next we let =20=

him sit for a while, see how many more show up. About 20 minutes later =20=

a LOT of crusiers show, CHP, redwood city, sheriff, SanMateo, maybe 13 =20=

- 20 cars. They start giving orders to disperse but the music is too =20
loud, Garth is throwing down some vicious trax, no-one would be going =20=

anyplace anyway, even if they could hear the order. Next thing I know, =20=

they're putting on riot gear! Shit, well is this the time to make the =20=

headlines? OR what? I am a vetran of the 60's and 70's demostrations, =20=

I knew that Pulgas was an enclosed area with the only method of escape =20=

blocked by the cops. The whole area is fenced in. If they could keep =20
us from leaving out the front, we could all be scooped up and arrested =20=

en masse (maybe not a bad idea) but some ravers would most likely =20
climb the fence and try to escape into the wilderness behind them. =20
There is an acquaduct and other stuff back there. Maybe defusing is in =20=

order. I go back up the hill and ask to speak to the person in =20
command. They want to know If I'm in control of the crowd, if not, =20
then I don't need to speak to anybody. I tell them that no-one is in =20
control, (a fact they find hard to fathom) but that I'm concerned, I =20
don't want any violence, to ensue and that I can carry a message to =20
the group.

Someone said that we want you guys to leave, we won't hassle anybody =20
if you just leave, I tell them that the riot gear is intimidating and =20=

unnecessary, we are a peaceful bunch but the riot stuff is scareing =20
people and when they are scared, they would rather stay together as a =20=

Family I they were going to be clubed. Just at that moment so police =20
officer turned on a high powered spot light that illuminated the area, =20=

some ravers got up in front of it and did some great "shadow dancing" =20=

the shadows were projected against the trees on the far side of the =20
temple making dancing figures 20 or 30 ft high. Truely on of the best =20=

visuals I've ever seen at a rave! Even the cops got a kick out of it =20
(those that could admit it) this seemed to chill them out a bit, a =20
couple laughed. My hats go off to the dancers whoever they are, who =20
made a truely transformational move in a scarey situation, it took =20
courage! I go back down the hill and back into the crowd, people are =20
talking about "sitting down" and stuff, well we'll see. Eventualy the =20=

cops send three or for officers in riot gear down to the DJ area and =20
stop Garth from playing. Everybody claps and cheers for Garth but =20
holds there ground. They didn't threaten the Police in any way, but =20
they did send the message that we were a family. After the music =20
stopped some people discussed what to do. I went back up the Hill to =20
"negotiate" with the police. They agreed to not arrest anyone or =20
confiscate any equipment so long as we leave now. I told them I =20
thought that would fly but that It would take time to break down the =20
sound system, when the sound system gets taken apart, people will =20
slowly leave. Just as some consensus seemed to be reached. A female =20
officer gets on one of their bull horns and starts in on people about =20=

how they have been nice so far but our patience is wearing thin, etc. =20=

I walked over to her...

"Excuse me, mam, um, mam, that's not helping". I start to have a talk =20=

with her, (sending her the Vibe in a big way) I told her that these =20
kids were peaceful, there is no need for beligerence, the riot gear =20
and helmuts are scaring people. she totally GETS IT! She takes of her =20=

helmut to reveal all of this thick, beautiful, long, blond flowing =20
hair! We walk down the hill together and I tell her about the scene =20
and why we have the full moon parties, she notices and comments on how =20=

there are people from every race present and every one seems calm and =20=

happy, they aren't sending her any bad vibes. I tell her that is what =20=

it's all about. This isn't about gangs, it's about Love, I watched her =20=

lighten up before my eyes. She told me her name was Ali and I told her =20=

mine, we walked along and I told her that we tried to choose places =20
that were remote so that the not just the cops but other negative =20
elements would have difficulty finding us. I told her that there is no =20=

hard drug use, maybe a little pot but nothing like crack or heroin (I =20=

didn't mention the e word), I told her that our scene is about Unity =20
and we welcome everyone. I invited her to come to one when she's off =20
duty, provided she won't arrest anyone :). By this ravers are going =20
around picking up trash (this blew her away) and cops and ravers are =20
at least being plesant to each other. I thought to myself, wow I =20
really charmed this big blond police officer, she's about my age, =20
maybe ... nayh , it would NEVER work :) So I said goodbye to Officer =20
Ali and told her that I hope if we meet in the future, it will always =20=

be on plesant terms, she thanked me for walking with her and chatting. =20=

We left it at that.

The FMR was moved to candlestick, I didn't follow.

I consider what happened there to be a success, a confrontation was =20
avoided (it was not the place to engague this issue, someday maybe) =20
and I know at least some police were educated about raves and ravers, =20=

(I am sure officer Ali has a different viewpoint). The important thing =20=

is a change in consciousnes occured both for the ravers and for the =20
police. Ultimately when all of the rhetoric is said and done, it =20
personal and individual action that makes the biggest difference. I =20
saw Ali talking to some ravers she seemed to have pulled over (two =20
young girls) I just hope that my talk had some influence in what ever =20=

business she had to conduct with them.

NEXUS SYSTEMS/CYBERTRIBE-5 : Voice:(415)965-2384 Fax: (415)327-6416 =20
Editor/Instigator/Catalyst : Geoff White Production Crew : Universal =20
Movement Trinity
"They might stop the party, but they can't stop the future"



Apollo
apollo@speakeasy.org

MySpace:  http://www.myspace.com/DJApollo

Tribenet:   http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k

Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"There is suffering in life, and there are defeats. No one can avoid =20
them. But it's better to lose some of the battles in the struggles for =20=

your dreams than to be defeated without ever knowing what you're =20
fighting for."  -Paulo Coelho

"Suffering and joy teach us, if we allow them, how to make the leap of =20=

empathy, which transports us into the soul and heart of another =20
person. ln those transparent moments we know other people's joys and =20
sorrows, and we care about their concerns as if they were our own."  -=20=

Fritz Williams

"I hate to advocate drugs, alcohol, violence or insanity to anyone, =20
but it worked for me." -Hunter S. Thompson

down in New Mexico and I think they need to run BART down there.  It =20

Just remember, Alex Jones says the majority doesn't want open borders, =20
but Jesse Ventura doesn't want to live in East Berlin and Ian thinks =20
the term 'illegal alien' stabs the very notion of liberty right in the =20
back.  All profound opinions, though we assume Alex is referring to =20
opinion polls, but I know that you get all your news and information =20
from ABC-7, which is owned by ABC, which is owned by Disney.  So next =20
time we have Moksha Tribe party, let's make sure to give Terry a =20
break, and we'll just all wear suits and watch Fox News while we dance =20
to 1997 Newport cigarette fuck you I like hard trance house sucks music.

everywhere.  They're trying to set up automated spying systems, just
to collate data, but they can't get us all.  We're the majority.  The
majority doesn't want the war, the majority doesn't want open borders,

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] wav file metadata and iTunes

--0-1646744236-1208366695=:34033
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

Hola,

I'm looking at different solutions to scale the organization of metadata-less content, aka wav files.  I have two goals to tackle:

1)  The current idea for the directory structure is Genre => Sub Genre => Year Month => Track.wav.  Does anyone have any feedback on this?  Or other possible solutions?

2)   This is a little more tricky.  Given that wav files don't have metadata, I'm trying to figure out the best solution to:
    a)  Easily sort through music
    b)  Keep relevant data across multiple platforms
    c) Maintain something that won't become obsolete

I've read that there are programs that will add some metadata bytes to the beginning of wav files, but don't know if they will be read properly, if at all, by different music programs or devices.

The next (and probably only real solution)  I've come up with is using iTunes and only iTunes and writing a program to parse the iTunes XML and recreate it with the relevant information taken out of the file name and placed into the proper tags.  I'd prefer not to take this approach, as it limits to only iTunes, but given the popularity of iTunes and the iPod among all the new music devices coming out, I think this may be the only approach.

Any ideas?

Thank you,
Phillip



--0-1646744236-1208366695=:34033--

won't display it, but the files are just wavs for playback purposes)  
but a python script could easily parse out the embedded metadata.

Beating the Odds
in Etcetera & Pop Culture & Science

It has come to light that men who ejaculate more than five times a =20
week are a third less likely to develop prostate cancer later in life. =20=

Recent studies show that cancer-causing cells in the prostate don't =20
build up in men who masturbate regularly, particularly in their 20s. =20
That's masturbating, not sexual intercourse; with fucking there's =20
always that possibility of contracting a sexually transmitted =20
infection, which increases the risk of cancer. A researcher puts it =20
simply: "It's a prostatic stagnation hypothesis. The more you flush =20
the ducts out, the less there is to hang around and damage the cells =20
that line them." Now here's a picture =96 go flush those ducts. (BBC =
News)


apollo@speakeasy.org

MySpace:  http://www.myspace.com/DJApollo

Tribenet:   http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k

Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm



"No wonder kids grow up crazy," the midget says. "A cat's cradle is =20
nothing but a bunch of X's between somebody's hands, and little kids =20
look and look and look at all those X's..."
"And?"
"No damn cat, and no damn cradle."
-Kurt Vonnegut

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of =20
the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will =20
gradually become visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

<<<What is Stilldream?>>>
Stilldream is something different for everyone. Ask anyone who=92s been and=
 they
have a hard time coming up with words to describe what it means to them. Al=
l
we can say is, "Its not a party, its an experience. You have to go to under=
stand".

Since many Stilldreamers live in different areas of California, the west co=
ast and
the U.S., fundraisers are a way that we can all reunite under one roof duri=
ng the
rest of the year as we all anxiously await the return of the Anniversary ev=
ent.
Some say its a warm-up party to get those creative juices flowing, so we ca=
n hit
the ground running for the Campout.

<<<So This is It!>>>

y area.

ming

At 10:31 PM 4/15/2008, you wrote:
>sfraves post from '93 re: pulgas water temple full moon
>
>
>"Date: Fri, 4 Jun 93 13:02:29 PDT
>From: geoffw@nexsys.net (Geoff White)
>Subject: June Moon Tune
>
>This months FMR was at Pulgas Water Temple, an eerie neo-grecco-roman
>outdoor promanade situated in the wilderness of San Mateo county. The
>site is actually the terminus for the hetch hetchy water acquaduct
>that supplies the reservoir system of San Francisco. The park is small
>but beautiful with a flat area for dancing, a long shallow reflective
>pool and an open dome or circular arch suppoorted by columns in the
>middle of which is a hole from which you can look down at thousands of
>gallons of swirling water. It was nice to play the mythical mind game
>of what a couple of kilos of sid could do... but then we have
>something better, the Vibe.
>
>All of the parking along canada road is illegal (no parking signs
>everywhere) by when I arrived at 0300 most cars were neatly parked
>along the road, maybe about 150 - 200 cars, this was a relief to me as
>I usualy park cars for these things and it was good to see that the
>community can take up the slack if I'm not there.
>
>Even though the site was secured and people had been arriving en-mass,
>by 0345 the sound system, though set up had not started yet, (The FMR
>seems to be plagued with sound system problems, it would be nice if
>they checked the stuff out before hand or arrived earlier, cuz it
>always takes them 45 - 1 hour to get the sound working) but by 0400
>Garth was spinning the groove right along. The weather was just the
>right temperature, and even though the moon became obscured by clouds,
>we could still feel her presence. Garth started to kick some really
>funky tunes, and I could see that this could turn out to be another
>incredible/evolutionary FMR when... the Police showed up.
>
>It was just a lone car at first, I saw him at the top of the hill
>shining his flashlight and whatever, I decides not to go up right
>away, let him take it all in for a bit (besides, I really didn't want
>to do it) but eventualy no one else was around who was gonna do it so
>I decided to make initial contact. I gave my sacrements to a friend
>for safe keeping and walked up the hill...
>
>"Hi ya doin officer!"
>"What's goin on down there" he says.
>I say, "Well I think it's one of those rave party things, or something"
>"Is this your party?"
>Who me! NO, I'm just coming up to see whats happening"
>He say "Well I sugguest that you leave right away cuz I just called my
>sargent and all of these people are going to jail"
>I think to myself yeah buddy, you and what army, but I say "Well my
>girlfriend is still down there, let me go get her OK?" This works
>every time :)
>"OK but I'd get her and leave right away if I were you."
>
>So back down the hill I go, this is a usual first contact, next we let
>him sit for a while, see how many more show up. About 20 minutes later
>a LOT of crusiers show, CHP, redwood city, sheriff, SanMateo, maybe 13
>- 20 cars. They start giving orders to disperse but the music is too
>loud, Garth is throwing down some vicious trax, no-one would be going
>anyplace anyway, even if they could hear the order. Next thing I know,
>they're putting on riot gear! Shit, well is this the time to make the
>headlines? OR what? I am a vetran of the 60's and 70's demostrations,
>I knew that Pulgas was an enclosed area with the only method of escape
>blocked by the cops. The whole area is fenced in. If they could keep
>us from leaving out the front, we could all be scooped up and arrested
>en masse (maybe not a bad idea) but some ravers would most likely
>climb the fence and try to escape into the wilderness behind them.
>There is an acquaduct and other stuff back there. Maybe defusing is in
>order. I go back up the hill and ask to speak to the person in
>command. They want to know If I'm in control of the crowd, if not,
>then I don't need to speak to anybody. I tell them that no-one is in
>control, (a fact they find hard to fathom) but that I'm concerned, I
>don't want any violence, to ensue and that I can carry a message to
>the group.
>
>Someone said that we want you guys to leave, we won't hassle anybody
>if you just leave, I tell them that the riot gear is intimidating and
>unnecessary, we are a peaceful bunch but the riot stuff is scareing
>people and when they are scared, they would rather stay together as a
>Family I they were going to be clubed. Just at that moment so police
>officer turned on a high powered spot light that illuminated the area,
>some ravers got up in front of it and did some great "shadow dancing"
>the shadows were projected against the trees on the far side of the
>temple making dancing figures 20 or 30 ft high. Truely on of the best
>visuals I've ever seen at a rave! Even the cops got a kick out of it
>(those that could admit it) this seemed to chill them out a bit, a
>couple laughed. My hats go off to the dancers whoever they are, who
>made a truely transformational move in a scarey situation, it took
>courage! I go back down the hill and back into the crowd, people are
>talking about "sitting down" and stuff, well we'll see. Eventualy the
>cops send three or for officers in riot gear down to the DJ area and
>stop Garth from playing. Everybody claps and cheers for Garth but
>holds there ground. They didn't threaten the Police in any way, but
>they did send the message that we were a family. After the music
>stopped some people discussed what to do. I went back up the Hill to
>"negotiate" with the police. They agreed to not arrest anyone or
>confiscate any equipment so long as we leave now. I told them I
>thought that would fly but that It would take time to break down the
>sound system, when the sound system gets taken apart, people will
>slowly leave. Just as some consensus seemed to be reached. A female
>officer gets on one of their bull horns and starts in on people about
>how they have been nice so far but our patience is wearing thin, etc.
>I walked over to her...
>
>"Excuse me, mam, um, mam, that's not helping". I start to have a talk
>with her, (sending her the Vibe in a big way) I told her that these
>kids were peaceful, there is no need for beligerence, the riot gear
>and helmuts are scaring people. she totally GETS IT! She takes of her
>helmut to reveal all of this thick, beautiful, long, blond flowing
>hair! We walk down the hill together and I tell her about the scene
>and why we have the full moon parties, she notices and comments on how
>there are people from every race present and every one seems calm and
>happy, they aren't sending her any bad vibes. I tell her that is what
>it's all about. This isn't about gangs, it's about Love, I watched her
>lighten up before my eyes. She told me her name was Ali and I told her
>mine, we walked along and I told her that we tried to choose places
>that were remote so that the not just the cops but other negative
>elements would have difficulty finding us. I told her that there is no
>hard drug use, maybe a little pot but nothing like crack or heroin (I
>didn't mention the e word), I told her that our scene is about Unity
>and we welcome everyone. I invited her to come to one when she's off
>duty, provided she won't arrest anyone :). By this ravers are going
>around picking up trash (this blew her away) and cops and ravers are
>at least being plesant to each other. I thought to myself, wow I
>really charmed this big blond police officer, she's about my age,
>maybe ... nayh , it would NEVER work :) So I said goodbye to Officer
>Ali and told her that I hope if we meet in the future, it will always
>be on plesant terms, she thanked me for walking with her and chatting.
>We left it at that.
>
>The FMR was moved to candlestick, I didn't follow.
>
>I consider what happened there to be a success, a confrontation was
>avoided (it was not the place to engague this issue, someday maybe)
>and I know at least some police were educated about raves and ravers,
>(I am sure officer Ali has a different viewpoint). The important thing
>is a change in consciousnes occured both for the ravers and for the
>police. Ultimately when all of the rhetoric is said and done, it
>personal and individual action that makes the biggest difference. I
>saw Ali talking to some ravers she seemed to have pulled over (two
>young girls) I just hope that my talk had some influence in what ever
>business she had to conduct with them.
>
>NEXUS SYSTEMS/CYBERTRIBE-5 : Voice:(415)965-2384 Fax: (415)327-6416
>Editor/Instigator/Catalyst : Geoff White Production Crew : Universal
>Movement Trinity
>"They might stop the party, but they can't stop the future"
>
>
>
>Apollo
>apollo@speakeasy.org
>
>MySpace:  http://www.myspace.com/DJApollo
>
>Tribenet:   http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k
>
>Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
>
>House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
>
>"There is suffering in life, and there are defeats. No one can avoid
>them. But it's better to lose some of the battles in the struggles for
>your dreams than to be defeated without ever knowing what you're
>fighting for."  -Paulo Coelho
>
>"Suffering and joy teach us, if we allow them, how to make the leap of
>empathy, which transports us into the soul and heart of another
>person. ln those transparent moments we know other people's joys and
>sorrows, and we care about their concerns as if they were our 
>own."  - Fritz Williams
>
>"I hate to advocate drugs, alcohol, violence or insanity to anyone,
>but it worked for me." -Hunter S. Thompson
>

Subject: [sfraves] WR: Blissed the fuck out! LIterally

OK.. sorry for the lag, but it's been kinda ummm... a werid like week to
fully write a a full like weekend review... so here I go :)

LIke before the shindig @ Bliss Bliss.. I had an accupunture treatment &
it was Dope!  So Dope!!!  I mean.. it was like a general just overall, no
specific problem area accupuncture... ummmm... well.. it was just to like
done to strngthen my chi (i think).. oh yeah, & to regualte my
digestion... but Wow... lol.. it was Awesome, like i mean.. i hate 10
needles stuck in me, mainly around my tummy area & belly button, & 2
needle pokes on each of my knees... then Dr Max like used this mini sage
stick, but it wasn't sage, to burn the needles & to also get some of that
sage smoke stuff insode my body or something, but yummmmm, that was sooo
Groovy feeling like seriously, HELLO 2DAY!!!

Then me and Dr Max went to Bliss Headquaters for some Mixed Blissed Uppity
yummy yum action, & all the while, i was pretty Naturally Blissed out
myself from the needle job.  LIke al night i was kinda in this constant
state that i was like floating.

So the music was Dope... we didn't get there 'til 11:45ish i think... &
this guy was playing like this kinda disco techyish tribally kinda house
from what i remember... I mean... there was aloooooota Electro from
alooota DJs, alota Techno too, there were alota DJ i saw, Loved, ooh shit,
Forest Green totally threw it down, but it kinda felt like she held back a
lil compared to other sets I've Groove to of hers lately, which was fine
for the occasion... & I still Loved it!!!  The DJ b4 her w/ the accent,
that's when i started dancing... then there was that 1 DJ who was part of
the DJ Bone party last year who dropped this Dope Techno set too (some
Electro too)...

OK... & I'm not just sayin' this 'cause he's my Big Bro, but fuckin' Andy
man... he really fucked me Blissed Over Hello 2Day WOW.. i mean... he
started out HAAAARD & 'cause me & Dr Max had to like leave in the middle
of this set, it was still hard!!!  I was lovin' this live hard set he
fuckin' pulled off man... So Loved it!!

OK.. there wasn't much decoration other than all the constant yummy Bliss
around there already... but OK.. so they were showing JEM & The Holograms
cartoons all night (Disc 3) & even though i couldn't hear what they were
sayin'... i mean.. i knew most these cartoons by heart kinda & Chel-C
invited me to go there on a non hyphy Bliss night to have a JEM
marathon!!!  YAAAY!!!

OK.. crowd was all Yummy!!  Alota Familia there.. so it was Dope seein'
y'all & then some!!!  YAAAY!!!  Oh yeah.. so like i mean.. it was a really
mixed crowd, this group po Spanish Dudes were here from Spain & it was fun
getting to knew them!!  But yeah... there was like people from UK, German
dudes, I mean... it was just BadAss meeting all those diffent people who i
never met.. it was a rainbow of new people to meet.. then there wsas one
person who was like "yeah man, remember me from back inthe day, i always
wore that visor"... LOLOLOLMAO

Oh yeah.. theere were these 2 people that brought Cheese Tamales that
costed $2 & ooh fuck man.. they were yummy!!!!  I actually had 2 then a
3rd .. ooh so good.. o h yeah.. Chel-C Bliss Cookies were oh so yUmmy!!
OK.. but here's the kicker of the night, Simon, the Chinese guy some of
you might know who goes out & buys everyone food after a party, well... he
left & came back with so much Chinese food!!  So that was SO DOPE!!! 
Hello 2Day.. 'cause i didn't get to like eat too much before my
accupuncture or after, so YUm.. Mondo Hello 2day YUM!!!

So yeah.. me & Dr Max left around 4:30ish like in the middle of Andy's
Yummy Live Set... but yeah... too Jem & too much ear candy all while
Blissful & Floaty.. Thank U Bliss People for the Bliss Fuck I needed so
bad!!!

-- 
Take Care <3
Peace=->Jus' Me =-> ObY {8O)

Subject: [sfraves] Sonic Mandalas - A New Black Note Music CD

------=_NextPart_000_01C4_01C8A00E.9AFCE370
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Kyron - Sonic Mandalas=20

An electronic aural transmutation of ancient principles=20

Mandalas have been employed by a variety of spiritual traditions to =
awaken the kernel of sanctity that lies dormant within all of the =
manifested universe. These Sonic Mandalas continue that tradition and =
may be used to focus attention and exercise pure consciousness in a =
trance state. They are also beautiful and enjoyable as pure musical =
experiences.=20
16 tracks ring in at just under one hour. Each track expresses a unique =
realm moving from expansive bright moods to dark ambient spaces and =
everything in between. Ambient electronic sounds meet with blip and body =
moving beats to create an album that spans from the heavens to the earth =
and back. This music can be used for meditation, deep listening, =
conscious movement, or sacred dance. It's the perfect CD to make any =
space more alive and conducive to the flow of raw creative energies.=20

You can get it from Itunes here:
http://phobos.apple.com/WebObjects/MZStore.woa/wa/viewAlbum?playListId=3D=
276026945

Or from CDBaby here:
http://cdbaby.com/cd/kyron7

Or directly from the Black Note Music site here:
http://www.deconstructionist.com/blacknote/mandalas.htm

Any comments, questions or suggestions are sincerely appreciated.

JC Mendizabal
Black Note Music
http://www.blacknotemusic.com
Via Sinistrae
www.viasinistrae.com
http://sinistrae.libsyn.com/
Other Sites
http://www.allhaildiscordia.com/
http://maddogmagick.blogspot.com/
http://secretsareeverywhere.blogspot.com/

Subject: [sfraves] BSP - Tomorrow night on Radio Integrated :: Early Edition live from Killswitch 6pm-10pm :: Chel-C Faith and Disconnect

------=_Part_25554_13565484.1208456711832
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

Tomorrow night, we'll be hosting a super special *early* edition of Radio
Integrated, broadcasting live from San Francisco's favorite Friday happy
hour techno meetup, Killswitch.  This week will be featuring sets from
Disconnect and Chel-C Faith, as well as Killswitch residents.  This party
has been becoming quite the happening... if you can't come down to the Lower
Haight and have a beer with us, tune in and hear what it's all about!

Tune in from 6pm-10pm at http://radio.defsf.com:1200/

More info below from the Killswitch crew.


Love from Chelsea for Radio Integrated

///Radio Integrated :: radiointegrated@gmail.com ::
http://radio.defsf.com:1200/  :: www.myspace.com/radiointegrated


# # # # # # # # # # # # # # # # # # # # # # # # # # # # # # # # # # # # # #
# # # # # # # #

This week at Killswitch: DJ Disconnect and Chel-C Faith (Live PA) of DEF SF

DEF is a collective of independent techno DJs, producers, and promoters
dedicated to advancing techno on the West Coast, by way of selflessness and
partnership in the underground electronic dance music community.


Currently led by DJ Disconnect and Chel-C Faith, DEF has hosted a number of
underground techno events over the years in addition to their own Radio
Integrated weekly radio show, and aims to promote and support the techno
community in the Bay Area.



DJ Disconnect describes his DJ style as "dreamy, groovin" and "laid back"
with a dash of progressive and neo-Detroit thrown in. Chel-C Faith, who will
be performing her own melodic, groovy, Detroit-influenced techno tracks
using all hardware, cites some of her techno influences as Speedy J, Kenny
Larkin, Marco Carola, and Funk D'Void. With two such strong proponents of
underground techno in the Bay Area, Killswitch is thrilled to feature yet
another strong contributor to the Bay Area's diverse techno scene.



Don't forget to get there early as we've got $4 Stellas + Slice of Pizza
from Volare Pizza from 6-7pm!
Killswitch @ Underground SF
424 Haight @ Webster
San Francisco
Fridays, 6-10pm

------=_Part_25554_13565484.1208456711832--

From: Ray Wong <rayw@rayw.net>
To: def-announce@defsf.com, sfraves@hyperreal.org
Cc: Ray Wong <rayw@rayw.net>

MIME-Version: 1.0

User-Agent: Mutt/1.5.13 (2006-08-11)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] [BSP][FAKTION] One more week! AMBER and DRAGN'FLY! @Anu! hide the subwoofers!



Spring has definitely arrived, and 2008 continues to be a reinvigorated
year for techno.  For April we have another, different treat for you, as we
reunite some of the West Coast's best in the latest installment of danceable,
affordable Techno.  Underground DJ sensations AMBER and DRAGN'FLY come
above to show you where things are at.  So maybe it's a little different
techno than you've come to expect at Anu, it's still great, danceable
EDM, and can anyone remember the last time this dynamic duo teamed up at a
party?

Friday, 25 April, 2008

RAY presents: 

F A K T I O N : because san francisco needs another techno cult
with special guests and extended sets:

Friday, 25 April 2008:
DRAGN'FLY: DJ4NORML/DJDRAGNFLY.COM [ SAC/SF ]
DJ AMBER: Sister SF/iamthedj.com [ SF ]

Last Fridays @ Anu

DJ AMBER is a San Francisco-based dj/producer with a driving beat and
aggressively risky mixing technique in a town better known for its
laid back house style.  For over ten years she has brought her vigorous
style and enthusiastic stage presence to events throughout North America
and Europe.  She's appeared in some other venues you might have heard
of (1015, Ruby Skye, Supperclub), now she brings her sick loops, breaks
and smooth mixes to the FAKTION.

DRAGN'FLY: For the techno-afficionado, Dragnfly provides a sublime musical
experience formed from an intricate mesh of dark, sexy tech-influenced
beats, driving baselines and relentless mixing skills. Having bridged
the millennium with some of the most revered Bay Area underground crews,
demand for this iconic DJ has spread like wildfire over the past decade
and today she remains in the forefront of the electronic dance movement,
having already made over 1,000 domestic appearances throughout the
United States, including Hawaii, and internationally in various regions
throughout Mexico, Germany and Brazil."

Anu-Bar 
43 Sixth St., San Francisco, CA
10 PM to 2 AM 21+
Cost: $5, free b4 11pm, LADIES FREE B4 MIDNIGHT!!!

Official Site: http://www.faktionsf.com/

 
///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
 
Coming up: Faktion: Last Fridays @ Anu 
Friday, 30 May 2008:
DRUMCELL: Droid Behavior/Omniscient [ LA ]
DEVELOPER: Modularz/Sound Division [ LA ]
FOREST GREEN: ForestGreen.org/Daly City Records/Faktion [ SF ]

---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Sat April 19th

Full Moon -
Santa Cruz


Starting at 9pm
there will be a tai chi lesson (free ) of course

10pm we shift into muzac beats from yard, the pound, the asylum and  
the asylum seeker, what does all this mean, no one can be sure
the only thing that is for sure is we are about to get down wiff our  
bad-selves and the bad-elves, and the good ones, the wild ones
(wild ones please show the domestic ones how its done) under the light  
and graces of the full moon

All Star Full Moon line up includes djs playing outside on the lawn
Brother
Alia
Little John
Rastatronix
Clay
Timonkey
Cloraphil

the lovely people of
3960 Empire Grade have invited us to
stir the primordial cauldron of the dancing spirit totem
please give them the respect and appreciation due


Apollo
apollo@speakeasy.org

MySpace:  http://www.myspace.com/DJApollo

"There is suffering in life, and there are defeats. No one can avoid  
them. But it's better to lose some of the battles in the struggles for  
your dreams than to be defeated without ever knowing what you're  
fighting for."  -Paulo Coelho

"Suffering and joy teach us, if we allow them, how to make the leap of  
empathy, which transports us into the soul and heart of another  
person. ln those transparent moments we know other people's joys and  
sorrows, and we care about their concerns as if they were our own."  - 
Fritz Williams

"I hate to advocate drugs, alcohol, violence or insanity to anyone,  
but it worked for me." -Hunter S. Thompson

Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr: wake up sfr!!..family is in town..where do i take them


Most of the touristy spots are in SF as mentioned, but it all depends on
what your fam's like...

Could take em on a boat ride out to Angel Island if they like photographing
nature and stuff...  For that matter there's the inevitable Alcatraz tour,
but it's probably expensive.  If there's little kids and they're looking
for an amusement park you've got great america down in the san jo, with
some other parks another hour past, leave them there and run yourself down
to santa cruz. ;)

The nature is certainly the best thing here, but if they want to see SF
like so many tourists, I'd probably start em off by the baseball park,
just drive through and point out all the old waterfront warehouses that
are still down there -- there's a nice brunch spot at 2 townsend if they
have money, don't forget that visiting relatives are a great source for
us having fine dining experiences :D -- move up around the ferry building
and then union square for shopping, castro, haight, mission districts for
some of SF's "culture" -- either pick some spots at random, or grab one
of those hotel "places to see" guides for some stopping points) -- run
out to the sunset if they haven't seen the ocean before, check out the
old sutro bathhouse ruins -- depending on timing a lot of tourists like
the ocean view from dining upstairs at the beach chalet btw -- maybe cruise
around the park, de young museum, asian art museum, the gardens, etc,
then loop over the top of the city so they can gawk at the golden gate
bridge -- ideally time this for sunset, it looks cool then -- stop at the
palace of fine arts and coit tower and stuff on the way down, and finish
a day with dinner in north beach for SF signature not-quite-italian-food.

Note that this list would normally take way more than a day to finish. :)

Subject: [sfraves] Re: [DEF] Re: [sfraves] [BSP][FAKTION] One more week! AMBER and DRAGN'FLY! @Anu! hide the subwoofers!


:)

Yep, got the next 3 months up at least, still working on the summer months
but those dates are at least predictable too.  I think I do happen to be
the only monthly not using a number for the day (last friday instead of 4th,
which means there's a couple times a year I'm on 5th friday) but you guys
are all smart enough for that one. :)

And I'm tellin ya guys, this year's collisions really feel like something
GOOD starting.  That there's actually CHOICES in cool music is critical in
a vibrant nightlife scene, and sure as hell beats a couple years ago when
we were all calling each other up and asking "hey is there a party this
weekend?" "A party" as in one... maybe... the sure sign of a dead music
scene.

We've been starting to get some folks out who mention it being their
first techno party, which seems shocking, but then I remember that I
know probably 80% of the folks at most parties as being DJs and
promoters at other parties.  While I love the "seeing my friends"
aspect of this, we've got a hell of a lot more talented DJs, producers
and what have you in this town than to just keep rotating whom among
us is on that night.  This means we must have multiple parties happening
at the same time, and people need to know about it.  A lot of folks don't
go out because they figure they'll never find that one underground, or
even which club has music they like, but if we get back to being famous
for lots of great parties all over, they'll come again.  It started last
year but it really does feel like it's hitting stride this year.

And I'll even confess that I have snuck out of one of my own parties to
go say hi to... well, she's a DJ everyone should know, and at least one
of you two knows her very well -- at a gig very close by. :)

Vista point on the Marin side of the GG Bridge
Coit Tower (near Chinatown)
Japanese Tea Garden or Botanical Gardens in GG Park
DeYoung Museum in GG Park (near Bunny Meadow)
Exploratorium (for the kids)

in your neck of the woods, the Lawrence Berkeley lab area in the hills behi=
nd the college is GORGEOUS
the Albany Bulb is really interesting but requires some meandering around u=
nstable footing/ground - still cool though.

HAVE FUN!!!
