> Yep, got the next 3 months up at least, still working on the summer month=
s
> but those dates are at least predictable too.  I think I do happen to be
> the only monthly not using a number for the day (last friday instead of 4=
th,
> which means there's a couple times a year I'm on 5th friday) but you guys
> are all smart enough for that one. :)
>=20
> And I'm tellin ya guys, this year's collisions really feel like something
> GOOD starting.  That there's actually CHOICES in cool music is critical i=
n
> a vibrant nightlife scene, and sure as hell beats a couple years ago when
> we were all calling each other up and asking "hey is there a party this
> weekend?" "A party" as in one... maybe... the sure sign of a dead music
> scene.
>=20
> We've been starting to get some folks out who mention it being their
> first techno party, which seems shocking, but then I remember that I
> know probably 80% of the folks at most parties as being DJs and
> promoters at other parties.  While I love the "seeing my friends"
> aspect of this, we've got a hell of a lot more talented DJs, producers
> and what have you in this town than to just keep rotating whom among
> us is on that night.  This means we must have multiple parties happening
> at the same time, and people need to know about it.  A lot of folks don't
> go out because they figure they'll never find that one underground, or
> even which club has music they like, but if we get back to being famous
> for lots of great parties all over, they'll come again.  It started last
> year but it really does feel like it's hitting stride this year.
>=20
> And I'll even confess that I have snuck out of one of my own parties to
> go say hi to... well, she's a DJ everyone should know, and at least one
> of you two knows her very well -- at a gig very close by. :)
>=20
>=20
>=20
>=20
>=20
>=20
>=20

>>> EDM, and can anyone remember the last time this dynamic duo teamed up a=
t a

>>>
>>> Last Fridays @ Anu
>>>
>>> DJ AMBER is a San Francisco-based dj/producer with a driving beat and
>>> aggressively risky mixing technique in a town better known for its
>>> laid back house style.  For over ten years she has brought her vigorous
>>> style and enthusiastic stage presence to events throughout North Americ=
a
>>> and Europe.  She's appeared in some other venues you might have heard
>>> of (1015, Ruby Skye, Supperclub), now she brings her sick loops, breaks
>>> and smooth mixes to the FAKTION.
>>>
>>> DRAGN'FLY: For the techno-afficionado, Dragn=E2=80=99fly provides a sub=
lime=20
>>> musical
>>> experience formed from an intricate mesh of dark, sexy tech-influenced
>>> beats, driving baselines and relentless mixing skills. Having bridged
>>> the millennium with some of the most revered Bay Area underground crews=
,
>>> demand for this iconic DJ has spread like wildfire over the past decade
>>> and today she remains in the forefront of the electronic dance movement=
,
>>> having already made over 1,000 domestic appearances throughout the
>>> United States, including Hawaii, and internationally in various regions
>>> throughout Mexico, Germany and Brazil."

Subject: Re: [sfraves] AT smoke out?

--0-525668053-1208744792=:73658
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

My buddy Bryce & I went. The walk there included passing by a waterfall (always a good sign), and  our path was well-lit by the moon. We initially got lost (thanks "Doug's Party") but arrived around 2:00, with plenty of time for festivities. 

Two people walked up to us to us at different times and apologized because they were tripping. One had lost their glasses and was extra apologetic. In both cases we assured them it was quite alright and sent them on their way. 

I'm glad I wore the trees hoodie. It reached 33 at one point but the fire kept us warm. The visuals on the trees were a nice touch, and the turnout was great. There was a long tree where a bunch of kids were sitting down while others gave them light shows, but they weren't sitting in the middle of the dance area, so fine by us!

Someone dropped 'Hey Boy/Hey Girl' around 4:15 and we prepped for the official sesh. Left around 4:23.

Long drive home (and I live in the South Bay) cause I had to drop my buddy off in Scotts Valley and wound up taking a 2-hour nap at a closed gas station with the nozzle still mounted in my tank.

Woke up to the attendant sending me on my merry way before he called for some "help." Got home around 8 and woke up just in time for the second 4:20. 

Overall Vibe Factor: 9.5 out of 10. Not an unfriendly face to be found, and we can't wait for the next one.

peace

chuck

Subject: [sfraves] bsp 4 programmer/dj/producer types

Relevant to MP3/music biz models discussion last week:

"In an MP3 world, recordings are cheap. Therefore, the whole
fundamental business model of selling recordings is completely doomed.
A business model based on expensive recordings sells recordings; a
business model based on cheap and abundant recordings gives recordings
away. This makes the body of recordings of your live musical
performances equivalent to a blog - you should be updating it all the
time. Recording your live performances should be as cheap as capturing
a log file, since distributing those recordings is as cheap as
publishing an RSS feed."

http://gilesbowkett.blogspot.com/2008/04/archaeopteryx-logging-and-soon-unit.html

-- 

Giles Soundwave/Goat Boy/Bowkett
http://www.gilesgoatboy.org/
http://gilesbowkett.blogspot.com (code)

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: worm composting workshop this Saturday

My latest project in the quest to save humankind from ourselves is a  
series of free composting workshops that I will be teaching at Spiral  
Gardens in South Berkeley.

The first will be a vermicomposting workshop this Saturday, April 26th  
from noon to 2 pm. Vermicomposting is the use of red worms to turn  
food scraps into plant fertilizer - great if you don't have much space  
or enough yard waste to make a regular compost pile.

In the workshop you will learn:

-How to set up and maintain a worm bin
-How to use the finished castings
-How to spot problems with the bin, and how to fix them
-How to order a discounted worm bin and how to make your own from  
cheap or free materials

If you'd like to come check it out, come by Spiral Gardens this  
Saturday at Noon. We'll have snacks and drinks, and will be giving  
away a worm bin ($100 retail value) as a door prize.

In addition to being a community garden, Spiral Gardens is also a  
plant nursery. All profits from the sale of plants go towards  
supporting the non-profit mission of the project, so plan on doing  
some spring plant shopping while you're there for the workshop!

Spiral Gardens is at 2850 Sacramento Street in Berkeley, 2 blocks  
north of Ashby.

http://www.spiralgardens.org/

Subject: Re: [sfraves] bsp 4 programmer/dj/producer types



An interesting perspective, and one that's actually quite flawed in a
very basic assumption -- counter-intuitively, on the blog side of the
analogy.  Bandwidth isn't free, isn't even close to it.  There's a myth
of free bandwidth propagated by the eargerness to sell that last mile of
net, the "home DSL" market, however as anyone hosting servers is slowly
and painfully learning, it isn't real.  The internet is cheap on that
end because you don't actually get the bandwidth you think you're
paying very little for.  If you've ever noticed how slow it is to
UPLOAD data, you get a sense of the real bandwidth you can get that
cheaply.

On the server side, these costs are quite exposed.  You get sites with
painfully slow performance, or ones with what seems excessive advertising,
or annoying subscriptions, or any number of other means to reclaim this
cost.  And the costs are rising.  leaving a single server running costs
some $40+/month just in power, by the time you have a farm of them
capable of delivering anything close to a useful choice of things to
download, you're paying again for the cooling costs (about doubling the
power cost), and real bandwidth costs, which drive things up by another
factor.

Sure, you can drive into sharing models, and you can rely on the
"free" sites (like youtube for video), none of these barriers are
insurmountable, they're just far from free.  RSS is "nearly free" mostly
because it's "nearly nothing" in terms of actual data.  A single MP3 of
any length/quality is more data than many RSS servers total content.  It's
the effort of sailing a paper airplane versus throwing an entire book
our your window.

Sure, as technology improves, it makes more bandwidth available, making
the whole thing cheaper, it just also exposes other areas that have
never been thought of as costs.  Distribution happens to be where the
world has spent most of its recent efforts in reducing costs.

Now, for a genre with a more limited appeal, and in a free world with
many artists, it's possible for much of this cost to be buried in the
individuals paying for bundled services.  I can throw a couple MP3s
of my artists out there for download, not because it's free, but because
the cost of just hosting a site where I can announce the parties and
whatnot masks how much I actually had to spend.  In economic terms,
as long as the real cost of sharing something is less than the step
variable increase in obvious costs, nobody notices (translation back:
I had to pay a fixed fee for webhosting so as long as the MP3 fits
in my space allocation and isn't popular enough to hit the bandwidth
limit, I don't pay extra.  That isn't free though, just means I had
to overbuy for the webhosting) what it cost.

So, my own belabored point?  Yes, recording is cheap.  I can record
hours of DJ sets every party.  I just can't give them away for free,
because distribution (giving away) is what costs me.  Just look at
how many people have recently offered to share their libraries IF
anyone was willing to offer a space to put them.

Ray

Subject: Re: [sfraves] bsp 4 programmer/dj/producer types



And as I said, yes, you can get into the sharing models, but that's still
far from free.  That I'm no longer paying for a dedicated high-volume media
server doesn't remove the cost, it merely hides it.  I'm paying to keep a
dedicated tracker somewhere, and I have to provide a seed server to keep
the torrent going.  Other people are paying not only for their internet
connection, but for keeping a computer turned on to help in the endeavor.

It's not that it's free, it's that there's a lot of wasted money out there
to use.  Very different case.  Maybe you don't care if the songs can't be
downloaded at long, random periods when no one with a copy is online to
help share, etc.

----- Original Message ----
From: Philip.X.Diaz <st_indigo@earthlink.net>
To: sf raves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Monday, April 21, 2008 11:28:19 AM
Subject: [sfraves] NRR: worm composting workshop this Saturday

My latest project in the quest to save humankind from ourselves is a  
series of free composting workshops that I will be teaching at Spiral  
Gardens in South Berkeley.

The first will be a vermicomposting workshop this Saturday, April 26th  
from noon to 2 pm. Vermicomposting is the use of red worms to turn  
food scraps into plant fertilizer - great if you don't have much space  
or enough yard waste to make a regular compost pile.

In the workshop you will learn:

-How to set up and maintain a worm bin
-How to use the finished castings
-How to spot problems with the bin, and how to fix them
-How to order a discounted worm bin and how to make your own from  
cheap or free materials

If you'd like to come check it out, come by Spiral Gardens this  
Saturday at Noon. We'll have snacks and drinks, and will be giving  
away a worm bin ($100 retail value) as a door prize.

In addition to being a community garden, Spiral Gardens is also a  
plant nursery. All profits from the sale of plants go towards  
supporting the non-profit mission of the project, so plan on doing  
some spring plant shopping while you're there for the workshop!

Spiral Gardens is at 2850 Sacramento Street in Berkeley, 2 blocks  
north of Ashby.

http://www.spiralgardens.org/

---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] bsp 4 programmer/dj/producer types

On 21 April 2008, Ray Wong wrote:

>
>
> And as I said, yes, you can get into the sharing models, but that's still
> far from free.  That I'm no longer paying for a dedicated high-volume media
> server doesn't remove the cost, it merely hides it.  I'm paying to keep a
> dedicated tracker somewhere, and I have to provide a seed server to keep
> the torrent going.  Other people are paying not only for their internet
> connection, but for keeping a computer turned on to help in the endeavor.
>
> It's not that it's free, it's that there's a lot of wasted money out there
> to use.  Very different case.  Maybe you don't care if the songs can't be
> downloaded at long, random periods when no one with a copy is online to
> help share, etc.

Why not have your web server box seeding the file? :)

I suppose my main reason for commenting was in regards to whoever posted 
the idea of the future business model for music more reasonably being 
one of the subscription model (or similar) than what seems to be an 
outdated one.  (Was it Peter or Philip who emailed about that idea???) 
This seems to me to be the most viable model for the future.  We are 
already seeing many muscial acts relying on income from touring as the 
means of making it.

Maybe this is a bit of consumer backlash from having to pay records 
labels 3 times more for something that cost them 1/10th the amount of 
money to produce as in the past (vinyl vs. CD's are what I'm comparing 
here.)  Is that how you treat your customer base?

Looking at today, is Apple losing money having all those servers and 
paying for all that bandwidth to sell tracks one track at a time?? 
Doesn't seem like it. :)

And how about the DJ/Producer who:
1. Sells his tracks on iTunes/Beatport/Amazon/etc.
2. Blogs about his performances/gigs, including serving up his mixes for 
download, as well as talking about the other releases out there 
that are driving his soul at this time while also getting a cut of sales 
he links to for these tracks and his own on iTunes/Beatport/Amazon/etc.


-- 
San Francisco Bay Guardian's Readers Choice Award Winner: Best Radio DJ:
http://www.sfbg.com/promo/pollpositions.php
AIM: jckzsu (or kzsudj during my show.)

"Opinions are my own only, and do not necessarily represent those of
KZSU Radio or Stanford University." (or words to that effect.)

load all your datas onto the truck and drive it around on the cheap

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] bsp 4 programmer/dj/producer types

There's a fellow I know from the digital music business named Gerd Leonhard http://www.facebook.com/profile.php?id=502410383&ref=ts

His recent thesis is that "blogs" (whatever that means) are the new music labels.  While I like Gerd a lot, I think he's dead wrong here.  

The problem is that there are  not going to be "new" record labels.  The entire concept of a big record label as an organization that promotes music and produces and distributes the copies is simply dead.    As you've said, the ability to produce and distribute nearly free copies (bandwidth does cost something) eliminates most of that aspect of what the labels used to do.   But the changes underway are not just about the means of production of copies.

The ability to search algorithmically, i.e. google, largely eliminates the need to promote artists.  Instead the prospective audience will simply search for and find the artists they are interested in based on hot phrases or terms that will be passed via social networks.  Algorithmic search coupled with free copies destroys every attempt to monetize aggregated or even exclusively offered "gated" content.

What you've done here that's really interesting I think is to extend the logic of these trends happeing in the marketing/distribution side to the production and especially performance side of things.  The notion of a log file being performable (yes I actually went and read your blog) is fascinating in this conext although not really a new idea in the software world.    Music is a macro?

Now I do continue to have some heartburn with the notion that a live performance is like a blog because of the above arguments about blogs and record labels, but as long as one understands that the blog (aka a recorded live concert)  is not the thing that gets monetized since it is also searchable and is infinitely reproduceable almost for free, there's really no problem here. 

Also, sort of off topic but maybe not, you might enjoy this snipet from my old boss Kai Krause:

"I used to think 'Software Design' is an art form. 
I now believe that I was half-right:
it is indeed an art, but it has a rather short half-life: 
Software is merely a performance art! 
A momentary flash of brilliance, doomed to be overtaken by the next wave, or maybe even by its own sequel. Eaten alive by its successors. And time... "

>From http://www.edge.org/q2008/q08_16.html

Keep on jamming with this...you're on the trail of something very interesting here.  IMO.

Best,

Peter

----- Original Message ----
From: Giles Bowkett <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>
To: sf raves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Monday, April 21, 2008 10:53:26 AM
Subject: [sfraves] bsp 4 programmer/dj/producer types

Relevant to MP3/music biz models discussion last week:

"In an MP3 world, recordings are cheap. Therefore, the whole
fundamental business model of selling recordings is completely doomed.
A business model based on expensive recordings sells recordings; a
business model based on cheap and abundant recordings gives recordings
away. This makes the body of recordings of your live musical
performances equivalent to a blog - you should be updating it all the
time. Recording your live performances should be as cheap as capturing
a log file, since distributing those recordings is as cheap as
publishing an RSS feed."

http://gilesbowkett.blogspot.com/2008/04/archaeopteryx-logging-and-soon-unit.html

-- 

Giles Soundwave/Goat Boy/Bowkett
http://www.gilesgoatboy.org/
http://gilesbowkett.blogspot.com (code)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] bsp 4 programmer/dj/producer types

On the bandwidth argument, I'm curious about that. I think your
argument's incorrect but I'm not actually sure.

The reason I think it's incorrect is I sometimes get 10,000 hits to my
blog in a single day, if I post something controversial and/or it's a
slow day on the Internet in general, and on a month when that happens,
my image serving costs go up. But they really don't go up very far.
I've got all my image files on Amazon S3, and an expensive month is
like $2 or $3.

The reason I'm not sure is that I'm not serving mix MP3s via S3 to
equivalent traffic, and a mix MP3 is a much larger file than an image.
On the whole though I think you could probably get very cheap hosting
via S3 for large MP3s without significant problems.

Date: Mon, 21 Apr 2008 14:22:34 -0700 (PDT)
From: dangrsmind@yahoo.com
To: Giles Bowkett <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>, sf raves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Message-ID: <16416.93941.qm@web32401.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] bsp 4 programmer/dj/producer types

The problem with the subscription model is that it still assumes the scarcity of a resource which in fact is not scarce.  The only real difference is in how you charge for access to this supposedly scarce resource.  But music is no longer scarce so there is a problem right up front.  The existing subscription services have failed in part because of the fetish of collecting music, but also because in reality there is little difference between a subscription service and a download service if they both have th emusic you want.

Also, you still need to lock your content to prevent unauthorized access to the subscription service.  This should be a warning sign that something is not quite right with your business model.  Further, assuming there is some way for me to record the content I obtain through the subscription, there is little reason for me to continue a subscription once I record everything I want.  Unless you can make the content I record self destruct again creating artificial scarcity.  These futile attempts to limit access and create artificial scarcity are all going to fail however.

I think the real way forward for the music business is something much closer and nearer and dearer to all of hearts at least on this list.  the future is in direct personal contact, in creating experiences that can't be packaged or reproduced, and which therefore can only exist in the moment in which they happen.  In other words its about raves.

Peace,

Peter

dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote: The problem with the subscription model is that it still assumes the scarcity of a resource which in fact is not scarce.  The only real difference is in how you charge for access to this supposedly scarce resource.  But music is no longer scarce so there is a problem right up front.  The existing subscription services have failed in part because of the fetish of collecting music, but also because in reality there is little difference between a subscription service and a download service if they both have th emusic you want.

Also, you still need to lock your content to prevent unauthorized access to the subscription service.  This should be a warning sign that something is not quite right with your business model.  Further, assuming there is some way for me to record the content I obtain through the subscription, there is little reason for me to continue a subscription once I record everything I want.  Unless you can make the content I record self destruct again creating artificial scarcity.  These futile attempts to limit access and create artificial scarcity are all going to fail however.

I think the real way forward for the music business is something much closer and nearer and dearer to all of hearts at least on this list.  the future is in direct personal contact, in creating experiences that can't be packaged or reproduced, and which therefore can only exist in the moment in which they happen.  In other words its about raves.

Peace,

Peter

Subject: Re: [sfraves] bsp 4 programmer/dj/producer types


I agree with Ray that this is an interesting model
that carries a fundamental flaw -- though, I see the
flaw from the perspective of the artist/producer.

For starters, so-call "electronica" music is far from
free to produce.  Even by using the most thrifty
hardware-reducing methods, establishing a gear-base
that is capable of producing decent tracks easily
hovers around the $1k mark, and if you really want to
have a more refined sound that would have some
dancefloor viability, you're looking at a lot more. 
You don't need a high-end Mac Pro loaded with the
latest software to churn out tunes; you could pick up
an older synth on eBay (or your favorite garage sale)
for around $200 and probably find a hardware sequencer
in the $100 range, and then invest in a multi-track
recorder - but even at the farthest reductionist
setup, we're far from a free rig.

The next step would then be mastering of the
recording(s) to get the right kind of sound on the
floor.  If you're even done an A/B of unmastered (or
poorly mastered) tracks against something from, say,
The Exchange, then you can see the necessity of this
step.  It simply can't be skipped with this kind of
music.  Mastering houses, even the ones set up in
folks' garages and basements, don't work for free -
even if it's just a matter of looking at the cost of
the equipment, or even renting time in a pro studio. 
Add to that the cost of the engineer, and again you're
far from free, even in the most reductionist model.

The other thing that just irks me is this idea that
the art itself is valueless.  The time and effort
spent on its creation is so willingly and blindly
dismissed by the audience that it's disturbing.  No
one would argue that the Colonel should hand over a
leg-and-thigh meal for free just to appease his fans,
yet listeners are cavalier about demanding that
musicians and producers turn over their wares without
recompense, and then decry those who won't as enemies
of the "true art" who just refuse to "keep it real."

Now, does this all mean that Sony/BMG charging the
average consumer $19.95 for a 7-track CD is a fair and
accurate exchange?  No.  But you can't paint artists
or art with the same brush that you use on a
corporation.  The methods that the audience has
developed to try to punish and injure the corporate
music industry serve to destroy and kill the
independent music industry.





--- Ray Wong <rayw@rayw.net> wrote:

> 
> 
> An interesting perspective, and one that's actually
> quite flawed in a
> very basic assumption -- counter-intuitively, on the
> blog side of the
> analogy.  Bandwidth isn't free, isn't even close to
> it.  There's a myth
> of free bandwidth propagated by the eargerness to
> sell that last mile of
> net, the "home DSL" market, however as anyone
> hosting servers is slowly
> and painfully learning, it isn't real.  The internet
> is cheap on that
> end because you don't actually get the bandwidth you
> think you're
> paying very little for.  If you've ever noticed how
> slow it is to
> UPLOAD data, you get a sense of the real bandwidth
> you can get that
> cheaply.
> 
> On the server side, these costs are quite exposed. 
> You get sites with
> painfully slow performance, or ones with what seems
> excessive advertising,
> or annoying subscriptions, or any number of other
> means to reclaim this
> cost.  And the costs are rising.  leaving a single
> server running costs
> some $40+/month just in power, by the time you have
> a farm of them
> capable of delivering anything close to a useful
> choice of things to
> download, you're paying again for the cooling costs
> (about doubling the
> power cost), and real bandwidth costs, which drive
> things up by another
> factor.
> 
> Sure, you can drive into sharing models, and you can
> rely on the
> "free" sites (like youtube for video), none of these
> barriers are
> insurmountable, they're just far from free.  RSS is
> "nearly free" mostly
> because it's "nearly nothing" in terms of actual
> data.  A single MP3 of
> any length/quality is more data than many RSS
> servers total content.  It's
> the effort of sailing a paper airplane versus
> throwing an entire book
> our your window.
> 
> Sure, as technology improves, it makes more
> bandwidth available, making
> the whole thing cheaper, it just also exposes other
> areas that have
> never been thought of as costs.  Distribution
> happens to be where the
> world has spent most of its recent efforts in
> reducing costs.
> 
> Now, for a genre with a more limited appeal, and in
> a free world with
> many artists, it's possible for much of this cost to
> be buried in the
> individuals paying for bundled services.  I can
> throw a couple MP3s
> of my artists out there for download, not because
> it's free, but because
> the cost of just hosting a site where I can announce
> the parties and
> whatnot masks how much I actually had to spend.  In
> economic terms,
> as long as the real cost of sharing something is
> less than the step
> variable increase in obvious costs, nobody notices
> (translation back:
> I had to pay a fixed fee for webhosting so as long
> as the MP3 fits
> in my space allocation and isn't popular enough to
> hit the bandwidth
> limit, I don't pay extra.  That isn't free though,
> just means I had
> to overbuy for the webhosting) what it cost.
> 
> So, my own belabored point?  Yes, recording is
> cheap.  I can record
> hours of DJ sets every party.  I just can't give
> them away for free,
> because distribution (giving away) is what costs me.
>  Just look at
> how many people have recently offered to share their
> libraries IF
> anyone was willing to offer a space to put them.
> 
> Ray
> 
> 
> 
> On Mon, Apr 21, 2008 at 10:53:26AM -0700, Giles
> Bowkett wrote:
> > Relevant to MP3/music biz models discussion last
> week:
> > 
> > "In an MP3 world, recordings are cheap. Therefore,
> the whole
> > fundamental business model of selling recordings
> is completely doomed.
> > A business model based on expensive recordings
> sells recordings; a
> > business model based on cheap and abundant
> recordings gives recordings
> > away. This makes the body of recordings of your
> live musical
> > performances equivalent to a blog - you should be
> updating it all the
> > time. Recording your live performances should be
> as cheap as capturing
> > a log file, since distributing those recordings is
> as cheap as
> > publishing an RSS feed."
> > 
> >
>
http://gilesbowkett.blogspot.com/2008/04/archaeopteryx-logging-and-soon-unit.html
> > 
> > -- 
> > 
> > Giles Soundwave/Goat Boy/Bowkett
> > http://www.gilesgoatboy.org/
> > http://gilesbowkett.blogspot.com (code)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] bsp 4 programmer/dj/producer types

>  What you've done here that's really interesting I think is to extend the
> logic of these trends happeing in the marketing/distribution side to the
> production and especially performance side of things.  The notion of a
> log file being performable (yes I actually went and read your blog) is
> fascinating in this conext although not really a new idea in the software
> world.    Music is a macro?

Thanks. Interesting things happen when an old idea to some people is a
new idea to other people.

>  Now I do continue to have some heartburn with the notion that a live
> performance is like a blog because of the above arguments about blogs
> and record labels, but as long as one understands that the blog (aka a
> recorded live concert)  is not the thing that gets monetized since it is
> also searchable and is infinitely reproduceable almost for free, there's
> really no problem here.

Well yeah that's almost a founding assumption. The idea is that since
it's extremely easy for people to share your work to each other at
zero cost to them your recordings should function not as product but
as documentary. I got this idea from Improv Everywhere. I don't know
what people in technology imagined the entertainment industry might
respond to things like YouTube with, but one response is Improv
Everywhere, which does weird live improv and then posts it on YouTube.
The real entertainment is in the live performance, but seeing it on
YouTube *documents* that performance. In the old days recordings
*substituted for* performances.

>  Also, sort of off topic but maybe not, you might enjoy this snipet from my old boss Kai Krause:

Holy crap, man, Kai Krause. That man's work is one of the reasons I
decided to take acid.

>  "I used to think 'Software Design' is an art form.
>  I now believe that I was half-right:
>  it is indeed an art, but it has a rather short half-life:
>  Software is merely a performance art!
>  A momentary flash of brilliance, doomed to be overtaken by the next wave, or maybe even by its own sequel. Eaten alive by its successors. And time... "
>
>  From http://www.edge.org/q2008/q08_16.html
>
>  Keep on jamming with this...you're on the trail of something very interesting here.  IMO.

Gracias! I'm going to be speaking on this programmer as artist thing
in New York next weekend as part of a general talk on my music code.
I'm going to swipe that quote! Perfect timing for me there.

-- 

Giles Soundwave/Goat Boy/Bowkett

Subject: Re: [sfraves] bsp 4 programmer/dj/producer types

Bandwidth pricing varies widely as does the method by which you are charged.  Often one is charged for peak usage for example.  Under the peak pricing model off peak incremental bandwidth is essentially free.  For example, Live365 charges for guaranteed peak hour access to popular streams as a way of shifting listeners to offf peak hours.  

Also depending on what you are serving, the quality of service may matter.  Streaming live events for example has more stringent QoS requirements than servings static media files.  Also, you'll see service providers start changing the rules on you if you actually start moving a lot of data.  Read the fine print!

Best,

Peter

----- Original Message ----
From: Giles Bowkett <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>
To: sf raves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Monday, April 21, 2008 2:15:02 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] bsp 4 programmer/dj/producer types

On the bandwidth argument, I'm curious about that. I think your
argument's incorrect but I'm not actually sure.

The reason I think it's incorrect is I sometimes get 10,000 hits to my
blog in a single day, if I post something controversial and/or it's a
slow day on the Internet in general, and on a month when that happens,
my image serving costs go up. But they really don't go up very far.
I've got all my image files on Amazon S3, and an expensive month is
like $2 or $3.

The reason I'm not sure is that I'm not serving mix MP3s via S3 to
equivalent traffic, and a mix MP3 is a much larger file than an image.
On the whole though I think you could probably get very cheap hosting
via S3 for large MP3s without significant problems.

--

chuck



dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote: The problem with the subscription model is that it still assumes the scarcity of a resource which in fact is not scarce.  The only real difference is in how you charge for access to this supposedly scarce resource.  But music is no longer scarce so there is a problem right up front.  The existing subscription services have failed in part because of the fetish of collecting music, but also because in reality there is little difference between a subscription service and a download service if they both have th emusic you want.

Also, you still need to lock your content to prevent unauthorized access to the subscription service.  This should be a warning sign that something is not quite right with your business model.  Further, assuming there is some way for me to record the content I obtain through the subscription, there is little reason for me to continue a subscription once I record everything I want.  Unless you can make the content I record self destruct again creating artificial scarcity.  These futile attempts to limit access and create artificial scarcity are all going to fail however.

I think the real way forward for the music business is something much closer and nearer and dearer to all of hearts at least on this list.  the future is in direct personal contact, in creating experiences that can't be packaged or reproduced, and which therefore can only exist in the moment in which they happen.  In other words its about raves.

Peace,

Peter


----- Original Message ----
From: Giles Bowkett 
To: sf raves 
Sent: Monday, April 21, 2008 2:04:21 PM

> (Was it Peter or Philip who emailed about that idea???) This seems to me to
> be the most viable model for the future.  We are already seeing many muscial
> acts relying on income from touring as the means of making it.

>  For starters, so-call "electronica" music is far from
>  free to produce.

>  The other thing that just irks me is this idea that
>  the art itself is valueless.  The time and effort
>  spent on its creation is so willingly and blindly
>  dismissed by the audience that it's disturbing.  No
>  one would argue that the Colonel should hand over a
>  leg-and-thigh meal for free just to appease his fans,
>  yet listeners are cavalier about demanding that
>  musicians and producers turn over their wares without
>  recompense, and then decry those who won't as enemies
>  of the "true art" who just refuse to "keep it real."

I think this is an extremely important point which is extremely
under-represented in the general dialogue.

Unfortunately, my answer there would piss so many people off
simultaneously in so many different ways that I can't even hint at it
right now.

On 21 April 2008, Uncle Noah wrote:

> Now, does this all mean that Sony/BMG charging the
> average consumer $19.95 for a 7-track CD is a fair and
> accurate exchange?  No.  But you can't paint artists
> or art with the same brush that you use on a
> corporation.  The methods that the audience has
> developed to try to punish and injure the corporate
> music industry serve to destroy and kill the
> independent music industry.

Yeah, but didn't Radiohead come away with around $5 on average for their 
"pay what you want" downloaded album recently?  If true, do you suppose 
they were upset with their sales?  Do you suppose they covered their up 
front (amortized equipment), studio time, creation time, etc. costs?

> Date: Mon, 21 Apr 2008 14:26:38 -0700
> From: dj.soundwave@gmail.com
> To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
> Subject: Re: [sfraves] bsp 4 programmer/dj/producer types
>=20
>>  What you've done here that's really interesting I think is to extend th=
e
>> logic of these trends happeing in the marketing/distribution side to the
>> production and especially performance side of things.  The notion of a
>> log file being performable (yes I actually went and read your blog) is
>> fascinating in this conext although not really a new idea in the softwar=
e
>> world.    Music is a macro?
>=20
> Thanks. Interesting things happen when an old idea to some people is a
> new idea to other people.
>=20
>>  Now I do continue to have some heartburn with the notion that a live
>> performance is like a blog because of the above arguments about blogs
>> and record labels, but as long as one understands that the blog (aka a
>> recorded live concert)  is not the thing that gets monetized since it is
>> also searchable and is infinitely reproduceable almost for free, there's
>> really no problem here.
>=20
> Well yeah that's almost a founding assumption. The idea is that since
> it's extremely easy for people to share your work to each other at
> zero cost to them your recordings should function not as product but
> as documentary. I got this idea from Improv Everywhere. I don't know
> what people in technology imagined the entertainment industry might
> respond to things like YouTube with, but one response is Improv
> Everywhere, which does weird live improv and then posts it on YouTube.
> The real entertainment is in the live performance, but seeing it on
> YouTube *documents* that performance. In the old days recordings
> *substituted for* performances.
>=20
>>  Also, sort of off topic but maybe not, you might enjoy this snipet from=
 my old boss Kai Krause:
>=20
> Holy crap, man, Kai Krause. That man's work is one of the reasons I
> decided to take acid.
>=20
>>  "I used to think 'Software Design' is an art form.
>>  I now believe that I was half-right:
>>  it is indeed an art, but it has a rather short half-life:
>>  Software is merely a performance art!
>>  A momentary flash of brilliance, doomed to be overtaken by the next wav=
e, or maybe even by its own sequel. Eaten alive by its successors. And time=
... "
>>
>>  From http://www.edge.org/q2008/q08_16.html
>>
>>  Keep on jamming with this...you're on the trail of something very inter=
esting here.  IMO.
>=20
> Gracias! I'm going to be speaking on this programmer as artist thing
> in New York next weekend as part of a general talk on my music code.
> I'm going to swipe that quote! Perfect timing for me there.
>=20
> --=20
>=20
> Giles Soundwave/Goat Boy/Bowkett
> http://www.gilesgoatboy.org/
> http://gilesbowkett.blogspot.com (code)

  b=V7TI90IIZ6c583qPd7rkZsz5PkS+29kmsLO1E/WWlW2ziSb6JtZD8zqICmnCH+DBdvNeQ1MUf0+uuDHwll58sJX4B9TI6pgzxkwmVkpMg5atnQazQppeVhJvk6mpgolButpTbpSS/RflA26aXCOX3jO0tPLX9R1iGYw4Q4LnLYc=;
X-YMail-OSG: yEJJOsIVM1mEmIhUL41Ev3ZhslJXUr0afTOQdtGqq4LtsHaUjsN2kafgirSHB3TLnb18JXUJC2F5VusJ5fBs8KpfN7zIq7p.LicI3hH8MRUGdlhvsu8uWw--
X-Mailer: YahooMailRC/902.40 YahooMailWebService/0.7.185
Date: Mon, 21 Apr 2008 14:47:30 -0700 (PDT)
From: dangrsmind@yahoo.com
To: Giles Bowkett <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>, sf raves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Message-ID: <971493.72823.qm@web32402.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] bsp 4 programmer/dj/producer types

It is worth mentioning that a lot of people contributed to the psychedelic interfaces and algorithms of Meta's products altough Kai always gets all the credit for these things.  I'll mention Ben Weiss on algorithms and Phil Clevenger for interfaces in particular.  Phil's now at Adobe and did the interface for their new pro photgraphy tool.  

I also never saw Kai consume any substance stronger than wine, but he did tell me that he lived in the Haight for a while and played with oil projection etc. when he was younger.  For the record.

Peter

PS I am going to quote you, "The real entertainment is in the live performance, but seeing it on
YouTube *documents* that performance. In the old days recordings
*substituted for* performances."  Very nice...


----- Original Message ----
From: Giles Bowkett <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>
To: sf raves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Monday, April 21, 2008 2:26:38 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] bsp 4 programmer/dj/producer types

>  What you've done here that's really interesting I think is to extend the
> logic of these trends happeing in the marketing/distribution side to the
> production and especially performance side of things.  The notion of a
> log file being performable (yes I actually went and read your blog) is
> fascinating in this conext although not really a new idea in the software
> world.    Music is a macro?

Thanks. Interesting things happen when an old idea to some people is a
new idea to other people.

>  Now I do continue to have some heartburn with the notion that a live
> performance is like a blog because of the above arguments about blogs
> and record labels, but as long as one understands that the blog (aka a
> recorded live concert)  is not the thing that gets monetized since it is
> also searchable and is infinitely reproduceable almost for free, there's
> really no problem here.

Well yeah that's almost a founding assumption. The idea is that since
it's extremely easy for people to share your work to each other at
zero cost to them your recordings should function not as product but
as documentary. I got this idea from Improv Everywhere. I don't know
what people in technology imagined the entertainment industry might
respond to things like YouTube with, but one response is Improv
Everywhere, which does weird live improv and then posts it on YouTube.
The real entertainment is in the live performance, but seeing it on
YouTube *documents* that performance. In the old days recordings
*substituted for* performances.

>  Also, sort of off topic but maybe not, you might enjoy this snipet from my old boss Kai Krause:

Holy crap, man, Kai Krause. That man's work is one of the reasons I
decided to take acid.

>  "I used to think 'Software Design' is an art form.
>  I now believe that I was half-right:
>  it is indeed an art, but it has a rather short half-life:
>  Software is merely a performance art!
>  A momentary flash of brilliance, doomed to be overtaken by the next wave, or maybe even by its own sequel. Eaten alive by its successors. And time... "
>
>  From http://www.edge.org/q2008/q08_16.html
>
>  Keep on jamming with this...you're on the trail of something very interesting here.  IMO.

Gracias! I'm going to be speaking on this programmer as artist thing
in New York next weekend as part of a general talk on my music code.
I'm going to swipe that quote! Perfect timing for me there.

-- 

Giles Soundwave/Goat Boy/Bowkett
http://www.gilesgoatboy.org/
http://gilesbowkett.blogspot.com (code)

Kai is a really smart and entertaining guy, arguably a true visionary of what comptuers might one day become, a  fun dinner companion, a drinker and sharer of fine wines, and also atleast at the time was an absolutely nightmare-ish boss from hell.   My very first exec team meeting at MetaTools included a near fist fight between Kai and then CEO John Wilczak with me sitting directly in between them.  Hmm, maybe I should have been taking acid.  

Which brings me to one of my life mottos: 

"Dinner and software don't mix."

Best,

Peter

There's a lot of conflicting information out about that actually.

E.g. http://technology.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/tech_and_web/the_web/article2817679.ece 
http://www.afterdawn.com/news/archive/11782.cfm
http://www.theregister.co.uk/2008/03/28/will_page_1000_fans/

etc...

No one in the industry (i.e. Ethan Kaplan from Warner mentioned in one of those links whom I know) wants to acknowledge they are already the walking dead.  The funny thing to me about Ethan's quote here is that just a few months before he was doing a record launch thing in Second Life that was attended by < 100 avatars and here he's dissing Radiohead's numbers.  I knew him when he was just a lonely blogger that was the worlds biggest fan of REM.  Now he's totally indoctrinated and spewing the party line.  Ah well...

Best,

Peter

----- Original Message ----
From: J.C. <dougm@kzsu.stanford.edu>
To: sf raves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Monday, April 21, 2008 2:37:48 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] bsp 4 programmer/dj/producer types

On 21 April 2008, Uncle Noah wrote:

> Now, does this all mean that Sony/BMG charging the
> average consumer $19.95 for a 7-track CD is a fair and
> accurate exchange?  No.  But you can't paint artists
> or art with the same brush that you use on a
> corporation.  The methods that the audience has
> developed to try to punish and injure the corporate
> music industry serve to destroy and kill the
> independent music industry.

Yeah, but didn't Radiohead come away with around $5 on average for their 
"pay what you want" downloaded album recently?  If true, do you suppose 
they were upset with their sales?  Do you suppose they covered their up 
front (amortized equipment), studio time, creation time, etc. costs?

>>> log file being performable (yes I actually went and read your blog) is
>>> fascinating in this conext although not really a new idea in the softwa=
re
>>> world.    Music is a macro?
>>=20
>> Thanks. Interesting things happen when an old idea to some people is a
>> new idea to other people.
>>=20
>>>  Now I do continue to have some heartburn with the notion that a live
>>> performance is like a blog because of the above arguments about blogs
>>> and record labels, but as long as one understands that the blog (aka a
>>> recorded live concert)  is not the thing that gets monetized since it i=
s
>>> also searchable and is infinitely reproduceable almost for free, there'=
s
>>> really no problem here.
>>=20
>> Well yeah that's almost a founding assumption. The idea is that since
>> it's extremely easy for people to share your work to each other at
>> zero cost to them your recordings should function not as product but
>> as documentary. I got this idea from Improv Everywhere. I don't know
>> what people in technology imagined the entertainment industry might
>> respond to things like YouTube with, but one response is Improv
>> Everywhere, which does weird live improv and then posts it on YouTube.
>> The real entertainment is in the live performance, but seeing it on
>> YouTube *documents* that performance. In the old days recordings
>> *substituted for* performances.
>>=20
>>>  Also, sort of off topic but maybe not, you might enjoy this snipet fro=
m my old boss Kai Krause:
>>=20
>> Holy crap, man, Kai Krause. That man's work is one of the reasons I
>> decided to take acid.
>>=20
>>>  "I used to think 'Software Design' is an art form.
>>>  I now believe that I was half-right:
>>>  it is indeed an art, but it has a rather short half-life:
>>>  Software is merely a performance art!
>>>  A momentary flash of brilliance, doomed to be overtaken by the next wa=
ve, or maybe even by its own sequel. Eaten alive by its successors. And tim=
e... "
>>>
>>>  From http://www.edge.org/q2008/q08_16.html
>>>
>>>  Keep on jamming with this...you're on the trail of something very inte=
resting here.  IMO.
>>=20
>> Gracias! I'm going to be speaking on this programmer as artist thing
>> in New York next weekend as part of a general talk on my music code.
>> I'm going to swipe that quote! Perfect timing for me there.
>>=20
>> --=20
>>=20
>> Giles Soundwave/Goat Boy/Bowkett
>> http://www.gilesgoatboy.org/
>> http://gilesbowkett.blogspot.com (code)
>>=20

Subject: Re: [sfraves] bsp 4 programmer/dj/producer types


Really only one major disagreement here:

> The ability to search algorithmically, i.e. google, largely eliminates the need to promote artists.  Instead the prospective audience will simply search for and find the artists they are interested in based on hot phrases or terms that will be passed via social networks.  Algorithmic search coupled with free copies destroys every attempt to monetize aggregated or even exclusively offered "gated" content.

Fundamental shortcoming in the algorithmic method is that it still boils down
to how to game a popularity contest.  The music labels haven't figured it out
yet, but there's a couple TLAs you will learn soon if you don't already know
them: SEO/SEM.  If you're relying on a google-like service to find cool shit,
you're still going to end up spoon fed a very limited subset of what's there,
and some of the most brilliant artists will continue to go undiscovered for
lack of good marketing.

ray




On Mon, Apr 21, 2008 at 02:12:35PM -0700, dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:
> There's a fellow I know from the digital music business named Gerd Leonhard http://www.facebook.com/profile.php?id=502410383&ref=ts
> 
> His recent thesis is that "blogs" (whatever that means) are the new music labels.  While I like Gerd a lot, I think he's dead wrong here.  
> 
> The problem is that there are  not going to be "new" record labels.  The entire concept of a big record label as an organization that promotes music and produces and distributes the copies is simply dead.    As you've said, the ability to produce and distribute nearly free copies (bandwidth does cost something) eliminates most of that aspect of what the labels used to do.   But the changes underway are not just about the means of production of copies.
> 
> The ability to search algorithmically, i.e. google, largely eliminates the need to promote artists.  Instead the prospective audience will simply search for and find the artists they are interested in based on hot phrases or terms that will be passed via social networks.  Algorithmic search coupled with free copies destroys every attempt to monetize aggregated or even exclusively offered "gated" content.
> 
> What you've done here that's really interesting I think is to extend the logic of these trends happeing in the marketing/distribution side to the production and especially performance side of things.  The notion of a log file being performable (yes I actually went and read your blog) is fascinating in this conext although not really a new idea in the software world.    Music is a macro?
> 
> Now I do continue to have some heartburn with the notion that a live performance is like a blog because of the above arguments about blogs and record labels, but as long as one understands that the blog (aka a recorded live concert)  is not the thing that gets monetized since it is also searchable and is infinitely reproduceable almost for free, there's really no problem here. 
> 
> Also, sort of off topic but maybe not, you might enjoy this snipet from my old boss Kai Krause:
> 
> "I used to think 'Software Design' is an art form. 
> I now believe that I was half-right:
> it is indeed an art, but it has a rather short half-life: 
> Software is merely a performance art! 
> A momentary flash of brilliance, doomed to be overtaken by the next wave, or maybe even by its own sequel. Eaten alive by its successors. And time... "
> 
> >From http://www.edge.org/q2008/q08_16.html
> 
> Keep on jamming with this...you're on the trail of something very interesting here.  IMO.
> 
> Best,
> 
> Peter
> 
> ----- Original Message ----
> From: Giles Bowkett <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>
> To: sf raves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
> Sent: Monday, April 21, 2008 10:53:26 AM
> Subject: [sfraves] bsp 4 programmer/dj/producer types
> 
> Relevant to MP3/music biz models discussion last week:
> 
> "In an MP3 world, recordings are cheap. Therefore, the whole
> fundamental business model of selling recordings is completely doomed.
> A business model based on expensive recordings sells recordings; a
> business model based on cheap and abundant recordings gives recordings
> away. This makes the body of recordings of your live musical
> performances equivalent to a blog - you should be updating it all the
> time. Recording your live performances should be as cheap as capturing
> a log file, since distributing those recordings is as cheap as
> publishing an RSS feed."
> 
> http://gilesbowkett.blogspot.com/2008/04/archaeopteryx-logging-and-soon-unit.html
>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] bsp 4 programmer/dj/producer types


Ah, I think Peter may understand the point I was attempting to make about
bandwidth:

On Mon, Apr 21, 2008 at 02:27:26PM -0700, dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:
> Bandwidth pricing varies widely as does the method by which you are charged.  Often one is charged for peak usage for example.  Under the peak pricing model off peak incremental bandwidth is essentially free.  For example, Live365 charges for guaranteed peak hour access to popular streams as a way of shifting listeners to offf peak hours.  
> 
> Also depending on what you are serving, the quality of service may matter.  Streaming live events for example has more stringent QoS requirements than servings static media files.  Also, you'll see service providers start changing the rules on you if you actually start moving a lot of data.  Read the fine print!

And the main point why blogging prices do not scale or carry forward.  THey
can do it precisely because it's so much smaller that they can shuffle you
around into the rounding error of much more expensive products.  However,
you can't build the model around this without depending on a much larger
service/product wasting the resources that you are allowed to exploit.

The rules change as you scale up to again expose the real cost.  Everything
cheap or free on the internet works on this, which is why so many cool ideas
end up shutting down later.  When they exceed the scraps falling from much
more expensive bandwidth products, they quickly find they don't have a model
for success after all.

Note, I'm not saying any of this can't work. :)  Just that it's different
than things might appear.

> 
> Best,
> 
> Peter
> 
> ----- Original Message ----
> From: Giles Bowkett <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>
> To: sf raves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
> Sent: Monday, April 21, 2008 2:15:02 PM
> Subject: Re: [sfraves] bsp 4 programmer/dj/producer types
> 
> On the bandwidth argument, I'm curious about that. I think your
> argument's incorrect but I'm not actually sure.
> 
> The reason I think it's incorrect is I sometimes get 10,000 hits to my
> blog in a single day, if I post something controversial and/or it's a
> slow day on the Internet in general, and on a month when that happens,
> my image serving costs go up. But they really don't go up very far.
> I've got all my image files on Amazon S3, and an expensive month is
> like $2 or $3.
> 
> The reason I'm not sure is that I'm not serving mix MP3s via S3 to
> equivalent traffic, and a mix MP3 is a much larger file than an image.
> On the whole though I think you could probably get very cheap hosting
> via S3 for large MP3s without significant problems.
> 
> -- 
>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] bsp 4 programmer/dj/producer types

This is an insightful observation. It follows that bittorent (and other 
p2p services) are successful because they are able to function within the 
"rounding errors" of "free" consumer grade upstream bandwidth. The 
question is, how much revenue do these services actually pull in? 
Bittorrent.com is finally getting some paying customers, but it's still 
small potatoes compared to someone like iTunes or Amazon, I'd imagine.

At 09:13 PM 4/21/2008, dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:
>Rock music?  Like with real instruments?  Wah?
>
>Seriously thoth computer generated music the difference between the 
>recording and the performance blurs to a greater degree.  Playing 
>the instrument means generating a series of control inputs to a 
>digital device and these inputs can be recorded and replayed to 
>regenerate the performance.  Or you could even use them as a theme 
>from which to start morphing them into a new and original 
>performance with each replay. Or ...  Imagination is the limit here I think.
>
>I can also think of some counter examples such as the Grateful Dead, 
>the early years Tubes, and pretty much all punk rock.  The live 
>concerts are/were what it was about and you really have to be there 
>to experience that.  But not necessarily because the live show sounds better...
>
>Peter

In-Reply-To: <526593.99509.qm@web32406.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
User-Agent: Mutt/1.5.13 (2006-08-11)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] bsp 4 programmer/dj/producer types



Fair enough, google is a present example, not an end to itself.  Let's
assume that while there'll always be big money trying to buy its way into
the hearts and minds, that the main thing the internet has provided is
the real choice that they can no longer completely stifle the alternate
sounds and choices.  The undeniable advantage we're seeing is that anyone
can get some expression of their art where someone determined enough to
find it, can.

Let me look at another scenario.  I'm new.  Some guy next to me in traffic
had some choonz blasting out of his car and it was way cooler than the hip pop
I'm used to, though it still wasn't perfect to me.  I figured out it was
some techno thanks to my cellular carrier's tune identifier service, but I
got sick of that track and don't know what else to try.  Oh, I found a blog,
except like every blog, every track/artist/mix/subgenre has fans and haterz.
Exactly how am I going to explore this new style of music to know what
I'm lookin' for?  I know how to find the latest track from britneybitch,
because she said that's her name.  The rest of this stuff, am I just supposed
to spend the rest of my life downloading tracks at random from every site
I surf to?

How do I find the stuff I've never heard of, from the really great artist
who just got that first, amazing track online somewhere?  How do I know
whom to listen to for guidance?  Going to live parties, raves, etc?  well,
how do I know what party to go to?  At some point, discovery requires a
jumping off point, and it's often going to be decided by someone else's
promotion/marketing budget.

Not really sure where it's all headed, myself, though it's definitely
exciting, and yes, I am quite convinced that the traditional ability
of the music labels to control what people hear has been broken, in a
critical and irrevocable way.  Ultimately, we'll certainly figure out
something, or just be lazy and let it happen like so much else in our
culture, but either way it'll finally be an actual choice.












On Mon, Apr 21, 2008 at 09:00:18PM -0700, dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:
> Valid point.  
> 
> Gradiva Couzin's (http://www.yourseoplan.com/)  son goes to preschool with my son Bennett and we've talked about some of this stuff before.  But we were both drunk so I can't remember what we concluded if anything.  Probably we decided to drink more.
> 
> The search algorithms continue to get smarter and harder to game.  And the SEO/SEM optimizers get smarter in response.  There's a coevolution happening there that actually leads search to become more effective over time in theory.
> 
> Perhaps I should state my position more carefully here because I am not really talking simply about Google as it exists right now...
> 
> Peter
> 
> 
> ----- Original Message ----
> From: Ray Wong <rayw@rayw.net>
> To: dangrsmind@yahoo.com
> Cc: Giles Bowkett <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>; sf raves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
> Sent: Monday, April 21, 2008 7:52:12 PM
> Subject: Re: [sfraves] bsp 4 programmer/dj/producer types
> 
> 
> Really only one major disagreement here:
> 
> > The ability to search algorithmically, i.e. google, largely eliminates the need to promote artists.  Instead the prospective audience will simply search for and find the artists they are interested in based on hot phrases or terms that will be passed via social networks.  Algorithmic search coupled with free copies destroys every attempt to monetize aggregated or even exclusively offered "gated" content.
> 
> Fundamental shortcoming in the algorithmic method is that it still boils down
> to how to game a popularity contest.  The music labels haven't figured it out
> yet, but there's a couple TLAs you will learn soon if you don't already know
> them: SEO/SEM.  If you're relying on a google-like service to find cool shit,
> you're still going to end up spoon fed a very limited subset of what's there,
> and some of the most brilliant artists will continue to go undiscovered for
> lack of good marketing.
> 
> ray
> 
> 
> 
> 
> On Mon, Apr 21, 2008 at 02:12:35PM -0700, dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:
> > There's a fellow I know from the digital music business named Gerd Leonhard http://www.facebook.com/profile.php?id=502410383&ref=ts
> > 
> > His recent thesis is that "blogs" (whatever that means) are the new music labels.  While I like Gerd a lot, I think he's dead wrong here.  
> > 
> > The problem is that there are  not going to be "new" record labels.  The entire concept of a big record label as an organization that promotes music and produces and distributes the copies is simply dead.    As you've said, the ability to produce and distribute nearly free copies (bandwidth does cost something) eliminates most of that aspect of what the labels used to do.  But the changes underway are not just about the means of production of copies.
> > 
> > The ability to search algorithmically, i.e. google, largely eliminates the need to promote artists.  Instead the prospective audience will simply search for and find the artists they are interested in based on hot phrases or terms that will be passed via social networks.  Algorithmic search coupled with free copies destroys every attempt to monetize aggregated or even exclusively offered "gated" content.
> > 
> > What you've done here that's really interesting I think is to extend the logic of these trends happeing in the marketing/distribution side to the production and especially performance side of things.  The notion of a log file being performable (yes I actually went and read your blog) is fascinating in this conext although not really a new idea in the software world.    Music is a macro?
> > 
> > Now I do continue to have some heartburn with the notion that a live performance is like a blog because of the above arguments about blogs and record labels, but as long as one understands that the blog (aka a recorded live concert)  is not the thing that gets monetized since it is also searchable and is infinitely reproduceable almost for free, there's really no problem here. 
> > 
> > Also, sort of off topic but maybe not, you might enjoy this snipet from my old boss Kai Krause:
> > 
> > "I used to think 'Software Design' is an art form. 
> > I now believe that I was half-right:
> > it is indeed an art, but it has a rather short half-life: 
> > Software is merely a performance art! 
> > A momentary flash of brilliance, doomed to be overtaken by the next wave, or maybe even by its own sequel. Eaten alive by its successors. And time... "
> > 
> > >From http://www.edge.org/q2008/q08_16.html
> > 
> > Keep on jamming with this...you're on the trail of something very interesting here.  IMO.
> > 
> > Best,
> > 
> > Peter
> > 
> > ----- Original Message ----
> > From: Giles Bowkett <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>
> > To: sf raves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
> > Sent: Monday, April 21, 2008 10:53:26 AM
> > Subject: [sfraves] bsp 4 programmer/dj/producer types
> > 
> > Relevant to MP3/music biz models discussion last week:
> > 
> > "In an MP3 world, recordings are cheap. Therefore, the whole
> > fundamental business model of selling recordings is completely doomed.
> > A business model based on expensive recordings sells recordings; a
> > business model based on cheap and abundant recordings gives recordings
> > away. This makes the body of recordings of your live musical
> > performances equivalent to a blog - you should be updating it all the
> > time. Recording your live performances should be as cheap as capturing
> > a log file, since distributing those recordings is as cheap as
> > publishing an RSS feed."
> > 
> > http://gilesbowkett.blogspot.com/2008/04/archaeopteryx-logging-and-soon-unit.html
> > 
> > -- 
> >

Subject: [sfraves] Tuesday Techno Mix

http://home.tiscali.nl/fullspectrum/Steve_Rachmad_at_Outhouse_01_09_07.mp3

Steve Rachmad - Outhouse Festival - Soest NL - Sep 2007

Steve Rachmad is a globally known Dutch techno producer, DJ and  
remixer. By many, he is considered a father of Detroit techno in the  
Netherlands, respected in the world of electronic music for his deep,  
groovy sounds that tend to rest on impressive strings, melodies, funk  
and soul. His career has been reaching its highest peaks from 1996 up  
to the present time. Yet, it is somewhat less known that he has been  
in the music realms for 25 years by now.

Steve?s life story starts in Amsterdam. At the age of 12, teenage  
Steve already starts buying his first records: to mix, remix, and  
cut-and-paste their parts with an open reel tape deck. In such a  
cut-and-paste fashion, he presented his first release in the  
mid-1980s. Among these early releases was also the one created for a  
hip-house/dance artist Tony Scott.

 From that time on, Steve finds his inspiration in the 1980s dance and  
electro, works of former Time members (Jimmy Jam and Terry Lewis), The  
System, Arthur Baker, to name but a few. At the age of 15, he also  
starts his DJing career with a disco set in a small Amsterdam club.  
Nevertheless, his love for music urges him to start buying equipment,  
which would later result in a professional studio that is, according  
to him, ?everything he ever dreamt of having.? Today, his equipment is  
mainly analogue, providing him with a chance to explore the realms of  
warm, alive, non-static sounds. He laid the corner stone of this  
collection in 1985, by getting a TR-808.

A year later, Steve gets introduced to the house music. His attention  
is captured by the new sounds echoing mostly from Detroit and Chicago,  
i.e. by the work of artists such as Mr. Fingers and Derrick May.  
Following their style, Steve?s own style takes a new direction. He is  
soon to be found releasing for artists like Darren Emerson and Derrick  
May.

The incoming years are to be marked by numerous successful releases on  
labels such as 100% Pure, Underwater, Fragile, M-Plant, Tresor, etc.  
He also made a significant number of remixes, signed under various  
pseudonyms. Among Steve?s most respected releases is certainly his  
album ?Secret Life of Machines,? which came out in 1996 under his  
pseudonym Sterac, and is up to this date considered as one of the  
all-time techno classics. About the same time his DJing path starts  
rapidly evolving as well. Until today, Steve shares his talent with  
the crowds all over the World. He occasionally spins disco and  
electro, but mainly techno.

Of all the fictitious names he used throughout his career to sign his  
productions, the ones that remained until today are Sterac, Ignacio,  
Dreg, Parallel 9, Adverse Match and Sterac Electronics. They appear on  
labels like Music Man, CLR, Jericho, Sino, etc. Steve also runs three  
labels of his own: Scorp, Ion, and an electro label Interpersonal  
//XP. The history of remixes continues into the present, including a  
variety of people, such as the Advent, Vince Watson, Kanzleramt, Mark  
Broom, Chris Liebing, etc. In the latest years, next to his  
characteristic techno sound, he also actively focuses on electro,  
stripping it down to the old-school feel. His latest Sterac  
Electronics remix of the vocal track Love Sweet Love (by Clashing  
Egos), and the ?Night Heat? release on Music Man Records have ended up  
in the record bags of a wide variety of artists, from techno, to  
minimal, house and electro. He re-confirms his sterac againreputation  
as an artist with exquisite ear for technical qualities of sound,  
always returning to his soulful roots and maintaining the warmth of  
analogue-produced music.

Over the years, Steve lost the count of his productions and remixes.  
However, he built an oeuvre that is without a doubt of a high  
magnitude: both quality and quantity-wise. Unfortunately, his busy DJ  
schedule puts a limit on the time he would like to spend in his  
studio. Yet, he strives for the balance that would satisfy his  
enormous artistic appetite and potential. His devotion to his dreams  
and inspirations drives him safely into the successful future.

http://www.myspace.com/steverachmad


---------------------------------------------------------------------

Word of mouth has always been the only effective means of advertising. I
cite whole foods, who have never run a single television commercial but have
experienced consistent explosive growth for over a decade. Get your little
obsessed mooklings to make a lifestyle out of your shit, and get them to go
proselytize to all their mookly friends. Thats how the music industry works
anyway. Everything else is just gloss.

> to spend the rest of my life downloading tracks at random from every site
> I surf to?

  The Paradox - 9pm tonight in the VOID..

"No wonder kids grow up crazy," the midget says. "A cat's cradle is  
nothing but a bunch of X's between somebody's hands, and little kids  
look and look and look at all those X's..."
"And?"
"No damn cat, and no damn cradle."
-Kurt Vonnegut

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of  
the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will  
gradually become visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"



--Apple-Mail-2-804488197--

X-YMail-OSG: kPmy9QYVM1nRvrjHTrre5WGq3HJepVPu3wWnnzUQDPamsCPNBVQzb3SQuFCSP6.ooMKRePZWhBt.Ja_T8Ajb0sWxh6B.SpMK

Date: Tue, 22 Apr 2008 12:46:55 -0700 (PDT)
From: dangrsmind@yahoo.com
To: Ray Wong <rayw@rayw.net>
Cc: Giles Bowkett <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>, sf raves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Message-ID: <652002.19190.qm@web32405.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] bsp 4 programmer/dj/producer types

"The rest of this stuff, am I just supposed
to spend the rest of my life downloading tracks at random from every site
I surf to?"

No that's what you trained monkey slaves are for.  You did get yours right?  Serioulsy, this is precisely why you'll use a search algorithm to help you...

"How do I find the stuff I've never heard of, from the really great artist
who just got that first, amazing track online somewhere?  How do I know
whom to listen to for guidance?  Going to live parties, raves, etc?  well,
how do I know what party to go to?  At some point, discovery requires a
jumping off point, and it's often going to be decided by someone else's
promotion/marketing budget."

You do need to start somewhere, and there is no guarantee that you won't start somewhere lame or with a site that's simply hijacked your keywords.  This is a well known problem in collaborative filtering and web search.  There are a number of ideas for solutions, for example by leveraging your social network.  OK, if you are a clueless loser with no friends you are still going to be fucked.  Get off the Internet and go outside.

But once you find something good out there you can immediately leverage the fact that a machine has searched uncountably many webpages to find the similar ones with the exact terms "french electro dubstep porn rock" or whatever.  If you really needed to find the Belgian variety, the search engine could simply expand your search geographically or by language.  There are standard methods of expanding searches, i.e. by secondary key word patterns, language/country of origin, author, date/time, location, etc. Seasoned searchers do all of this themselves since Google doesn't automate all of this for you yet.  And BTW when I say automate here I mean to include any algorithm that uses inference of patterns from user clickstream data so its not all about pure algorithmic recommendation and selection...

"Not really sure where it's all headed, myself, though it's definitely
exciting, and yes, I am quite convinced that the traditional ability
of the music labels to control what people hear has been broken, in a
critical and irrevocable way.  Ultimately, we'll certainly figure out
something, or just be lazy and let it happen like so much else in our
culture, but either way it'll finally be an actual choice."

With robots and algorithmic agents to help us, we can be totally lazy couch potatos and get exactly what we want exaclty when we want it.  

Plus you can have sex with robots.  'Nuff said.

Best,

Peter

---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: [sfraves] A new techno track from Chelsea - "Astral"

------=_Part_14267_32160505.1208902129884
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1

I wanted to test out my new audio interface so I whipped up this track last
night, and I think it turned out kind of nice. "Astral" a spaced-out techno
track, was produced on my hardware setup and recorded live in one take in my
home studio here in Alameda.
If you want to check it out, you may download the mp3 at
http://www.divshare.com/download/4322451-e3b or you can listen to it on my
myspace page - www.myspace.com/chelcfaithmusic

That's all, just wanted to share. =)

Love Chelsea

track, was produced on my hardware setup and recorded live in one take in my
home studio here in Alameda.

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] bsp 4 programmer/dj/producer types


This is my $.02 on the thread and a quick (not very rave related) BSP at 
the bottom if you want to skip to that:

Having had an interest in techno, electronic music in general and 
stochiastic/intelligent computer composed work since the late 80s, I've 
been following this thread, writing half responses over and over and then 
not sending them.  Mostly cause the fact of the matter is that producers / 
artists SHOULD be able to recover monies for their copyrighted works, just 
as film staff, jingle writers and authors and all those others should.  
The solutions are disgusting for many people, they lie in either ethics or 
enforcement (legal, corporate or both), and neither one is all that 
appealling.  If something costs me $1,000,000 to make, and I just have 2 
million fans pick it up for free, I'm kinda fucked if I was banking on a 
third of them paying a few buycks each.  Some projects will never make 
money touring the way they can in the studio (at least by the "old" 
model).  Tours like Pink Floyd's "The Wall" were a horrible money sink, 
they were fueled by album sales and licensing.  All this stuff about "evil 
record labels" and anti-corporate sentiment is like justifying stealing 
gum from Walmart.  It's still wrong.  It's just less wrong than stealing 
from your sister, or your neighbor cause Walmart are unmitigated bastards.

I really think the live model is good, I love music performed.  The 
frustrating thing about that is it sucks for live techno.  I've seen more 
"Live PAs" than most people, and they tend to be either horribly dishonest 
(aka cheerleading over a bunch of half plugged in gear while a DAT plays) 
or just plain boring to watch.  I've played off laptops, piles of gear, 
various mixes of the above, and after a long time experimenting I've sorta 
realized that the most fun on both sides of the 4th wall seems to be this 
weird interface called "a guitar", working with other tone generators 
called "band members" with a beer stained hand copied setlist that usually 
only gets followed for the first song or two.  No, it's not techno, but 
it's obviously live, fun, and visceral as all fucky.

I still play live pa's of my techno, but it's honestly frustrating when 
the best compliments you get are "wow, that was really good for a laptop 
dj set" (do they have any idea I wrote every single note of this shit?).

That said... my band (the Lag) is playing Thursday in SF if you want to 
come say hi or check it out or whatever.  Info below my sig.

andyw - mutorsoundsystem - saturn5.com/andy
/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\_________________
"I think the biggest misconception about me is that I'm this spoiled brat. 
But I'm not. I'm, like, the total opposite." - Paris Hilton



::Thursday April 24th::
The Lag & Gosta Berling @
Mr. Smiths - 34 7th st.
sound by cloudsound
san francisco, California 94103
9pm - $5.00 - AIDS Lifecycle Benefit

THIS IS NOT A DRILL!!!

In what might be our last set as a two piece; we're digging into our top 
secret amory*, arming the megaton love bombs and leaving a foreboding 
mushroom cloud with over 500 ppm of hallucinogenic/radioactive particles 
in the air for our devoted fans to inhale.

Also debuting some new material that we've been having a blast playing, so 
the fun factor and freshness should be turned on full blast. Get there at 
9pm sharp, we're on first and this place doesn't go very late.

- AndyW

Samples of Gosta Berling - http://www.cabinlife.org/
Samples of the Lag - http://myspace.com/thelagsf
Show Flyer - www.saturn5.com/andy/lag02.jpg

* yes, I know bombs are kept in an "armory", but love bombs are stored in 
an "amory". I swear, I thought that one through...

X-YMail-OSG: E9iamMcVM1ljHjuOfqetibb2BoF_KIXoUkCDFiMoZc1RdGpj38rVa8oCBd9B5ejcnimjH.VEx4Nb64ALhTToUz7HL.sJ7DIRdOtAfr09msf7Yp7q7uWsAQ--
