Date: Tue, 22 Apr 2008 20:17:16 -0700 (PDT)
From: dangrsmind@yahoo.com
To: AndyW <andy@saturn5.com>, sf raves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Message-ID: <465298.24145.qm@web32404.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] bsp 4 programmer/dj/producer types

Hmm.  I wasn't advocating stealing music from anyone.  But lets face it, stealing from the RIAA labels is at least ironic justice if not actually  justified.  After all they steal the music in many cases themselves.  E.g. http://archive.salon.com/tech/feature/2000/06/14/love/print.html#  and http://www.internet-defense.org/John-Deep_Piracy_by_RIAA_Agents

A more recent example of the RIAA fucking the artists with a little help from their friends:  http://gizmodo.com/352762/riaa-wants-to-cut-artist-royalties-to-9-apple-wants-them-at-4-artists-just-want-to-eat 

Plus they are simply fucks in general.  E.g.

http://www.boingboing.net/2006/04/23/riaa-sues-family-tha.html
http://news.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=08/04/18/1233227
etc.

And I could list a hundred more examples of their foulness.

Still I wasn't trying to encourage anyone to steal from these people although that might appear to be their karma.  That would be both wrong and illegal.

Rather I am suggesting that we simply don't do business with them.  Never, ever.  Don't buy what they are selling.  Instead buy direct from artists and small labels only and buy major label music used if you must.  This is neither illegal nor unethical.  Its merely smart consumerism and probably good business if you are in the industry yourself.

Trying to inflate the price of a good or service by creating artificial scarcity only works until it doesn't.  Oh, BTW remember this one?   http://www.cdfreaks.com/news/RIAA-price-fixing-settlement-delivers-dud-CDs-to-libraries.html Ya just gotta love these guys...

Anyway those days are over (for better or worse) in the music business.   I listen to music for free all day long and none of it or almost none of it is from any RIAA related label.  I don't need to nor want to steal their music.  That's why they now want to tax everyone's Internet service instead.  (http://www.techcrunch.com/2008/03/28/the-music-tax-details-of-the-plan-they-dont-want-you-to-know/) $5 per month for music you didn't even buy or listen to? Whom exactly is stealing from whom here? 

The current fuss and ruckus from the industry about people stealing music is truly  "a tale told by an idiot, full of sound and fury, signifying nothing."  And the lawsuits and vile legislation proposals are merely the sounds of loudly dying dinosaur.  Game over.  The consumer and the Internet has won.

Therefore, in almost all cases artists will be better served by working within rather than against the new paradigm and exploring new ideas and possibilities.   Of course those giant royalty advances from the big labels are tempting...

IMO, YMMV.

Best,

Peter

PS Will there be a giant inflatable pig at this so called rock music performance?  If not, why not?



----- Original Message ----
From: AndyW <andy@saturn5.com>
To: sf raves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Tuesday, April 22, 2008 7:04:45 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] bsp 4 programmer/dj/producer types


This is my $.02 on the thread and a quick (not very rave related) BSP at 
the bottom if you want to skip to that:

Having had an interest in techno, electronic music in general and 
stochiastic/intelligent computer composed work since the late 80s, I've 
been following this thread, writing half responses over and over and then 
not sending them.  Mostly cause the fact of the matter is that producers / 
artists SHOULD be able to recover monies for their copyrighted works, just 
as film staff, jingle writers and authors and all those others should.  
The solutions are disgusting for many people, they lie in either ethics or 
enforcement (legal, corporate or both), and neither one is all that 
appealling.  If something costs me $1,000,000 to make, and I just have 2 
million fans pick it up for free, I'm kinda fucked if I was banking on a 
third of them paying a few buycks each.  Some projects will never make 
money touring the way they can in the studio (at least by the "old" 
model).  Tours like Pink Floyd's "The Wall" were a horrible money sink, 
they were fueled by album sales and licensing.  All this stuff about "evil 
record labels" and anti-corporate sentiment is like justifying stealing 
gum from Walmart.  It's still wrong.  It's just less wrong than stealing 
from your sister, or your neighbor cause Walmart are unmitigated bastards.

I really think the live model is good, I love music performed.  The 
frustrating thing about that is it sucks for live techno.  I've seen more 
"Live PAs" than most people, and they tend to be either horribly dishonest 
(aka cheerleading over a bunch of half plugged in gear while a DAT plays) 
or just plain boring to watch.  I've played off laptops, piles of gear, 
various mixes of the above, and after a long time experimenting I've sorta 
realized that the most fun on both sides of the 4th wall seems to be this 
weird interface called "a guitar", working with other tone generators 
called "band members" with a beer stained hand copied setlist that usually 
only gets followed for the first song or two.  No, it's not techno, but 
it's obviously live, fun, and visceral as all fucky.

I still play live pa's of my techno, but it's honestly frustrating when 
the best compliments you get are "wow, that was really good for a laptop 
dj set" (do they have any idea I wrote every single note of this shit?).

That said... my band (the Lag) is playing Thursday in SF if you want to 
come say hi or check it out or whatever.  Info below my sig.

andyw - mutorsoundsystem - saturn5.com/andy
/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\_________________

Subject: Re: [sfraves] bsp 4 programmer/dj/producer types

>  I really think the live model is good, I love music performed.  The
>  frustrating thing about that is it sucks for live techno.  I've seen more
>  "Live PAs" than most people, and they tend to be either horribly dishonest
>  (aka cheerleading over a bunch of half plugged in gear while a DAT plays)
>  or just plain boring to watch.  I've played off laptops, piles of gear,
>  various mixes of the above, and after a long time experimenting I've sorta
>  realized that the most fun on both sides of the 4th wall seems to be this
>  weird interface called "a guitar", working with other tone generators
>  called "band members" with a beer stained hand copied setlist that usually
>  only gets followed for the first song or two.  No, it's not techno, but
>  it's obviously live, fun, and visceral as all fucky.
>
>  I still play live pa's of my techno, but it's honestly frustrating when
>  the best compliments you get are "wow, that was really good for a laptop
>  dj set" (do they have any idea I wrote every single note of this shit?).

Muahahahahahahahahahahaha!!!!!!! Soon my robot minions will etc etc etc etc

Its no joke kids, robot sex is in your future and you don't have to just believe me because MSNBC says its true: http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/21271545/

Some links NSFW!

Mime-Version: 1.0 (Apple Message framework v753)

Message-Id: <1A2AB4BB-5AFE-40CE-A708-A38243F022C7@deepfog.com>

From: Deepfog <sfo@deepfog.com>
Date: Thu, 24 Apr 2008 10:48:28 -0700
X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.753)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Thu)

April 24, 2008

To:  Members of the UCSC Community
Fr:  Ginny Steel, University Librarian
Re:  Grateful Dead Archives Given to UCSC

It is a thrill to write to tell you that the surviving members of the  
iconic rock 'n' roll band, the Grateful Dead, have selected the UCSC  
Library as the permanent home for their substantial archive of  
materials documenting the band's history. The collection will be the  
largest donation ever made to the library's Special Collections  
Department, and it includes more than 2,000 square feet of  
memorabilia, artifacts, and other documents. This incomparable  
archive will undoubtedly become a major resource for research related  
to the Grateful Dead, the phenomenon of the Deadheads, American  
music, and popular culture during the last three decades of the 20th  
century.

The formal announcement of this gift will be made this morning at a  
press conference to be held at the Fillmore in San Francisco, a  
singularly appropriate venue where the band performed many times.  
Chancellor Blumenthal will be present to accept the archive on behalf  
of the campus, and he will be joined by Grateful Dead band members  
Bob Weir and Mickey Hart.

UCSC has a long tradition of academic interest in the Grateful Dead.  
Fred Lieberman, professor of music, teaches a course on the band, and  
he has also collaborated with Mickey Hart on two books, Planet Drum  
and Drumming at the Edge of Magic. It was through Professor Lieberman  
that we first became aware of the search for a home for the archive.

The Library will be raising funds to support the processing and  
preservation of the archive, and, as work on it begins, we will  
provide regular updates on our web site.

The press conference, which will begin at 11 a.m., will be streamed  
live on the web. You can access it via a link on the UCSC home page;  
a press release, providing more information about this substantial  
gift, will also be posted there at that time.


--

I mean, just because you're a musician doesn't mean all your ideas  
are about music. So every once in a while I get an idea about  
plumbing, I get an idea about city government, and they come the way  
they come.

- Jerry Garcia

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

the hell-ride bad motherfuckers without any assistance from Mr. Garcia, the
Grateful Dead are officially useless to me.

> On Thu, Apr 24, 2008 at 10:48 AM, Deepfog <sfo@deepfog.com> wrote:
>
> > April 24, 2008
> >
> > To:  Members of the UCSC Community
> > Fr:  Ginny Steel, University Librarian
> > Re:  Grateful Dead Archives Given to UCSC
> >
> > It is a thrill to write to tell you that the surviving members of the
> > iconic rock 'n' roll band, the Grateful Dead, have selected the UCSC
> Library
> > as the permanent home for their substantial archive of materials
> documenting
> > the band's history. The collection will be the largest donation ever
> made to
> > the library's Special Collections Department, and it includes more
> than
> > 2,000 square feet of memorabilia, artifacts, and other documents. This
> > incomparable archive will undoubtedly become a major resource for
> research
> > related to the Grateful Dead, the phenomenon of the Deadheads,
> American
> > music, and popular culture during the last three decades of the 20th
> > century.
> >
> > The formal announcement of this gift will be made this morning at a
> press
> > conference to be held at the Fillmore in San Francisco, a singularly
> > appropriate venue where the band performed many times. Chancellor
> Blumenthal
> > will be present to accept the archive on behalf of the campus, and he
> will
> > be joined by Grateful Dead band members Bob Weir and Mickey Hart.
> >
> > UCSC has a long tradition of academic interest in the Grateful Dead.
> Fred
> > Lieberman, professor of music, teaches a course on the band, and he
> has also
> > collaborated with Mickey Hart on two books, Planet Drum and Drumming
> at the
> > Edge of Magic. It was through Professor Lieberman that we first became
> aware
> > of the search for a home for the archive.
> >
> > The Library will be raising funds to support the processing and
> > preservation of the archive, and, as work on it begins, we will
> provide
> > regular updates on our web site.
> >
> > The press conference, which will begin at 11 a.m., will be streamed
> live on
> > the web. You can access it via a link on the UCSC home page; a press
> > release, providing more information about this substantial gift, will
> also
> > be posted there at that time.
> >
> >
> > --
> >
> > I mean, just because you're a musician doesn't mean all your ideas are
> > about music. So every once in a while I get an idea about plumbing, I
> get an
> > idea about city government, and they come the way they come.
> >
> > - Jerry Garcia
> >
> >
> >

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Oppose the music tax! And related attempts to pick your pocket...

Some of you already know about this, so I apologize in advnace for this red=
undant posting.  If you are not aware of the issue, please read on...=0A=0A=
Oppose RIAA, MBG, and other big media taxes on your Internet connection! =
=0A=0AIn the USA:=0AWarner Music group wants to charge every Internet user =
in the United States a $5 per month tax in exchange for a blanket license t=
o use their music. This additional fee would be charged by your ISP without=
 your consent and you would have to pay even if you never downloaded or lis=
tened to any music owned by Warner. This amounts to a multi-billion dollar =
gift to the recording industry out of our pockets.=0A=0AIn the UK:=0AThe Mu=
sic Business Group (MBG), an umbrella group including the BPI (British Phon=
ographic Industry), has called for a new tax to be levied on "format shifti=
ng", that is copying an MP3 file ripped from a CD to an iPod or other music=
 player. Peter Jenner, a well known figure in the music industry wants a ma=
ndatory monthly tax in the European Union on broadband Internet and mobile =
phones of around =E2=82=AC4/month. This hypothetically would allow consumer=
s to download and consume all the music they wanted without DRM.=0A=0AIn Ca=
lifornia:=0AOn top of Warner's proposed $5 fee one California lawmaker, Ass=
emblyman Charles Calderon D- City of Industry, wants to charge sales tax on=
 digital music downloads (and possibly other downloads) to help alleviate t=
he state's budget crisis. This incredibly dangerous proposal attempts to cr=
eate a new tax regime for digital goods which might apply to any digital pr=
oduct.=0A=0AIn Tennessee:=0AGovernor Phil Bredesen's Department of Revenue =
is planning to tax iTunes downloads, and all other digital media purchased =
online and download including music videos, movies, news and entertainment =
programs, music, ringtones and electronic books. Under current law digitall=
y delivered goods are not taxable unless delivered in a tangible form.=0A=
=0AThe Stakes:=0AIf Warner Music is successful in pushing this fee onto you=
r Internet bill you can expect other media companies to demand a cut as wel=
l. Naturally the other major labels will want their share. Can you expect a=
 movie tax and a video game tax in your future even if you've never downloa=
ded a movie or played a video game? How high will these fees go? =0A=0AAnd =
if Charles Calderone's bill passes in California or Governor Phil Bredesen =
gets his way in Tennessee residents of those states will have to pay an add=
itional sales tax on top of the industry's fees for each track that they do=
wnload. But even worse these proposals establish laws with such vague langu=
age that any transfered non-tangible good could be taxed in the future. Thi=
s is essentially a tax on speech. =0A=0AIn the UK and Europe, the MBG's and=
 other efforts likely would force European consumers to pay significantly h=
igher prices for digital audio/video devices such as the iPod and most mobi=
le phones. It will also create a tax and enforcement regime similar to that=
 currently in place for collecting the television tax in the UK. One should=
 also expect the movie and television industries to demand mandatory levies=
 in addition to these fees.=0A=0AWhat you can do about it:=0AContact your I=
SP and let them know that you oppose these improper and unfair fees on your=
 Internet usage. Contact your legislative representatives and let them know=
 what you think. Fly the "Nine Striped Flag", share this group on your Face=
book profile, and tell your friends to oppose these taxes on Internet and m=
edia use.=0A=0AWho we are:=0AThe New Sons of Liberty take their name from t=
he group of individuals that opposed unfair taxation during the American co=
lonial era. We share their ideals, that taxation without representation is =
tyranny, and that unfair taxes and fees charged without individual consent =
should be opposed by all freedom loving men and women. =0A=0AFor now we're =
on Facebook here: http://www.facebook.com/group.php?gid=3D16187415986&ref=

So This is It! Come join us for the first ever Stilldream Campout Fundraise=
r to hit the bay area.

<<<Stilldream>>>
Friday April 25th, 2008
Bay Area Fundraiser!

Area 1: The Lost Garden
Breaks / House / Techno / Trance

Dub Step / DNB / Breaks

Arize - Connected - SF
Atom ONE - National Entity - Sacramento
The Aaron Brothers - Rizin & David Aaron - Sac / Reno
Darkemeth - Viral Vibes / Desert Tribe - Reno
Adammatic - Viral Vibes / Desert Tribe - Reno


What is Stilldream?
Stilldream is something different for everyone. Ask anyone who=92s been and=
 they
have a hard time coming up with words to describe what it means to them. Al=
l
we can say is, "Its not a party, its an experience. You have to go to under=
stand".

Since many Stilldreamers live in different areas of California, the west co=
ast and
the U.S., fundraisers are a way that we can all reunite under one roof duri=
ng the
rest of the year as we all anxiously await the return of the Anniversary ev=
ent.
Some say its a warm-up party to get those creative juices flowing, so we ca=
n hit
the ground running for the Campout.

So This is It!
Come join us for the first ever Stilldream Campout Fundraiser to hit the ba=
y area.
All of the proceeds of this event go directly into the anniversary event co=
ming
June 13, 14 and 15th 2008. Do not miss this monumental occasion!

2 Rooms / Fully Permitted!

All Responsible Ages Welcome
Bar for the 21+

$10 b4 11PM / $15 after
8PM - 3AM

MORE INFO:
415.373.0181
916.676.7411
www.stilldream.org
www.myspace.com/stilldream


Stilldream 8 Year Anniversary
Coming June 13th, 14th & 15th, 2008!
Tickets now on sale @:
www.groovetickets.com

www.stilldream.org

Subject: [sfraves] Wed night review

So like Ms Seraphim is like 1 of my oldest closest Homegirl Sista's in
like forever now & apparently she's been hiding back here in the Bay Area
for the past month now working & doing gigs on the sly here since she's
back here from NYC... grrr... I didn't even know & well.. anywaze... I
found out she was here through Sleazemore & that she was spinning @ his
new monthly @ Vessel in the City!! So YAY!!  But like Seraphim like hella
AIMed me yesterday & told me, even though i knew & I wanted to surprise
her, but i told her i know already, but to throw her off, I told her i got
a Ben Aflect facelift, but when it healed i looked like Tom Cruise, 'cause
i mean... i wanted to surprise her!

Anywaze, got to Vessel around like 7:45ish.. & there was this like Trunk
show there... i met 1 of hte designers @ her ummm... clothing section &
Wow... mondo yummy stuff, like all this graph art in Chinesse Characters &
kinda Animie-ish kinda looking stuff on shirts & jackets!!  Loved it!!

Then around like 9ish, Sleazemore & HELLO 2DAY... SERAPHIM showed up &
like seriously... we talk like crazy.. it was Awesome!!!  Oh oh oh.. lol..
the 1st thing she said to me was that I didn't look like Tom Cruise... lol
Oh yeah... so I'm not sure how long this place has been open, but there
was this happy hour (literally an hour) of free Saphire gin mixed
drinks... so i had some... WOW!!!  Really YUmmy actually...

After the Trunk clothing people left, there was a few heads that stuck
around & a few more that showed up while i was there... but yeah... it was
fun meeting new people!!! :)

So when they finally got on the decks, they were all Electro-ie & stuff...
it was fun!!  Oh yeah.. there was this girl, ummm, forgot her name, who
was a GoGo Dancer turned 9-5 business executive which was Awesome!!  She's
a CooL Chica & we're suppose to hang out alot & go dancing!

Unfortunately, i couldn't stay all too long to see Drop The Lime's set :( 
I left around 10:30-ish ';cause i seriously had to get home & well... not
have a gypsy raver adventure 'cause i wasn't really feeling it last night
& totally like felt this mondo need to be home for like some reason.

OK.. riding the bart & taking a bus home & waiting @ the gas station where
my Uncle works graveyard for my dad to like pick me up.. so not fun!!!  I
mean... yeah... lol.. hello 2Day... i hella had to admit to my Uncle Benji
that I was drunk 'cause i mean... yeah... grrrr...

BUt it was a Groovy night!!!  Vessel is a cute lil spot like totally
hidden, so if
know where ummm.. Campton St is... it's 85 Campton!!  But yeah... nice
staff, & well... that whole free drinks between 9-10, that was just bonus
man!  YAAAY!!! :)

Subject: [sfraves] dj jelo RIP :(

All,

I think some on the list might know Jeff Elo who lived here during the Internet boom years and DJed hereabouts under the name Jelo for a bit.  

He was mostly known for his driving progressive house sets and he played at parties such as the Qool at 111 Minna, some crazy nights at Jelly's, etc.

Just heard he died in Australia possibly due to an overdose of GHB.

Be careful out there kids and keep safe.

Peace,

Peter

PS Please note that there is/was more than one DJ Jelo.  Don't get confused!

----- Original Message ----
From: "dangrsmind@yahoo.com" <dangrsmind@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Sent: Friday, April 25, 2008 11:09:11 AM
Subject: [sfraves] dj jelo RIP :(

All,

I think some on the list might know Jeff Elo who lived here during the Internet boom years and DJed hereabouts under the name Jelo for a bit.  

He was mostly known for his driving progressive house sets and he played at parties such as the Qool at 111 Minna, some crazy nights at Jelly's, etc.

Just heard he died in Australia possibly due to an overdose of GHB.

Be careful out there kids and keep safe.

Peace,

Peter

PS Please note that there is/was more than one DJ Jelo.  Don't get confused!

Tonight on Radio Integrated :: Friday April 25th 2008 ::  9pm-1am Pacific
Time  ::  http://radio.defsf.com:1200/

A live DJ set from Derek Scott / The Rhythmist !

Derek Scott a.k.a. The Rhythmist is one of the forerunners of the San Jose
techno scene and continues to shape its ever changing sound with his label,
Dobox Recordings. His mixing is smooth, his record selection is fresh, and
he is by far one of the most down to earth and passionate guys you'll meet
in techno in The Bay.

Check out DEF's interview with Derek at www.defsf.com/people/rhythmist

Plus... sets from Integrated's DJ STML and Disconnect.

Tune in at :

http://radio.defsf.com:1200/

Every Friday from 9pm - 1am Pacific Time

Contact : radiointegrated@gmail.com  www.myspace.com/radiointegrated

For updates on DEF and San Francisco Bay Area techno
news and info, sign up for the DEF list at
def-announce-subscribe@defsf.com

For Radio Integrated updates:
radio-integrated-subscribe@defsf.com


///Radio Integrated :: radiointegrated@gmail.com ::
http://radio.defsf.com:1200/  ::
Broadcasting live from Bliss Factory Studios, Alameda, CA///

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: Sat.May.3rd [KONTROL] w/ Alex Under (live) + Agaric (live)

------=_Part_2067_26005879.1209167371395
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Disposition: inline

If you like it on the harder tip, you're gonna dig this one!

___________________________________________________



Saturday, May 3rd, 2008

[ K O N T R O L ]

minimal techno + avant house
every 1st Saturday at The Endup


featuring from Madrid, Spain:

ALEX UNDER   ** 2 hour live PA **

Plus 8 . Trapez . CMYK Musik . Apnea

The last time Alex Under played for us, his intense aural onslaught
had the Endup crowd going absolutely mental, and prompted
resident Alland Byallo to name it in an online interview as the best
live PA he's ever seen.  We are therefore supremely excited to
welcome this talented young producer and label owner back for
another sweat-soaked dancefloor pummeling before he heads to
Detroit for a headlining set at this year's DEMF.


and from Stockholm, Sweden:

AGARIC aka PATRIK SKOOG  ** 2 hour live PA **

We Are . Leibe*Detail . Drumcode . Syndikaat

Patrik Skoog began producing in the 90's, originally focusing on
a harder techno sound which brought him global notoriety.
These days he goes by Agaric, an alias with which he delves into
the slower, deeper realms of techno and house.  With over a
decade of production experience and more than 100 vinyl
releases to his name, his extended live performance is sure to
excite chin-strokers and rug-cutters alike.


plus special guest:

MYLES EGNER   ( s.w.a.t . platform . tweekin' )

with resident DJs:

NIKOLA BAYTALA   ( robsoul . junior boys own . s.w.a.t. )
SAMMY D   ( classic . dirtybird . utensil )
CRAIG KUNA   ( platform . esdjco )

____________________________________________________

The ENDUP
401 6th St @ Harrison, SF
10pm - 8am / 21+ / $15
http://www.theendup.com

FREE until 11pm!

____________________________________________________

Full bios, pics and lots FREE music:
http://www.kontrolsf.com

[KONTROL] on MySpace:
http://www.myspace.com/kontrolsf

Flyer front:
http://www.kontrolsf.com/K35/K35F.jpg

Flyer back:
http://www.kontrolsf.com/K35/K35B.jpg

Poster:
http://www.kontrolsf.com/K35/K35P.jpg

____________________________________________________


ALEX UNDER  (aka Friendly People, Musica Charlista)

The deepest meaning of 'collage', defined by Max Ernst, is the general
application of Arthur Rimabaud's 'delirium': "I accustomed myself to simple
hallucination; I saw quite deliberately a mosque instead of a factory, a
drummer's school conducted by angels, carriages on the highways of the sky,
a salon at the bottom of a lake: monsters, mysteries, a vaudeville poster
raising horrors before my eyes."  We could describe collage as an alchemic
compound of two or more heterogeneous elements, derivate by their unexpecte=
d
approximation generated deliberately by the search of systematic confusion
and distorted perception.

That's Alex Under's musical universe. Based in Madrid, this producer is the
'CMYK' label manager. He is also one of the men behind 'Apnea' and
'Bemysheep', and one of the founders of Net28 (the network behind these
labels and others like 'CyclicalTracks' and 'Pulpa'). Alex Under confirmed
himself as the new reality of the best international techno, sometimes bein=
g
minimal and deep, sometimes hard and aggressive, but always original. He
creates a sonic collage combining techno, trance and house elements while h=
e
constructs complex rhythms that arise from the dancefloor, taking the
listeners to a higher level where emotions, depth, mind & body blend in a
unique equation. Alex Under will intrigue beyond your perception.


=3D=3D> LINKS:

Alex Under's website:
http://www.cmykmusik.com/

Alex Under's discography:
http://www.discogs.com/artist/Alex%20Under

CMYK on MySpace:
http://www.myspace.com/cmykmusik


=3D=3D> MUSIC:

http://mp3.juno.co.uk/MP3/SF209389-01-01-01.mp3

Friendly People - 99.9  (Apnea)
http://mp3.juno.co.uk/MP3/SF245690-01-02-02.mp3

https://www.beatport.com/en-US/html/content/artist/detail/8484/alex_under


=3D=3D> VIDEO:

Alex Under - Live @ [KONTROL], March 3, 2007
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3Du0F2v-xU7M4


____________________________________________________


AGARIC  (aka Patrik Skoog, Headroom)

After working together with Niklas Ehrlin and Henrik Larsson on their main
and well known project in the 90's, Headroom, Patrik Skoog began a solo
project, darker and more tribal-techno influenced in comparison to the
collaborations.  After releasing the first output on German and American
labels, he then decided to set up Native Diffusion records for these type o=
f
tracks.  This focused mainly on Patrik's own productions, but also showcase=
d
remixes from the likes of Damon Wild, W.J. Henze, Inigo Kennedy, Slobodan,
Takaaki Itoh & Hardcell. As of 2003 and 2004 other talent started to appear
on the label as well, respected producers and newcomers to the techno scene
alike.  2004 also saw Headroom=B4s debut release on the classic New York-la=
bel
Synewave getting licensed to the "Exhibitionist" CD and DVD compilation,
compiled and mixed by world renowned DJ Jeff Mills, and as the popularity o=
f
their style of techno increased over the last years, remix offers also
dropped in frequently. Patrik did one for fellow Swede Adam Beyer on his no=
w
classic Drumcode imprint, which shortly thereafter lead to more releases on
Drumcode, and its sublabel Truesoul.

Being a technical DJ with great sense for momentum and track selection,
Skoog has played and continues to play praised gigs in the US, UK, North-
and South America and all across Europe. In early 2005 a new project was
found in "Agaric" where he explores the slower, deeper realms of techno and
house and with productions on his well-received label project named "We
Are". As Agaric, Patrik has gained appreciation from high-ranking peers, an=
d
fans have seen a big change in performances as well as track work, where he
evolves further and further away from playing the typical "hard" sound for
which he was known, and more often than not performs a deeper variety of
tracks that hints at a modern take on early influences like Robert Hood,
Wolfgang Voigt. and Plastikman, still with high intensity and groove. In
2006, the Native Diffusion label was put on ice, ending after six years at
number 19 in the series, and Patrik started to perform live acts all over
the world with the Agaric project--premiering at one of the leading
festivals for innovative electronic music in the Nordic countries, Public
Service.

In 2007, nearly a decade after his debut on the Loop label and over one
hundred vinyl releases later, Agaric relocated to and got involved in the
ever-evolving electronic music scene in Berlin, Germany, where he now
resides.  His highly-anticipated appearance at [KONTROL] will be one of onl=
y
a handfull of North American performances, including stops in NYC, LA,
Chicago and Detroit.


=3D=3D> LINKS:

Agaric on MySpace:
http://www.myspace.com/djagaric

Agaric's Discography:
http://www.discogs.com/artist/Agaric%20(2)

We Are Records Website:
http://www.wearerecords.se/


=3D=3D> MUSIC:

Patrick Skoog - recent live PA broadcast on Hardsignal Radio:
http://wrhaw.com/audio/Hardsignal/Hardsignal_Radio_-_Ep003_-_Apr_2008.mp3


=3D=3D> VIDEO:

Agaric - Live PA in Austin, Texas - 2006
http://youtube.com/watch?v=3DGvF7ZJJQRRc


____________________________________________________


MYLES EGNER

Myles Egner grew up in a small town in Iowa and was turned on to the "futur=
e
house sound of Chicago" at a young age.  By age 14 he started mixing with
his brother DJ Rin, playing deep house and ghetto house while attending
warehouse parties in Chicago on the weekends and being influenced by people
like Gene Farris, Paul Johnson, DJ Traxx, and  DJ Funk.

After moving to SF in '94, Myles linked up with S.W.A.T. (Nikola Baytala,
Kwai le Chief, and DJ Rasoul), sat in on studio sessions whenever there was
an empty seat, and soon found himself a resident at their long-running
Friday night weekly at SF's legendary house club The Top.  Over the years
Myles has moved away from and returned to SF several times, working in four
different record stores along the way: Housewares (SF), Aaron's Records and
Beat Non Stop (LA), and most recently Tweekin' Records (SF). His many hours
logged in these shops gave him the opportunity to soak in boundless
influences and of course pick up an arsenal of heaters, from house to
minimal to hard techno.  His uncontested skills behind the decks have lande=
d
him gigs alongside talent including Kenny Larkin, Octave One, Boo Williams,
K. Alexi, Christian Bloch, JPLS, and more.

Myles is currently making a mark on the Bay Area techno scene as a resident
at Platform, Bureau, and Wish, where he can always be counted on to bring a
unique style of "beating the box".  Be it house, minimal, or banging techno=
,
this talented young man is surely one to look out for.


=3D=3D> LINKS:

Myles Egner on MySpace:
http://www.myspace.com/mylesegner1


=3D=3D> MUSIC:

Myles Egner - Gilbert Street (160kbs mp3 - 65mins)
http://www.kontrolsf.com/AUD/Myles%20Egner%20-%20Gilbert%20Street%20-%20160=
.mp3


____________________________________________________

http://www.kontrolsf.com

         Babe, my trusty big blue 1984 biodiesel beast of a Suburban is for  
sale.   
 
She runs well, can fit 5 people plus gear easily, and has room  
for  a queen size futon in the back, making her an ideal vehicle for  
festivals or hauling stuff around.  She gets between 15-20 mi/gallon.  
While she has a few cosmetic blemishes and quirks, she is a pleasure to  
drive and always brings a smile to my face.  I will be sad to see her  
go, so would love to keep her in the family and to someone committed to  
using bio.  Asking $2000. 
 
Please feel free to contact me if you would like to see her or have  
questions. 
 
Cory

Long as we're talking personal preferences here... Jeff Harrington's
album "Obliterature" makes me feel pretty damn loopy. (Funny thing is,
that album is ambient electronic so this post might actually qualify as
rave-related.) 

It's not really scary like Gibby Haynes circa 1982... but it leaves you
feeling like you went around too many times on the merry-go-round if you
know what I mean...

http://www.harrington.lunarpages.com/mp3/obliterature/

-D

Subject: [sfraves] bsp: Archaeopteryx - creating music with code - video presentation 4 programmers

I went to New York on Saturday and did a presentation for programmers
about my laptop-set system Archaeopteryx. It comes very much from the
programmer point of view, not the DJ/producer point of view.

There's a very short video where I demo live-coding drum and bass:

http://vimeo.com/947877

and a very long video of the presentation:

http://gilesbowkett.blogspot.com/2008/04/video-of-my-goruco-presentation-on.html

Subject: [sfraves] WR: Family, Fanu, & Cheese

So in the afternoon/ early evening, hungout w/ Family & had some dinner &
played alota ummmm.. Rock Band... well.. i sang for songs & like yeah.. i
didn't know i could sing them high octaves like that.. Hello 2day

Then I got over to Il Pirata for the Active Mindz shindig, they brought
out Fanu, this Mondo Yummy Jungle Producer/ DJ from Holland (1st time out
in Cali like ever) & it was pretty sick!!!  i mean.. I'll be honest, it
was another mainly all raga night & it was Dope.. i got my Groovy on as
much as poxxible, but it's hard for me to dance to raga jungle...

I mean... it was a fuckin' Groovy Hyphy ass vibe on Saturday night.. so
like I mean... fuck man... it was just good energy, balls to wall, hella
hype... everyone was hella dancing @ some point, but the dance floor was
just poundin' the whole night... when Fanu got on.... it weas sick.. i
mean.. the music went from this evil hard jungle from robin weber to like
this atmo raga spacey kinda hippy jungle from War Breakerz to like strait
hard ass raga and hip hop and breaks from SillyKid... then Fanu went on &
all hell broke loose.. I mean... he spun like diufferent sub genres of
like Raga, but every so often he dropped this like hellla fucky yummy
electro tech tune here & there & i just lost it man... & the il pirata
dance floor well... it's not that big, but it was like hella packed & I
danced soooo hard like in sections it got so hot!

Afterwards Audio1 & some other homies & i ate like @ Sparky's b4 goin' to
the "after party".... lol.. YUM... Bacon @ 3AM is just so yum!!!  A Bacon
Burger @ 3AM is double yum!!!  Hello 2day!!  Then Audio1 dropped me off @
WarBreakerz pad, but there wasn't an afterparty unfortunately.. so I kinda
just kicked it there 'til 6 something before 6:30 AM & caught Muni... liek
1 watch the ending 1/2 of BIG & the beginning 1/2 of Truman Show, then
took off :)

OK.. on Muni, like there was this homeless dude who like preaching the
word of Satan which kiiiiinda freaked me out 'cause I've been kinda
meeting all these Satan Worshipers, so Homeless Satan worshipper man
freaked me out that i did whatever i could to make my ipod louder...

When i finally got to the bart station, I kinda got into this conversation
with some guy who was Yoyoing... long story short short, after we found
out that we knew some of the same people, him & I actually did cross paths
@ Phoenix a few weeks ago & he couldn't stop talkin' about it & it was
kinda refreshing to see this random guy talk about something like I mean..
h e was still after glowin' high from Phoenix still & YAAAAY!!!

OK.. yeah... so it was a good time from start to fini!!  I hope y'all had
a Groovy night!!!  OK.. gotta finish watching Gossip Girl!!!  Love U
Ravers!!!
-- 
Take Care <3
Peace=->Jus' Me =-> ObY {8O)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] bsp: Archaeopteryx - creating music with code - video presentation 4 programmers

On Mon, Apr 28, 2008 at 9:09 PM, George Cochrane
<newstylesound@yahoo.com> wrote:
> Wow, that's neat- I'd like a little explanation of what was being effected when you
> changed that parameter around (I understood the "rand" thing but not the decimal'd number).

Sure. The braces around the parameter and the L make it an executable
code block which gets passed around like an object. It has to evaluate
to a number between 0 and 1. That number represents a measure of
probability for each. The beat results when you send that code block
against a probability matrix, which maps each beat of each drum to a
measure of probability. So if you give the code block an actual
number, it'll filter through the probability matrix the same way every
time, resulting in a pre-sequenced beat, whereas if you give it rand -
or any code which evaluates dynamically to non-pre-determined values
between 0 and 1 -then it dynamically generates an entirely new beat
every time the code runs. (Usually every measure, every second
measure, or every fourth measure.) The probability matrix is a
meta-sequence rather than a sequence.

More simply, the code block is a fader, where 0.0 is the bottom of the
fader, 1.0 is the top of the fader, and rand is code that positions
the fader randomly somewhere between the top and the bottom. And
instead of controlling just the volume of two tracks, you're
controlling every drum in the rhythm, and of course if you want any
arbitrary pattern of fader movement - whether a repeating pattern or a
chaotic one based on nonlinear fluid dynamics - then you can have that
too. Currently it only modulates on and off for each drum, but
modulating volume is doable, and will probably happen further down the
line.

I also forgot to mention. Last week Andy W brought up the twin
questions of showmanship and user interface. The long video contains
my answers. My answer in e-mail was "muahahaha soon my robot minions
will conquer all" or something along those lines. This was not due to
random insanity. Or at least it was not *just* due to random insanity.
It was also due to the fact that I already had an answer but it takes
a lot of time to explain. And it takes even more time to make it sound
like it is in fact possible. But it is. So in the video, I explain it.
But it's a long answer. The short answer: a combination of ill science
fiction shit and Make magazine. Build drums which trigger psychedelic
video software, collect a timestamp every time somebody hits a drum,
and throw statistical AI (machine learning) at the timestamps once you
have a volume of data sufficiently large to draw conclusions from
(which in a good party should happen reasonably quickly). Use code
flexible enough that you can then choose to use that data any way you
wish. Leverage user-generated content and let the audience supply its
**own** showmanship - which back in the days before the evolution of
superstar DJs was how things were always supposed to be anyway - and
in the process collect exact information about which beats they're
responding to, and when. That's the answer for showmanship. User
interface is code, and anything else you need. The reason the answer
for showmanship is such a good answer is that it allows the answer for
user interface to be **only** about user interface.

Also, to prevent superstar DJ syndrome, which I consider a serious
toxin, you put video screens in the back which supply a feed of the
code and real-time video of the DJ. So if all you want to do is geek
out and watch a dude twist knobs, you can chill in the back and do
that while the crazy people are wigging out like they're supposed to.
(I have a kind of fundamentalist old-school attitude here. DJ worship
is the mind-killer.) The zone in the back would be some hybrid of a
chill room and an Amsterdam cafe, since the crowd that likes to geek
out would probably be into having the music quieter so they could geek
out together - you know, discussing what they see, kicking ideas
around, not just standing there staring like a pack of fucking
zombies. Trainspotters freak me out, man. You totally expect them to
be like "BRRRRAAAAINNSSSSS."

Anyway, lots of work to do.

--
Giles Soundwave/Goat Boy/Bowkett
http://www.gilesgoatboy.org/
http://gilesbowkett.blogspot.com (code)

pwns Google for finding new music.

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Is keyword search about to hit its breaking point?

Or maybe search engines need to further refine things for us (and the 
RIAA) by supporting CC only types of searches.  Having one person/a 
small group of people (as Giles mentions when he speaks of blogs) be the 
prefilter for what you are made aware of probably isn't the best model.

Although, thinking of it in terms of KZSU it's actually fairly similar, 
albeit with a fairly permeable prefilter.  How THAT works is this:
1. A 1st pass is made of all incoming music, where the true dreck is 
weeded out.  (Which is sort of like the blog prefilter mentioned above. 
Main difference is that the goal is to cast the broadest net over what 
MAY be good music, simply by eliminating the obviously bad music.)
2. 2nd step is that what remains is now available for anyone on staff 
("the collective", as it were) to review.  Most likely one is going to 
have a listen to something before taking the time to review it, just so 
that one can be sure they're not wasting their time on something that 
doesn't appeal to them.
3. From those reviewed CDs, they either go into "rotation", or get filed 
directly into the main music library.

And, in the greater world, KZSU is just one of numerous non-commercial 
radio stations where a similar (although often time not as involved) 
process is taking place.  And from that greater whole we all have a 
chance to discover new music.

I know that there are other non-comms out there who have their own 
blogs (KZSU, as a station, doesn't.)  So if those blogs somehow 
represented the vetting process of each individual station, THEY would 
likely be the best source of information.  Hmmmmm.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] bsp: Archaeopteryx - creating music with code - video presentation 4 programmers

On Tue, Apr 29, 2008 at 7:59 AM, Giles Bowkett <dj.soundwave@gmail.com> wrote:
> On Mon, Apr 28, 2008 at 9:09 PM, George Cochrane
>  <newstylesound@yahoo.com> wrote:
>  > Wow, that's neat- I'd like a little explanation of what was being effected when you
>  > changed that parameter around (I understood the "rand" thing but not the decimal'd number).
>
>  Sure. The braces around the parameter and the L make it an executable
>  code block which gets passed around like an object. It has to evaluate
>  to a number between 0 and 1. That number represents a measure of
>  probability for each. The beat results when you send that code block
>  against a probability matrix, which maps each beat of each drum to a
>  measure of probability. So if you give the code block an actual
>  number, it'll filter through the probability matrix the same way every
>  time, resulting in a pre-sequenced beat, whereas if you give it rand -
>  or any code which evaluates dynamically to non-pre-determined values
>  between 0 and 1 -then it dynamically generates an entirely new beat
>  every time the code runs. (Usually every measure, every second
>  measure, or every fourth measure.) The probability matrix is a
>  meta-sequence rather than a sequence.
>
>  More simply, the code block is a fader, where 0.0 is the bottom of the
>  fader, 1.0 is the top of the fader, and rand is code that positions
>  the fader randomly somewhere between the top and the bottom. And
>  instead of controlling just the volume of two tracks, you're
>  controlling every drum in the rhythm, and of course if you want any
>  arbitrary pattern of fader movement - whether a repeating pattern or a
>  chaotic one based on nonlinear fluid dynamics - then you can have that
>  too. Currently it only modulates on and off for each drum, but
>  modulating volume is doable, and will probably happen further down the
>  line.
>
>  I also forgot to mention. Last week Andy W brought up the twin
>  questions of showmanship and user interface. The long video contains
>  my answers. My answer in e-mail was "muahahaha soon my robot minions
>  will conquer all" or something along those lines. This was not due to
>  random insanity. Or at least it was not *just* due to random insanity.
>  It was also due to the fact that I already had an answer but it takes
>  a lot of time to explain. And it takes even more time to make it sound
>  like it is in fact possible. But it is. So in the video, I explain it.
>  But it's a long answer. The short answer: a combination of ill science
>  fiction shit and Make magazine. Build drums which trigger psychedelic
>  video software, collect a timestamp every time somebody hits a drum,
>  and throw statistical AI (machine learning) at the timestamps once you
>  have a volume of data sufficiently large to draw conclusions from
>  (which in a good party should happen reasonably quickly). Use code
>  flexible enough that you can then choose to use that data any way you
>  wish. Leverage user-generated content and let the audience supply its
>  **own** showmanship - which back in the days before the evolution of
>  superstar DJs was how things were always supposed to be anyway - and
>  in the process collect exact information about which beats they're
>  responding to, and when. That's the answer for showmanship. User
>  interface is code, and anything else you need. The reason the answer
>  for showmanship is such a good answer is that it allows the answer for
>  user interface to be **only** about user interface.
>
>  Also, to prevent superstar DJ syndrome, which I consider a serious
>  toxin, you put video screens in the back which supply a feed of the
>  code and real-time video of the DJ. So if all you want to do is geek
>  out and watch a dude twist knobs, you can chill in the back and do
>  that while the crazy people are wigging out like they're supposed to.
>  (I have a kind of fundamentalist old-school attitude here. DJ worship
>  is the mind-killer.) The zone in the back would be some hybrid of a
>  chill room and an Amsterdam cafe, since the crowd that likes to geek
>  out would probably be into having the music quieter so they could geek
>  out together - you know, discussing what they see, kicking ideas
>  around, not just standing there staring like a pack of fucking
>  zombies. Trainspotters freak me out, man. You totally expect them to
>  be like "BRRRRAAAAINNSSSSS."
>
>  Anyway, lots of work to do.
>
>  --
>
>
> Giles Soundwave/Goat Boy/Bowkett
>  http://www.gilesgoatboy.org/
>  http://gilesbowkett.blogspot.com (code)
>
>  ---------------------------------------------------------------------
>  To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
>  For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org
>
>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Is keyword search about to hit its breaking point?

Blogs are searchable, no?  But I agree that blogs, or rather people's opinions as expressed in blogs, are going to be a big part of it.

Again, I'm not talking about Google as it is, I'm talking about what it should and IMO will be.  

What's coming is full semantic metadata and text search as true well "sounds like" audio search.  Add in search that includes your social network and you have the ultimate music (and many other things!) discovery engine.  

Many things are possible here. For example at Live365 we had the idea of searching based on co-placement in playlists.  Not sure if they ever implemented that idea actually, but some experiments I did showed the power of the idea.  And you can also detect when many people (considered over the domain of a social network) put the same track in their playlists.  Interesting stuff is possible from here.Sure all of this isn't going to happen overnight but it is not very far away either.

I'd have to give you a (rather ridiculous/lengthy) reading list if you want to get deeper into exactly what I am thinking about... 

BTW I tried to watch your presentation last night, but my wireless network kept gagging on it.  I was bout to go get the red emergency cable when my wife said, "I like it better when you listen to music instead of some guy talking"

So I still haven't watched to the end...but now I am at work where we have a screamingly fast Opti-man connection.

However at the risk of asking a really clueless question about your stuff, it seems you are implementing a sort of Markov process for generating music implemented using continuations?  Also is the probability matrix is static/unchanging?  Ok, I guess I should just watch the video..

Regards,

Peter

----- Original Message ----
From: Giles Bowkett <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>

> Related to the nerdly discussion of search and new economic models for music last week....
>
>  http://www.techcrunch.com/2008/04/25/is-keyword-search-about-to-hit-its-breaking-point/

Yeah but I don't think search really has much to do with music
business models. The Yahoo music guy, who used to run a label and do
Web design for the Beastie Boys, says bands are telling him it's all
about the blogs:

http://www.fistfulayen.com/blog/?p=198

And personally I get all my new mix MP3s from BijouBreaks.com or
http://mnmltechno.blogspot.com/ or Myspace or somewhere like this.
Social networking (blogs, podcasts, message boards, mailing lists)
pwns Google for finding new music.

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Tue, Apr 29, 2008 at 11:35 AM
Subject: Sad news about an RS (rhythm society) Friend


Dear Friends,

It is with a heavy heart that I bear sad tidings to the community: RS
Friend Eric Tiedemann has died.

There has been no word yet, that I have heard, regarding cause of
death; to the best of my knowledge, he was found in his home, and an
investigation is ongoing.  More details on that, along with funeral or
memorial arrangements, will be posted as they become known.  I would
respectfully request that, in the meantime, we avoid speculating about
it on the lists.

Like me, Eric was sponsored by Karin Wertheim, and has been a friend
of ours since we all attended an NE-Raves net-party in Rochester, NY,
in 1997.  It was that online electronic dance community that brought
all of us together before we slowly, each in turn, filtered our way
across the country and into the RS.  Back in those days, we used to
call him Dances With Beverages, though my mother always referred to
him as Pajamas Eric, due to his fondness for the comfort of plaid
flannel dance-wear.

Eric was the first person Karin sponsored into the RS, and with me he
was "co-heresiarch" of the RS Peninsula Meditation Group from 2005 to
2006.  He also served on the Tech Team, and co-lead Spiritual
Emergence and the Dance Ceremony for exPeRiEnce, the 2007 RS Retreat,
with Christine Benvenuto. Most recently, he led Bishops Desk for
Magic, and was kind enough to submit a copy of the Bishops Desk Binder
to the wiki so it no longer needs to be re-created for each event.

He was a man of wildly diverse interests: ecstatic dance, the
supremacy of breakbeat as a musical art form, Thelema, Buddhism, NLP,
Robert Anton Wilson, Robert Heinlein, David Deida, Nietzsche, computer
technology, entheogens, quantum theory...pure geekery of every sort,
kind, and manner, on which he could discourse at length, and in depth,
once you got him started.

Though I had lost track of him for a while after he moved from Philly
to Cali, upon reconnecting at Dance, my first ANDC in Fall'05, our
friendship resumed immediately as if the lacuna had never occurred. He
was that kind of guy; my confidant, my mentor.  Eric was a true
friend, one of those without whose generous assistance on numerous
levels I could never have taken root here.  He was my biggest fan,
encouraging and facilitating my DJing even when I thought I'd put that
well behind me.  His presence will be dearly missed, and his physical
absence keenly and palpably felt.

Eric, I miss you; I love you.

Eric S. Tiedemann, 1966-2008
http://est.livejournal.com/
http://hyperreal.org/~est/

"Unto them from whose eyes the veil of life hath fallen may there be
granted the accomplishment of their true Wills; whether they will
absorption in the Infinite, or to be united with their chosen and
preferred, or to be in contemplation, or to be at peace, or to achieve
the labour and heroism of incarnation on this planet or another, or in
any Star, or aught else, unto them may there be granted the
accomplishment of their wills; yea, the accomplishment of their
wills." -Liber XV, Ecclesi=C3=A6 Gnostic=C3=A6 Catholic=C3=A6 Canon Miss=C3=
=A6

Subject: [sfraves] tuesday techno mix

http://www.bodytonicmusic.com/audio/mixes/btp007_roberthood.mp3

Robert Hood is without any question one of the most important founding  
fathers of minimalism within techno. In the early nineties he helped  
launch a couple of the most influential techno labels ever:  
Underground Resistance, Axis and M-Plant. He learned the ropes from  
nobody less than Mike Banks and Jeff Mills. It didn't take long for  
Hood to set out on his own course and he made independence his  
strength. With his own label M-Plant and sublabels Drama, Duet and  
Hardwax he left an ineradicable stamp on the evolution of the techno  
sound. After carrying out his operations mainly from the shadows for  
many years Robert Hood has been on a head-on assault in the last  
couple of months. The Detroit legend has intensified his schedule of  
appearances all over the world, especially in Europe.

Robert Hood makes minimal Detroit techno with an emphasis on soul and  
experimentation over flash and popularity. Having recorded for  
Metroplex, as well as the Austrian Cheap label and Jeff Mills' Axis  
label, Hood also owns and operates the M-Plant imprint, through which  
he's released the bulk of his solo material. Hood was a founding  
member, along with Jeff Mills and Mike Banks, of the Underground  
Resistance label, whose influential releases throughout the early and  
mid '90s helped change the face of modern Detroit techno and sparked a  
creative renaissance. Infusing elements of acid and industrial into a  
potent blend of Chicago house and Detroit techno, UR's aesthetic  
project and militant business philosophy were (and remain) singular  
commitments in underground techno. Hood left Detroit (and UR) with  
Jeff Mills in 1992, setting up shop in New York and recording a series  
of 12-inch EPs . Through the mid '90s, Hood has focused on his solo  
work, setting up M-Plant in 1994 and releasing singles such as  
'Internal Empire,' 'Music Data,' and 'Moveable Parts.' Although his  
desire to remain underground has been replaced by an urge to reach a  
wider audience, Hood remains fiercely critical of artistic and  
economic movements destructive to inner-city communities and has  
combined his musical enterprises with outreach and social activist  
ends. His debut Peacefrog album 'Point Blank' took Hood's hypnotic  
minimalism to entirely new depths and territories, whilst his latest  
album 'Wire To Wire' takes his productions onto new levels of  
musicality and sophistication within the world of electronic music.

Currently enjoying something of a renaissance having just released a  
corker of a mix for Fabric as well as series of singles for Music Man,  
this mix features Hood under his Grey Area guise - an alias he uses to  
showcase his own productions and remixes and his labels catalogue from  
M-Plant, Duet, Drama, Hardwax.

This mix was recorded recently at the legendary FUSE club in Belgium.  
Thanks to Oliver at EPM for making this happen...and enjoy!

Saturday, May 3rd, 2008

[ K O N T R O L ]

minimal techno + avant house
every 1st Saturday at The Endup


featuring from Madrid, Spain:

ALEX UNDER   ** 2 hour live PA **

Plus 8 . Trapez . CMYK Musik . Apnea

The last time Alex Under played for us, his intense aural onslaught
had the Endup crowd going absolutely mental, and prompted
resident Alland Byallo to name it in an online interview as the best
live PA he's ever seen.  We are therefore supremely excited to
welcome this talented young producer and label owner back for
another sweat-soaked dancefloor pummeling before he heads to
Detroit for a headlining set at this year's DEMF.


and from Stockholm, Sweden:

AGARIC aka Patrik Skoog  ** 2 hour live PA **

We Are . Leibe*Detail . Drumcode . Syndikaat

Patrik Skoog began producing in the 90's, originally focusing on
a harder techno sound which brought him global notoriety.
These days he goes by Agaric, an alias with which he delves into
the slower, deeper realms of techno and house.  With over a
decade of production experience and more than 100 vinyl
releases to his name, his extended live performance is sure to
excite chin-strokers and rug-cutters alike.


plus special guest:

MYLES EGNER   ( s.w.a.t . platform . tweekin' )

with resident DJs:

NIKOLA BAYTALA   ( robsoul . junior boys own . s.w.a.t. )
SAMMY D   ( classic . dirtybird . utensil )
CRAIG KUNA   ( platform . esdjco )

____________________________________________________

The ENDUP
401 6th St @ Harrison, SF
10pm - 8am / 21+ / $15
http://www.theendup.com

FREE until 11pm!

____________________________________________________

Full bios, pics and lots FREE music:
http://www.kontrolsf.com

[KONTROL] on MySpace:
http://www.myspace.com/kontrolsf

http://www.kontrolsf.com/K35/K35F.jpg

Flyer back:
http://www.kontrolsf.com/K35/K35B.jpg

Poster:
http://www.kontrolsf.com/K35/K35P.jpg

____________________________________________________


ALEX UNDER  (aka Friendly People, Musica Charlista)

The deepest meaning of 'collage', defined by Max Ernst, is the general
application of Arthur Rimabaud's 'delirium': "I accustomed myself to simple
hallucination; I saw quite deliberately a mosque instead of a factory, a
drummer's school conducted by angels, carriages on the highways of the sky,
a salon at the bottom of a lake: monsters, mysteries, a vaudeville poster
raising horrors before my eyes."  We could describe collage as an alchemic
compound of two or more heterogeneous elements, derivate by their unexpecte=
d
approximation generated deliberately by the search of systematic confusion
and distorted perception.

That's Alex Under's musical universe. Based in Madrid, this producer is the
'CMYK' label manager. He is also one of the men behind 'Apnea' and
'Bemysheep', and one of the founders of Net28 (the network behind these
labels and others like 'CyclicalTracks' and 'Pulpa'). Alex Under confirmed
himself as the new reality of the best international techno, sometimes bein=
g
minimal and deep, sometimes hard and aggressive, but always original. He
creates a sonic collage combining techno, trance and house elements while h=
e
constructs complex rhythms that arise from the dancefloor, taking the
listeners to a higher level where emotions, depth, mind & body blend in a
unique equation. Alex Under will intrigue beyond your perception.


=3D=3D> LINKS:

Alex Under's website:
http://www.cmykmusik.com/

Alex Under's discography:
http://www.discogs.com/artist/Alex%20Under

CMYK on MySpace:
http://www.myspace.com/cmykmusik


=3D=3D> MUSIC:

Alex Under - El Encuentro  (Plus 8)
http://mp3.juno.co.uk/MP3/SF209389-01-01-01.mp3

Friendly People - 99.9  (Apnea)
http://mp3.juno.co.uk/MP3/SF245690-01-02-02.mp3

Alex Under music samples on BeatPort:
https://www.beatport.com/en-US/html/content/artist/detail/8484/alex_under


=3D=3D> VIDEO:

Alex Under - Live @ [KONTROL], March 3, 2007
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3Du0F2v-xU7M4


____________________________________________________


AGARIC  (aka Patrik Skoog, Headroom)

After working together with Niklas Ehrlin and Henrik Larsson on their main
and well known project in the 90's, Headroom, Patrik Skoog began a solo
project, darker and more tribal-techno influenced in comparison to the
collaborations.  After releasing the first output on German and American
labels, he then decided to set up Native Diffusion records for these type o=
f
tracks.  This focused mainly on Patrik's own productions, but also showcase=
d
remixes from the likes of Damon Wild, W.J. Henze, Inigo Kennedy, Slobodan,
Takaaki Itoh & Hardcell. As of 2003 and 2004 other talent started to appear
on the label as well, respected producers and newcomers to the techno scene
alike.  2004 also saw Headroom=B4s debut release on the classic New York-la=
bel
Synewave getting licensed to the "Exhibitionist" CD and DVD compilation,
compiled and mixed by world renowned DJ Jeff Mills, and as the popularity o=
f
their style of techno increased over the last years, remix offers also
dropped in frequently. Patrik did one for fellow Swede Adam Beyer on his no=
w
classic Drumcode imprint, which shortly thereafter lead to more releases on
Drumcode, and its sublabel Truesoul.

Being a technical DJ with great sense for momentum and track selection,
Skoog has played and continues to play praised gigs in the US, UK, North-
and South America and all across Europe. In early 2005 a new project was
found in "Agaric" where he explores the slower, deeper realms of techno and
house and with productions on his well-received label project named "We
Are". As Agaric, Patrik has gained appreciation from high-ranking peers, an=
d
fans have seen a big change in performances as well as track work, where he
evolves further and further away from playing the typical "hard" sound for
which he was known, and more often than not performs a deeper variety of
tracks that hints at a modern take on early influences like Robert Hood,
Wolfgang Voigt. and Plastikman, still with high intensity and groove. In
2006, the Native Diffusion label was put on ice, ending after six years at
number 19 in the series, and Patrik started to perform live acts all over
the world with the Agaric project--premiering at one of the leading
festivals for innovative electronic music in the Nordic countries, Public
Service.

In 2007, nearly a decade after his debut on the Loop label and over one
hundred vinyl releases later, Agaric relocated to and got involved in the
ever-evolving electronic music scene in Berlin, Germany, where he now
resides.  His highly-anticipated appearance at [KONTROL] will be one of onl=
y
a handfull of North American performances, including stops in NYC, LA,
Chicago and Detroit.


=3D=3D> LINKS:

Agaric on MySpace:
http://www.myspace.com/djagaric

Agaric's Discography:
http://www.discogs.com/artist/Agaric%20(2)

We Are Records Website:
http://www.wearerecords.se/


=3D=3D> MUSIC:

Patrick Skoog - recent live PA broadcast on Hardsignal Radio:
http://wrhaw.com/audio/Hardsignal/Hardsignal_Radio_-_Ep003_-_Apr_2008.mp3


=3D=3D> VIDEO:

Agaric - Live PA in Austin, Texas - 2006
http://youtube.com/watch?v=3DGvF7ZJJQRRc


____________________________________________________


MYLES EGNER

Myles Egner grew up in a small town in Iowa and was turned on to the "futur=
e
house sound of Chicago" at a young age.  By age 14 he started mixing with
his brother DJ Rin, playing deep house and ghetto house while attending
warehouse parties in Chicago on the weekends and being influenced by people
like Gene Farris, Paul Johnson, DJ Traxx, and  DJ Funk.

After moving to SF in '94, Myles linked up with S.W.A.T. (Nikola Baytala,
Kwai le Chief, and DJ Rasoul), sat in on studio sessions whenever there was
an empty seat, and soon found himself a resident at their long-running
Friday night weekly at SF's legendary house club The Top.  Over the years
Myles has moved away from and returned to SF several times, working in four
different record stores along the way: Housewares (SF), Aaron's Records and
Beat Non Stop (LA), and most recently Tweekin' Records (SF). His many hours
logged in these shops gave him the opportunity to soak in boundless
influences and of course pick up an arsenal of heaters, from house to
minimal to hard techno.  His uncontested skills behind the decks have lande=
d
him gigs alongside talent including Kenny Larkin, Octave One, Boo Williams,
K. Alexi, Christian Bloch, JPLS, and more.

Myles is currently making a mark on the Bay Area techno scene as a resident
at Platform, Bureau, and Wish, where he can always be counted on to bring a
unique style of "beating the box".  Be it house, minimal, or banging techno=
,
this talented young man is surely one to look out for.


=3D=3D> LINKS:

Myles Egner on MySpace:
http://www.myspace.com/mylesegner1


=3D=3D> MUSIC:

Myles Egner - Gilbert Street (160kbs mp3 - 65mins)
http://www.kontrolsf.com/AUD/Myles%20Egner%20-%20Gilbert%20Street%20-%20160=
.mp3

http://www.kontrolsf.com

On Apr 29, 2008, at 20:36, "Greg Bird" <bird415@gmail.com> wrote:

> Saturday, May 3rd, 2008
>
> [ K O N T R O L ]
>
> minimal techno + avant house
> every 1st Saturday at The Endup
>
>
> featuring from Madrid, Spain:
>
> ALEX UNDER   ** 2 hour live PA **
>
> Plus 8 . Trapez . CMYK Musik . Apnea
>
> The last time Alex Under played for us, his intense aural onslaught
> had the Endup crowd going absolutely mental, and prompted
> resident Alland Byallo to name it in an online interview as the best
> live PA he's ever seen.  We are therefore supremely excited to
> welcome this talented young producer and label owner back for
> another sweat-soaked dancefloor pummeling before he heads to
> Detroit for a headlining set at this year's DEMF.
>
>
> and from Stockholm, Sweden:
>
> AGARIC aka Patrik Skoog  ** 2 hour live PA **
>
> We Are . Leibe*Detail . Drumcode . Syndikaat
>
> Patrik Skoog began producing in the 90's, originally focusing on
> a harder techno sound which brought him global notoriety.
> These days he goes by Agaric, an alias with which he delves into
> the slower, deeper realms of techno and house.  With over a
> decade of production experience and more than 100 vinyl
> releases to his name, his extended live performance is sure to
> excite chin-strokers and rug-cutters alike.
>
>
> plus special guest:
>
> MYLES EGNER   ( s.w.a.t . platform . tweekin' )

> SAMMY D   ( classic . dirtybird . utensil )

>
>
> ALEX UNDER  (aka Friendly People, Musica Charlista)
>
> The deepest meaning of 'collage', defined by Max Ernst, is the general
> application of Arthur Rimabaud's 'delirium': "I accustomed myself to =20=

> simple
> hallucination; I saw quite deliberately a mosque instead of a =20
> factory, a
> drummer's school conducted by angels, carriages on the highways of =20
> the sky,
> a salon at the bottom of a lake: monsters, mysteries, a vaudeville =20
> poster
> raising horrors before my eyes."  We could describe collage as an =20
> alchemic
> compound of two or more heterogeneous elements, derivate by their =20
> unexpected
> approximation generated deliberately by the search of systematic =20
> confusion
> and distorted perception.
>
> That's Alex Under's musical universe. Based in Madrid, this producer =20=

> is the
> 'CMYK' label manager. He is also one of the men behind 'Apnea' and
> 'Bemysheep', and one of the founders of Net28 (the network behind =20
> these
> labels and others like 'CyclicalTracks' and 'Pulpa'). Alex Under =20
> confirmed
> himself as the new reality of the best international techno, =20
> sometimes being
> minimal and deep, sometimes hard and aggressive, but always =20
> original. He
> creates a sonic collage combining techno, trance and house elements =20=

> while he
> constructs complex rhythms that arise from the dancefloor, taking the
> listeners to a higher level where emotions, depth, mind & body blend =20=

> in a
> unique equation. Alex Under will intrigue beyond your perception.
>
>
> =3D=3D> LINKS:
>
> Alex Under's website:
> http://www.cmykmusik.com/
>
> Alex Under's discography:
> http://www.discogs.com/artist/Alex%20Under
>
> CMYK on MySpace:
> http://www.myspace.com/cmykmusik

> http://mp3.juno.co.uk/MP3/SF245690-01-02-02.mp3

> ____________________________________________________
>
>
> AGARIC  (aka Patrik Skoog, Headroom)
>
> After working together with Niklas Ehrlin and Henrik Larsson on =20
> their main
> and well known project in the 90's, Headroom, Patrik Skoog began a =20
> solo
> project, darker and more tribal-techno influenced in comparison to the
> collaborations.  After releasing the first output on German and =20
> American
> labels, he then decided to set up Native Diffusion records for these =20=

> type of
> tracks.  This focused mainly on Patrik's own productions, but also =20
> showcased
> remixes from the likes of Damon Wild, W.J. Henze, Inigo Kennedy, =20
> Slobodan,
> Takaaki Itoh & Hardcell. As of 2003 and 2004 other talent started to =20=

> appear
> on the label as well, respected producers and newcomers to the =20
> techno scene
> alike.  2004 also saw Headroom=C2=B4s debut release on the classic New =
Yo=20
> rk-label
> Synewave getting licensed to the "Exhibitionist" CD and DVD =20
> compilation,
> compiled and mixed by world renowned DJ Jeff Mills, and as the =20
> popularity of
> their style of techno increased over the last years, remix offers also
> dropped in frequently. Patrik did one for fellow Swede Adam Beyer on =20=

> his now
> classic Drumcode imprint, which shortly thereafter lead to more =20
> releases on
> Drumcode, and its sublabel Truesoul.
>
> Being a technical DJ with great sense for momentum and track =20
> selection,
> Skoog has played and continues to play praised gigs in the US, UK, =20
> North-
> and South America and all across Europe. In early 2005 a new project =20=

> was
> found in "Agaric" where he explores the slower, deeper realms of =20
> techno and
> house and with productions on his well-received label project named =20=

> "We
> Are". As Agaric, Patrik has gained appreciation from high-ranking =20
> peers, and
> fans have seen a big change in performances as well as track work, =20
> where he
> evolves further and further away from playing the typical "hard" =20
> sound for
> which he was known, and more often than not performs a deeper =20
> variety of
> tracks that hints at a modern take on early influences like Robert =20
> Hood,
> Wolfgang Voigt. and Plastikman, still with high intensity and =20
> groove. In
> 2006, the Native Diffusion label was put on ice, ending after six =20
> years at
> number 19 in the series, and Patrik started to perform live acts all =20=

> over
> the world with the Agaric project--premiering at one of the leading
> festivals for innovative electronic music in the Nordic countries, =20
> Public
> Service.
>
> In 2007, nearly a decade after his debut on the Loop label and over =20=

> one
> hundred vinyl releases later, Agaric relocated to and got involved =20
> in the
> ever-evolving electronic music scene in Berlin, Germany, where he now
> resides.  His highly-anticipated appearance at [KONTROL] will be one =20=

> of only
> a handfull of North American performances, including stops in NYC, LA,
> Chicago and Detroit.
>
>
> =3D=3D> LINKS:
>
> Agaric on MySpace:
> http://www.myspace.com/djagaric
>

> http://www.discogs.com/artist/Agaric%20(2)
>

> http://www.wearerecords.se/

http://wrhaw.com/audio/Hardsignal/Hardsignal_Radio_-_Ep003_-_Apr_2008.mp3

> ____________________________________________________
>
>
> MYLES EGNER
>
> Myles Egner grew up in a small town in Iowa and was turned on to the =20=

> "future
> house sound of Chicago" at a young age.  By age 14 he started mixing =20=

> with
> his brother DJ Rin, playing deep house and ghetto house while =20
> attending
> warehouse parties in Chicago on the weekends and being influenced by =20=

> people
> like Gene Farris, Paul Johnson, DJ Traxx, and  DJ Funk.
>
> After moving to SF in '94, Myles linked up with S.W.A.T. (Nikola =20
> Baytala,
> Kwai le Chief, and DJ Rasoul), sat in on studio sessions whenever =20
> there was
> an empty seat, and soon found himself a resident at their long-running
> Friday night weekly at SF's legendary house club The Top.  Over the =20=

> years
> Myles has moved away from and returned to SF several times, working =20=

> in four
> different record stores along the way: Housewares (SF), Aaron's =20
> Records and
> Beat Non Stop (LA), and most recently Tweekin' Records (SF). His =20
> many hours
> logged in these shops gave him the opportunity to soak in boundless
> influences and of course pick up an arsenal of heaters, from house to
> minimal to hard techno.  His uncontested skills behind the decks =20
> have landed
> him gigs alongside talent including Kenny Larkin, Octave One, Boo =20
> Williams,
> K. Alexi, Christian Bloch, JPLS, and more.
>
> Myles is currently making a mark on the Bay Area techno scene as a =20
> resident
> at Platform, Bureau, and Wish, where he can always be counted on to =20=

> bring a
> unique style of "beating the box".  Be it house, minimal, or banging =20=

> techno,
> this talented young man is surely one to look out for.
>
>

>

> http://www.myspace.com/mylesegner1

From sfraves-return-146399-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Wed Apr 30 22:44:10 2008
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-146399-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 60903 invoked by uid 1103); 30 Apr 2008 22:44:06 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes

list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 60874 invoked from network); 30 Apr 2008 22:44:05 -0000
Message-ID: <20080430184208.0sbus0qfkc4g08s0@webmail.utoronto.ca>
Date: Wed, 30 Apr 2008 18:42:08 -0400
From:	james.hurlbut@utoronto.ca
To:	sfraves@hyperreal.org
References: <128685.7850.qm@web65403.mail.ac4.yahoo.com>
	<4688f3110804290759k2e120718n1e0eafce31dc6b04@mail.gmail.com>
In-Reply-To: <4688f3110804290759k2e120718n1e0eafce31dc6b04@mail.gmail.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
