	charset=ISO-8859-1;
	DelSp="Yes";
	format="flowed"
Content-Disposition: inline
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8BIT
User-Agent: Internet Messaging Program (IMP) H3 (4.1.6)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] bsp: Archaeopteryx - creating music with code -
	video presentation 4 programmers

If you havent checked it out, I recommend ChucK : Strongly-timed,  
Concurrent, and On-the-fly Audio Programming Language.

I was really impressed with this demo video:
http://youtube.com/watch?v=hFAh-pgxGyc


Quoting Giles Bowkett <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>:

> On Mon, Apr 28, 2008 at 9:09 PM, George Cochrane
> <newstylesound@yahoo.com> wrote:
>> Wow, that's neat- I'd like a little explanation of what was being   
>> effected when you
>> changed that parameter around (I understood the "rand" thing but   
>> not the decimal'd number).
>
> Sure. The braces around the parameter and the L make it an executable
> code block which gets passed around like an object. It has to evaluate
> to a number between 0 and 1. That number represents a measure of
> probability for each. The beat results when you send that code block
> against a probability matrix, which maps each beat of each drum to a
> measure of probability. So if you give the code block an actual
> number, it'll filter through the probability matrix the same way every
> time, resulting in a pre-sequenced beat, whereas if you give it rand -
> or any code which evaluates dynamically to non-pre-determined values
> between 0 and 1 -then it dynamically generates an entirely new beat
> every time the code runs. (Usually every measure, every second
> measure, or every fourth measure.) The probability matrix is a
> meta-sequence rather than a sequence.
>
> More simply, the code block is a fader, where 0.0 is the bottom of the
> fader, 1.0 is the top of the fader, and rand is code that positions
> the fader randomly somewhere between the top and the bottom. And
> instead of controlling just the volume of two tracks, you're
> controlling every drum in the rhythm, and of course if you want any
> arbitrary pattern of fader movement - whether a repeating pattern or a
> chaotic one based on nonlinear fluid dynamics - then you can have that
> too. Currently it only modulates on and off for each drum, but
> modulating volume is doable, and will probably happen further down the
> line.
>
> I also forgot to mention. Last week Andy W brought up the twin
> questions of showmanship and user interface. The long video contains
> my answers. My answer in e-mail was "muahahaha soon my robot minions
> will conquer all" or something along those lines. This was not due to
> random insanity. Or at least it was not *just* due to random insanity.
> It was also due to the fact that I already had an answer but it takes
> a lot of time to explain. And it takes even more time to make it sound
> like it is in fact possible. But it is. So in the video, I explain it.
> But it's a long answer. The short answer: a combination of ill science
> fiction shit and Make magazine. Build drums which trigger psychedelic
> video software, collect a timestamp every time somebody hits a drum,
> and throw statistical AI (machine learning) at the timestamps once you
> have a volume of data sufficiently large to draw conclusions from
> (which in a good party should happen reasonably quickly). Use code
> flexible enough that you can then choose to use that data any way you
> wish. Leverage user-generated content and let the audience supply its
> **own** showmanship - which back in the days before the evolution of
> superstar DJs was how things were always supposed to be anyway - and
> in the process collect exact information about which beats they're
> responding to, and when. That's the answer for showmanship. User
> interface is code, and anything else you need. The reason the answer
> for showmanship is such a good answer is that it allows the answer for
> user interface to be **only** about user interface.
>
> Also, to prevent superstar DJ syndrome, which I consider a serious
> toxin, you put video screens in the back which supply a feed of the
> code and real-time video of the DJ. So if all you want to do is geek
> out and watch a dude twist knobs, you can chill in the back and do
> that while the crazy people are wigging out like they're supposed to.
> (I have a kind of fundamentalist old-school attitude here. DJ worship
> is the mind-killer.) The zone in the back would be some hybrid of a
> chill room and an Amsterdam cafe, since the crowd that likes to geek
> out would probably be into having the music quieter so they could geek
> out together - you know, discussing what they see, kicking ideas
> around, not just standing there staring like a pack of fucking
> zombies. Trainspotters freak me out, man. You totally expect them to
> be like "BRRRRAAAAINNSSSSS."
>
> Anyway, lots of work to do.
>
> --
> Giles Soundwave/Goat Boy/Bowkett
> http://www.gilesgoatboy.org/
> http://gilesbowkett.blogspot.com (code)
>
> ---------------------------------------------------------------------
> To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
> For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org
>
>




---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

 see
> the movie =93A Scanner Darkly,=94 and was like, hey, maybe I should call =
my CD
> =93Substance D,=94 obviously because of Dieselboy/Damian, you know, the D=
 ties
> in. I said it half seriously and put it in the back of my head. As time
> went on I hadn=92t really come up with anything else and the more I thoug=
ht
> about Substance D as a concept, the more I thought I could get some good
> ideas out of that name. Eventually my subconscious decided that was the w=
ay
> to go.
>=20
> DOA:  When and where did you do the mix?
>=20
> D:    I did it at home, in March, just before I went to South Africa.
>=20
> DOA:  How did you conceive the remixes you wanted for SUBSTANCE D?
>=20
> D:    The first thing I had done was that track =93O.D.=94 which Demo pre=
tty
> much wrote specifically for this. SUBSTANCE D is a drug. O.D., or overdos=
e,
> ties in with the idea of too many drugs. I wanted the name to reflect the
> CD. Also, I=92d had some music signed to HUMAN that I=92d intended to put=
 out
> on 12=94 but had some troubles with my distributor and hadn=92t got some =
tracks
> out like I=92d wanted to, like =93Parallel Universe=94 (Infiltrata), =93P=
ressure
> Wounds=94 (Tetradin + Advance), =93Machine March=94 (SPKTRM), and =93Fata=
l=94 (The
> Fix), which should have come out a while ago that I=92d been sitting on t=
hat
> are now out on SUBSTANCE D.
>=20
> Then it was a matter of sitting down again, like I did with =93The
> Dungeonmaster=92s Guide,=94 deciding to remix Sasha, BT, Tiesto, Josh Win=
k. I
> didn=92t want to do a repeat of =93The Dungeonmaster=92s Guide.=94 This t=
ime around
> I thought about getting different genres done, and different artists. I
> really wanted to get remixes of some electro-house, and maybe some old
> industrial.
>=20
> At Shambala, a festival in Canada, Adam Freeland told me he wanted a new
> remix of his breaks tune =93We Want Your Soul.=94 Ed Rush + Optical remix=
ed it
> a few years ago and it was more of a jump-up style and I knew Raiden coul=
d
> put a totally different spin on it, like a techno/d&b style, and the voca=
l
> kind of fits with Raiden=92s style, kind of creepy. I knew he could do
> something special. It=92s really fresh. The kids who like the harder d&b
> really go off on it.
>=20
> I=92d met MSTRKRFT a few times and they said they were fans of d&b, so I
> thought it would be cool to get one of their electro-house tunes remixed.=
 I
> got the Upbeats on board and they chose =93Paris=94 to remix. MSTRKRFT li=
ked
> it.
>=20
> Computer Club, which is Gigantor of Evol Intent doing his electro-house
> project, sent me =93Load Rocket=94 just to get my vibe on it. I was so
> impressed I sent it to System which signed it right off the bat. I=92m re=
ally
> excited with what Gridlok turned in. Computer Club was into it. It gets a
> huge response on the dance floor every time.
>=20
> Last year listening to my old industrial Meat Beat Manifesto CD=92s, I
> thought it would be great to get something by them remixed. Jack Danger
> used lots of interesting samples and breaks. Jack was down with it, so we
> got the samples for =93Helter Skelter=94 for Mayhem and Evol Intent. Meat=
 Beat
> liked it.
>=20
> DOA:  What instructions did you give the remixers?
>=20
> D:    I didn=92t really give specific instructions. With the Meat Beat th=
ing
> I talked to Mayhem and said maybe it would be a good idea if we had the
> track slow down in the middle and go into the original =93Helter Skelter,=
=94
> which it does. With the Upbeats and Gridlok, I just let them do what they
> wanted to do. Some of the other guys I went back and forth with.
>=20
> The SPKTRM remix of Demo is one of the absolutely most effective tunes on
> the CD, the way it=92s structured, the way it hits. It=92s just a really
> high-energy, hard ass d&b tune. When I play that out at shows it=92s like=
 the
> ultra epic track. People just go mental when that track drops.
>=20
> DOA:  That=92s the one called =93Trauma/Cell=94 and it=92s called a =93du=
omix=94?
>=20
> D:    Yeah, the original is two tracks, =93Traumatize=94 and =93The Cell.=
=94 I had
> him take =93Traumatize=94 and =93The Cell=94 and make a track that combin=
es samples
> from both tracks. I did the same thing with the Current Value
> =93Fear/Machine=94; Demo did two tracks together in one. You take the bes=
t
> elements of two tracks and get them made into a two-in-one mash-up.
>=20
> DOA:  Can we get a bit of background on the other tracks, too? Current
> Value=92s remix of Limewax=92s =93One of Them=94?
>=20
> D:    I didn=92t line that one up. SPL sent it to me and I really liked i=
t
> and licensed it. I also licensed Psidream=92s =93Death Sentence=94 and th=
e
> Upbeats=92 =93SFX.=94 The =93N/V/D=94 Counterstrike Zentraedi remix I=92d=
 had for a
> while and decided I should put it on the CD. I think it sounds kind of li=
ke
> what it probably originally should have sounded like. The structure is ve=
ry
> similar to the original but the production=92s a lot better.
>=20
> DOA:  What=92s Zentraedi?
>=20
> D:    The Zentraedi were the enemy alien race in the Robotech anime TV
> series. (laughs) What else can I tell you?
>=20
> DOA:  How about Technical Itch + Kemal =93The Calling=94 (Evol Intent and=
 Ewun
> remix)?
>=20
> D:    I basically wanted something remixed by Evol Intent and Ewun and th=
ey
> picked =93The Calling.=94 I spoke with Rob (Playford) at Moving Shadow, h=
e
> cleared it, and Mark (Caro, Technical Itch) was down. They had to pretty
> much write that tune from scratch. They had to remake =93The Calling=94 r=
iff
> because no one had the sample anymore, which made their job a lot harder.=
 I
> think Gigantor from Evol Intent did that. It was huge that he was able to
> do that. Mark liked it.
>=20
> The =93Timewarp=94 VIP is one of my favorite Counterstrike tunes in the p=
ast
> few years but I didn=92t want to use the original, so they did a more bee=
fed
> up, more polished version of it, which was great because I love the
> original of that tune.
>=20
> Mark (Technical Itch) agreed to remix his track =93Pressure Drop,=94 whic=
h was
> one of the first tunes I thought of that I wanted to have remixed. At the
> last minute Mark had just got his new studio set up, went in and complete=
ly
> rewrote the tune from scratch. I was so happy with what he turned in. It=
=92s
> a really hard-ass, steppin=92, d&b tune totally different from the origin=
al,
> very unique and very fresh. That was the last track that got turned in fo=
r
> this CD.
>=20
> =93Midnight Express=94 was something I started with Evol Intent in Novemb=
er of
> =9106 and because of our schedules and whatnot it didn=92t get finished t=
ill
> the end of =9207, so that was a long time in the making. When we started =
the
> tune I was all about making something Raiden-style. It doesn=92t sound li=
ke
> Raiden but I wanted something with that techno/d&b hybrid sound. Working =
on
> it, it turned into this acid roller. The whole time we had this idea it
> would have this breakdown that would be chopped up, filtery electro-house=
.
> It ended up being more like an acid/techno/house breakdown with some
> electro sound effects in there. I wanted some hard, techno-y, up-tempo cl=
ub
> music. It goes from like techno roller to hard ass acid club tune. It get=
s
> a good response when I play it.
>=20
> DOA:  Who named it?
>=20
> D:    I did. I thought it was a cool name. There=92s a movie =93Midnight
> Express=94 about this guy that gets busted smuggling drugs and sent to th=
is
> prison in Turkey. There are a lot of drug references in SUBSTANCE D and
> it=92s all intentional. Originally I wanted every song title to have
> something to do with pharmaceuticals or drugs and I realized that wasn=92=
t
> going to happen, but I tried to get as much of that in there for the
> overall vibe of the CD.
>=20
> I was supposed to have a track on there with Gridlok called =93MDMX.=94 I=
=92d
> been playing an unfinished version of it in some of my sets and getting a
> good response, but when we sat down with it we decided it wasn=92t where =
it
> needed to be. He was busy with other projects and I didn=92t have time to=
 get
> out to the West Coast so that track didn=92t make it but hopefully I=92ll=
 have
> a chance this year to go back out to L.A. to finish it with him.
>=20
> As for the tracks on CD2, like I said I=92d been sitting on some tracks I
> wanted to put out on HUMAN so I used it as a way to put out an album for
> DJ=92s to play tracks off of, unmixed. Actually at the end of the project=
, I
> signed additional material at the last minute to get more good music on t=
he
> label =96 =93Rail Gun=94  (Demo + Cease),=94 =93Step Up=94 (Friske + Perp=
etuum),=94 and
> =93The Big Pullback=94 (Noah D).=94
>=20
> DOA:  Who=92s the voice in the =93Warning Label=94 intro?
>=20
> D:    I spent an afternoon on the Internet going through voiceover demos =
of
> all these different narrators and found this guy, Tom Kane, who=92s done =
lots
> of documentaries, has been the announcer for the Oscars, is the voice of
> Yoda in the Star Wars videogames. I contacted him and he was down to do i=
t.
>=20
> When I write my scripts, I=92m trying to walk that line between sounding
> serious and not sounding corny. I try to make it sound appropriate but no=
t
> cheesy. Tom did a few takes.  In one he sounds like HAL in the movie
> =932001.=94 I almost went with that one because it sounds detached, but i=
n the
> end I wanted a voice that had a little bit of humanity in it. The last ta=
ke
> he did he sounds like Anthony Hopkins in =93Silence of the Lambs=94 in th=
is
> weird British accent, but we didn=92t use that one.
>=20
> Then Ewun and I went over how we wanted to do it and finished it. Instead
> of crazy movie trailer sound effects in this intro, I wanted it more
> subtle, real minimal, with just a voice and little details in the voice.
> The voice pitches down in places, and there=92s little glitchy sounds. I =
did
> some phasing on the voice, like it=92s automated, so it sounds kind of li=
ke
> it=92s sucking in and out of your head. If you listen to it with headphon=
es
> you=92ll hear a slight liquidy sound in the voice that comes through in
> certain parts.
>=20
> DOA:  How did you decide which track to start with?
>=20
> D:    I spent a lot of time losing sleep over how to intro the mix, what
> d&b track to use. I was seriously bugging out because once you have the
> first track figured out, then you can connect the pieces. If you don=92t =
have
> your first track you can=92t do your mix. I=92d originally wanted to use =
the
> SPKTRM remix of =93Trauma/Cell=94 (Demo) as one of the last tunes because=
 it=92s
> so epic. I wanted to build up to it. I went to sleep one night and I had =
a
> dream that I was working on my CD and started off with that track. I woke
> up and was like, yeah, I should use that for my first tune, and that was =
my
> breakthrough. It was crazy. Once I used it, like this medical sample come=
s
> in, then it goes =93the mothafucking saga continues=94 which ties in with=
 the
> new mix. It fit perfectly.
>=20
> One thing about this CD is that the guys I worked with are guys I=92ve wo=
rked
> with before, guys from my label, guys I mostly have personal close
> friendships with and who I knew would step up their games and do really
> good jobs with their remixes. I also really wanted to help promote and pu=
sh
> guys I have really good relationships with and who I think are really
> talented. That=92s why I chose to work with these people on this CD.
>=20
> DOA:  How did you envision how the mix would progress?
>=20
> D:    Originally I didn=92t really have an idea. I was thinking I=92d sta=
rt off
> =93projectHUMAN=94 style where it kind of has more of an intro, tracks wi=
th a
> lot of synth pads and kind of builds up. But how I approached =91The 6ixt=
h
> Session=94 =96 started off with =93Messiah=94 (Kemal + Rob Data) which we=
nt into
> Tech Itch =93Heavy Metal=94 then kind of went rolling after that? The way
> =936ixth Session=94 starts - it comes in like Bam! Super impact. When I w=
oke up
> after that dream about starting with that Demo tune, I realized, wow, it
> was going to be pretty heavy, but as I was laying it out I realized, if y=
ou
> listen to it, the CD starts out real hard, then it gets rollin=92 in the
> middle, gets a bit funky with =93Timewarp,=94 then the Upbeats=92 =93Pari=
s=94 remix,
> then =93Load Rocket.=94 Then at the end I always wanted to end with the =
=93N/V/D
> tune,=94 just kind of a nod to the track I=92m most known for. It goes fr=
om
> hard to rolling into funky then ends with one last punch in the face.
> (laughs)
>=20
> DOA:  Your CD art is always an important component of your projects. How
> did you envision the art for SUBSTANCE D?
>=20
> D:    I love working with Akira Takahashi, who lives in San Francisco now=
.
> His work is really clean. He never turns in anything half-assed and he=92=
s a
> very diverse graphic designer. He can do any style and we=92ve had a
> long-standing relationship. The original idea I had, and this is the art
> direction I gave him, was I wanted the CD to look like a futuristic
> pharmaceutical drug, maybe something that might be considered an illegal
> substance now but which would be legal in the future. An audioceutical is
> what I=92m calling it.
>=20
> I wanted the CD to resemble drug packaging, with the cleanliness of steri=
le
> drug packaging but if you imagine something you might get from a pharmacy
> is white with text, I wanted it to be black but all the ink to be
> fluorescent, psychedelic, a tripped out version of what a futuristic
> pharmaceutical might be like. Kind of the opposite of what it looks like
> now. There=92s a huge drug warning. It looks like you=92ve purchased a dr=
ug in
> the form of a CD. The wheels of the circles on the front of the CD bookle=
t
> represent the time lengths of the different tracks.
>=20
> DOA:  Will there be simultaneous releases of SUBSTANCE D in other formats=
?
>=20
> D:    We=92re going to do a simultaneous release of digital 12=94=92s on
> beatport.com off of CD2. The only track that=92s not going to be on there=
 is
> =93Rail Gun=94 (Demo + Cease). Then I=92m going to submit four, I think, =
12=94=92s to
> the distributor. I actually need to work on the graphics today for the 12=

> sleeves for the label, but I=92m not sure what they=92re going to do with=
 that.
> I want it to come out in vinyl but it=92s really down to the distributor
> whether or not they can do it or not, so it=92s not going to be simultane=

> with the vinyl, but the digital will be.
>=20
> DOA:  What are you proudest about re: SUBSTANCE D?
>=20
> D:    It=92s hard for me to get perspective on this CD because it took so
> long to make. From the time I started conceptualizing and working on it
> till I turned it in, it was over a year. What I=92m proudest of is that I
> remember originally I really had no ideas. I felt like I=92d set the bar =
high
> for myself with my last two CD=92s, so okay, how can I try to beat that? =
So
> initially I had kind of a sinking feeling that I wasn=92t going to be abl=
e to
> do it. Now looking at the final version, seeing how I managed to get all
> these various elements to tie together and have a pretty wide variety of
> d&b on the CD, and the text in the art, the graphics, the intro, the trac=
k
> names, all the subtle little details that I try to put into all my projec=
ts
> - I=92m just happy that it came together the way it did. I was able to se=
t
> the bar where I wanted to. I don=92t know of anyone else who=92s done any=
thing
> like the projects I=92ve done, so I=92m happy with how it came out.
>=20
> DOA:  Are you still planning a SUBSTANCE D tour with rotating HUMAN

> DOA:  What=92s changed in your life since the release of =93The Dungeonma=
ster=92s
> Guide=94 in 2004?
>=20
> D:    My international DJ=92ing career has taken off. I travel overseas a
> lot, lot more now. Since this year started I=92ve probably been gone thre=
e

> DOA:  In a Hong Kong interview you said you=92re doing three-turntable
> mixing?
>=20
> D:     When I said three-turntables I meant two CD=92s and vinyl. It does=
n=92t
> mean I=92m always rocking three things at the same time, but a lot of tim=
es
> I=92ll have two things mixing and I=92ll be cueing up a third thing and I=
=92ll
> start the third. I=92m able to mix faster and do more than with two
> turntables or two CD players.
> DOA:  How does the current generation of d&b compare to the era of =93The
> Dungeonmaster=92s Guide?=94  SUBSTANCE D sounds really different. Has son=
g
> structure changed?
>=20
> D:    To me, maybe just because I listen to d&b a lot, the structure soun=
ds
> similar. Most tunes still have 64-bar intros and a breakdown and the midd=
le
> part could be 64-plus bars. Maybe some of the tunes I use in this
> particular mix, maybe some just have long intros, like =93Timewarp=94
> (Counterstrike VIP) is basically like one giant long intro, then a short
> breakdown and then it drops again, so it might be just the tracks I=92ve
> chosen. I don=92t feel like d&b has changed too, too much in the past few
> years. I was going to say that maybe =93Midnight Express=94 gets into som=
ething
> that=92s different, but if you listen to Tech Itch=92s =93Reborn,=94 an o=
ld d&b
> tune, it=92s all like acid techno drums, which is pretty much what =93Mid=
night
> Express=94 is. I don=92t think it=92s evolved that much. It sounds differ=
ent a
> bit, but I don=92t think it=92s terribly different from what I was doing =
on
> =93The Dungeonmaster=92s Guide.=94
>=20
> Maybe it=92s the tracks I chose. With =93projectHUMAN,=94 =93Dungeonmaste=
r=92s
> Guide,=94 SUBSTANCE D, I got people to do remixes for me and I had to rel=
y on
> what I was given. When other DJ=92s do a mix, they pick their favorite tu=
nes,
> know what they sound like and know they work together. I take a Meat Beat
> Manifesto song and say, here you go, remix this, and I=92m basically cros=
sing
> my fingers and hoping that I=92m going to get something back that I can w=
ork
> in with the other tracks I=92m getting in. It=92s really like doing it bl=
indly.
> In the end you get more interesting tunes, which is what I want, but it=
=92s
> definitely difficult because I don=92t know what I=92m going to get and h=
ave to
> work with what I=92m given.
>=20
> DOA:  Would you say SUBSTANCE D sounds more like one of your live sets?
>=20
> D:    It depends. My CD=92s and live sets are different. I pretty much do=
n=92t
> play dance floor tunes on my CD=92s; I play heavier tunes. In my live set=
s I
> play dance floor stuff if I=92m playing for that kind of crowd. If I=92m
> playing in Eastern Europe I might play more the style of what=92s on
> SUBSTANCE D. At my gig the weekend before in Holland, those kids like it
> pretty hard there so my set sounded more like what SUBSTANCE D sounds lik=
e,
> that style. But I=92ve always played diverse d&b sets depending on where =
I=92m
> playing. Definitely I=92ve played shows where the sound has the same
> heaviness as SUBSTANCE D, but it just depends on where I am. All the trac=
ks
> on SUBSTANCE D I=92ve played out.
>=20
> DOA:  Will there be a Planet of the Drums tour this year?
>=20
> D:    Our ninth annual tour! We=92re planning it to start in September.
>=20
> DOA:  Commander on DOA was asking about your opening your set at Renegade
> Hardware a few years ago with a =93stunning rock intro=94 to KC=92s =93Ex=
treme
> Steel.=94 He wanted to know what remix that was and if it=92s ever coming=

d

> there=92s no special version. It=92s two different songs.
>=20
> DOA:  Any other thoughts to share on SUBSTANCE D?
>=20
> D:    I had so many problems and weird setbacks pop up along the way
> preparing this CD, like stuff I thought was happening falling through. In
> the last three weeks before I had to turn it in, I felt like I was runnin=
g
> toward the finish line of a race and my shoes were falling apart. (laughs=
)
>=20
> It=92s hard for me to have a really honest opinion about my own CD. Four
> years ago when I did =93The Dungeonmaster=92s Guide=94 there weren=92t so=

> leaks of tracks on the Internet. For this I had to jump through hoops to
> make sure people didn=92t hear these tracks outside of hearing me DJ. I
> wanted the dogs to see the tracklist on DOA and be like, wow, whoa, I don=
=92t
> know these tunes! That=92s something I really wanted. That=92s not easy
> nowadays! I think I did a pretty good job of that but it was a pretty
> nerve-wracking, stressful road. I hope people like it.
>=20
> DOA:  What are you going to do now?
>=20
> D:    I took the past weekend off to be best man at my agent=92s wedding =
and
> I=92ve got the end of the month off before I=92m going to be full on DJ=

> After I get these Monsters of Jungle graphics knocked out I=92ll be good =
